Right distributivity of multiplication over addition (a+b)\star c=(a\star c)+(b\star c) Some rings don't have a multiplicative unit 1, in which case they are "nonunital rings". If we don't care about the existence of the multiplicative unit, we'll just speak of "rings".

We also don't require all rings to be associative (i.e., multiplication may or may not be associative). When it matters, we will speak of "associative rings" and "nonassociative rings", but by default we will assume rings as associative.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We could define a unital ring as an Abelian group equipped with a monoid structure. The axioms for a unital ring would be satisfied automatically.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The integers \mathbb {Z} equipped with the usual addition and multiplication forms a Ring.
We need to prove that all 8 axioms are satisfied, but they are straightforward arithmetic.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The integers are the epitome of a ring.

fr:title.text: Rationals, reals, complex numbers are a ring

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Rationals, reals, complex numbers are a ring

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The rational numbers \mathbb {Q}, the real numbers \mathbb {R}, and the complex numbers form a ring.

Let R be a Ring, let n\in \mathbb {N}_{0} be any non-negative integer. We define the Matrix Ring \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(R) to consist of all n\times n matrices equipped with Matrix Addition and Matrix Multiplication forms a ring.
Moreover, if R is unital, then \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(R) is unital where its multiplicative identity is the identity matrix (and we see it satisfies the unit axioms).
Let R be a Ring. We say R is Commutative if its multiplication operator is a Commutative binary operator.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We see \mathbb {Z}, \mathbb {Q}, \mathbb {R}, and \mathbb {C} are commutative rings. But in general the Matrix ring is noncommutative since Matrix Multiplication is not commutative generally.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Quaternions is a generalization of the complex numbers, denoted as \mathbb {H} (after William Hamilton) consisting of t+ix+jy+kz where t,x,y,z\in \mathbb {R} are real numbers, where the imaginary "numbers" satisfy i^{2}=j^{2}=k^{2}=ijk=-1. It's not hard to deduce that jk=-kj=i ki=-ik=j ij=-ji=k Addition is given by (a+ib+jc+kd)+(t+ix+jy+kz)=(a+t)+i(b+x)+j(c+y)+k(d+z) and multiplication is given by \begin {align*} (a+ib+jc+kd)(t+ix+jy+kz) &=(at-bx-cy-dz)\\ &\quad +i(at+bx+cz-dy)\\ &\quad +j(ct-bz+cy+dx)\\ &\quad +k(az+by-cx+dt)\end {align*} This means the quaternions form a noncommutative ring.
(1) Quaternions turn out to be useful for 3d computer graphics.

(2) Although Springer's LaTeX macros uses \mathrm{i} for \sqrt {-1}, the conventions for the imaginary quaternions i, j, k varies wildly. Wikipedia uses bold symbols. Michael Kinyon told me on Bluesky that "Gibbs, in his 1881 Elements of Vector Analysis book (more like a pamphlet), just used the math typeface of his day for i,j,k."

From the past few examples, it should be clear that we should think of rings as number systems. In the 19th century, many Mathematicians explored different "number systems" by adding new "numbers" analogous to \mathrm {i}=\sqrt {-1}. This was how Hamilton invented the Quaternions. Many other rings were invented in this manner, and it's the best intuition to have in mind while we continue to study rings.
The set \mathbb {Z}[i]=\{x+\mathrm {i} y\in \mathbb {C}\mid x,y\in \mathbb {Z}\} forms a ring when equipped with addition and multiplication from the complex numbers.
Moreover, since multiplication of complex numbers is commutative, this forms a Commutative Ring.

Let \omega =\mathop {\textrm {exp}}\nolimits (\mathrm {i} 2\pi / 3)=(-1+\mathrm {i}\sqrt {3}) / 2. Then the set \mathbb {Z}[\omega ]=\{a+b\omega \in \mathbb {C}\mid a,b\in \mathbb {Z}\} forms a Commutative Ring when equipped with addition and multiplication from the complex numbers. These form the ring of Hurwitz integers.
Let A be an additive Abelian group. Then the set \mathop {\textrm {End}}\nolimits (A) of group morphisms ("endomorphisms") f\colon A\to A is a ring.
We see (f+g)(x)=f(x)+g(x) and (f\star g)(x)=(f\circ g)(x)=f(g(x)) are the binary operators for the ring.
This is called the Endomorphism Ring of A.

fr:title.text: Multiplication by Zero is Zero in a ring

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Multiplication by Zero is Zero in a ring

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a (possibly non-unital) Ring. For any x\in R, we see 0\star x=0 and x\star 0=0.

We see from 0+0=0 that (0+0)\star x=0\star x. But distributivity rewrites the left-hand side as (0\star x)+(0\star x)=0\star x, then subtracting 0\star x from both sides gives us 0\star x=0 as desired.

Similarly, from 0+0=0 we see x\star (0+0)=x\star 0. Distributivity allows us to rewrite the left-hand side again as (x\star 0)+(x\star 0)=x\star 0 and then subtracting x\star 0 from both sides gives us x\star 0=0 as desired.
A unital Ring R with 1\neq 0 is called a Division Ring (or Skew Field) if for every nonzero element a\in R there exists a multiplicative inverse, i.e., there exists a b\in R such that ab=ba=1.
Let R be a unital Ring with 1\neq 0. If x\in R has a unique multiplicative two-sided inverse, then we will just denote it by x^{-1}.
Let R be a unital (possibly nonassociative) Ring. Let x\in R be an element of R. We say x is a Unit if it has a two-sided inverse x^{-1}\in R such that x^{-1}x=xx^{-1}=1.

fr:title.text: Inverse of one is one in a ring

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inverse of one is one in a ring

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a unital Ring. Then 1^{-1}=1 and (-1)^{-1}=-1 in R.
We see 1=1\star 1^{-1}=1^{-1} the first equality by definition of multiplicative inverse, the second equality by the unital property.

Similarly 1=(-1)\star (-1)^{-1} so then adding -1 to both sides gives us 0=1-1=(-1)\star (-1)^{-1}+(-1) and distributivity allows us to rewrite (-1)\star (-1)^{-1}+(-1)=(-1)\star ((-1)^{-1}+1)=0. So either -1=0 or (-1)^{-1}+1=0.
If (-1)^{-1}+1=0, then adding -1 to both sides gives us the result.

fr:title.text: Negation in a unital ring is multiplying by minus one

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Negation in a unital ring is multiplying by minus one

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a unital Ring. For any x\in R we have -x=(-1)\star x.
We see x+(-1)\star x=1\star x+(-1)\star x and then distributivity gives us x+(-1)\star x=(1-1)\star x=0\star x and from Multiplication by Zero is Zero in a ring we have the result.

Let R_{1} and R_{2} be Rings. We define their Product Ring R_{1}\times R_{2} to consist of the direct product of the underlying set of elements of R_{1} with R_{2}, equipped with the operations (a,b)+(c,d)=(a+c,b+d) and (a,b)(c,d)=(ac,bd). This forms a ring.
Moreover, if R_{1} and R_{2} are both commutative, then R_{1}\times R_{2} is commutative.
And if R_{1} and R_{2} are both unital, then R_{1}\times R_{2} is unital.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This generalizes to any indexed family of rings \{R_{i}\}_{i\in I}.

fr:title.text: Set of nonzero elements in a ring

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Set of nonzero elements in a ring

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be an arbitrary Ring. Then the Set of Nonzero Elements of R is denoted by R^{*}:=\{x\in R\mid x\neq 0\}.

fr:title.text: Set of invertible elements of a ring

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Set of invertible elements of a ring

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a unital (possibly nonassociative) Ring. We define the Set of Invertible Elements of R to be the set of elements with two-sided inverses: R^{\times }:=\{x\in R\mid \exists x^{-1}\in R\ldotp xx^{-1}=x^{-1}x=1\}. Furthermore, if multiplication is associative, then this forms a group.
This example generalizes to any n\geq 2 and any unital Ring R (with a single nonzero entry instead of 1 for non-unital rings).

fr:title.text: Ring of formal distributions has zero divisors

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ring of formal distributions has zero divisors

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field (but it could be any commutative ring, however nice you want it). Let x be a formal variable. Consider the Ring of Formal Distributions \mathbb {F}[{[x,x^{-1}]}] which consists of generic formal power series like f(x)=\sum ^{\infty }_{n=-\infty }a_{n}x^{n}. Consider the specific function \delta (x)=\sum _{n\in \mathbb {Z}}x^{n} Then x\delta (x)=\delta (x) so (1-x)\delta (x). But 1-x\neq 0 and \delta (x)\neq 0, so \mathbb {F}[{[x,x^{-1}]}] has zero divisors.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This ring appears when studying Vertex Operator Algebras, a sort of formal model of 1-dimensional quantum field theories.

fr:title.text: Ring elements are either units or some kind of zero divisor

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ring elements are either units or some kind of zero divisor

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a unital associative Ring, let x\in R be any arbitrary element of R. Then either x is a Unit or x is a Zero Divisor.
The situation for x being a right zero divisor is similar.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: It is important to stress that the ring must be associative. The Sedonions are a nonassociative unital ring where nonzero elements have a multiplicative inverse and there are also zero divisors.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A Ring is called a Domain if it has no Zero Divisors.
An Integral Domain is a commutative Domain.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A Field is traditionally defined as a set F with two binary operators, addition (denoted +) and multiplication (denoted \cdot ), satisfying the field axioms:

fr:ol.fr:li: Associativity of addition: for all x,y,z\in F, (x+y)+z=x+(y+z)
Commutativity of addition: for all x,y\in F, x+y=y+x
Additive identity: there exists a 0\in F such that for all x\in F we have 0+x=x and x+0=x
Additive inverses: for each x\in F there is a unique y\in F such that x+y=0 and y+x=0; in this case, we usually denote y as (-x)
Associativity of multiplication: for all x,y,z\in F, (x\cdot y)\cdot z=x\cdot (y\cdot z)
Commutativity of multiplication: for all x,y\in F, x\cdot y=y\cdot x
Multiplicative identity: there exists a 1\in F such that for all x\in F we have 1\cdot x=x and x\cdot 1=x
Multiplicative inverses: for each x\in F which is nonzero x\neq 0 there is a unique y\in F such that x\cdot y=1 and y\cdot x=1; usually we denote y as x^{-1}
Distributivity of multiplication over addition: for all x,y,z\in F, we have x\cdot (y+z)=(x\cdot y)+(x\cdot z) and (x+y)\cdot z=(x\cdot z)+(x\cdot y)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Note that some of these are redundant.
Also note: fields are usually written in blackboard bold, and the generic field is either \mathbb {F} or \Bbbk (since the German word for field is "Körper").

fr:title.text: Integers modulo a prime form a field

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Integers modulo a prime form a field

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let p\in \mathbb {N} be a prime number. Then \mathbb {F}_{p}:=\mathbb {Z} / p\mathbb {Z} forms a Field.
Let us write \overline {n} for the element of \mathbb {F}_{p} corresponding to the equivalence class containing n\in \mathbb {Z}.
Claim 1: \mathbb {F}_{p} forms an Abelian group with addition and \overline {0}.
Claim 2: \mathbb {F}_{p} forms a commutative unital ring with multiplication and multiplicative identity \overline {1}.
Claim 3: Every nonzero \overline {n}\in \mathbb {F}_{p} has a multiplicative inverse.

Let R be a Commutative Ring. Let x\notin R be a formal variable (just a symbol, not a number). We define the Ring of Polynomials with coefficients R and in unknown x to be the ring R[x] consisting of formal polynomials which are finite sums p(x)=\sum ^{n}_{k=0}a_{k}x^{k} where a_{n}\neq 0, addition is done with the coefficients of each power, and multiplication is done using the Cauchy convolution product \left (\sum ^{m}_{j=0}a_{j}x^{j}\right )\left (\sum ^{n}_{k=0}b_{k}x^{k}\right )=\sum ^{m+n}_{k=0}\left (\sum ^{k}_{j=0}a_{j}b_{k-j}\right )x^{k}. Then this forms a commutative ring.
(2) We could generalize this to noncommutative R, but there are subtle issues which cause problems best left to be revisited in a graduate level algebra course.

Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. An n-dimensional Multi-Index is an n tuple \alpha =(\alpha _{1},…,\alpha _{n}) where each component \alpha _{i}\in \mathbb {N}_{0} is a non-negative integer.
We have the following operations defined:

fr:ol.fr:li: Componentwise sum and difference: \alpha \pm \beta =(\alpha _{1}\pm \beta _{1},…,\alpha _{n}\pm \beta _{n})
Sum of components |\alpha |=\alpha _{1}+…+\alpha _{n}
Factorial \alpha !=\alpha _{1}!(…)!\alpha _{n}!
If x=(x_{1},…,x_{n}) is a tuple of unknowns (or knowns), then x^{\alpha }=x_{1}^{\alpha _{1}}(…)x_{n}^{\alpha _{n}}

fr:title.text: Properties of degree of formal polynomials

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of degree of formal polynomials

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring, let p,q\in R[x_{1},…,x_{n}] be nonzero formal polynomials. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: If R is an integral domain, then \deg (fg)=\deg (f)+\deg (g)

fr:title.text: Ring of formal polynomials with coefficients in integral domain forms an integral domain

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ring of formal polynomials with coefficients in integral domain forms an integral domain

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be an Integral domain. Let x be a formal polynomial. Then the Polynomial ring R[x] is an integral domain.

Let R be a Commutative Ring, let x be a formal variable. We define the Ring of Formal Laurent Polynomials to be the ring R(x)=\{\sum ^{n}_{j=-k}a_{k}x^{k}\mid a_{j}\in R, a_{-k}\neq 0,a_{n}\neq 0, n,k\in \mathbb {N}_{0}\}.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Caution: Terminology seems to vary wildly here. Some people reserve the term "Laurent polynomials" for the situation where n=\infty . I'm going to call these things Formal Laurent series and denote it by R(\mskip -3mu(x)\mskip -3mu) in analogy to R[{[x]}].

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring. Let x be a formal variable. The Ring of Formal Power Series R[{[x]}] consists of all formal power series f(x)=\sum ^{\infty }_{n=0}a_{n}x^{n} with addition defined by matching powers of x: \left (\sum _{n}a_{n}x^{n}\right )+\left (\sum _{m}b_{m}x^{m}\right )=\sum _{n}(a_{n}+b_{n})x^{n} and multiplication defined by Cauchy convolution product \left (\sum _{n}a_{n}x^{n}\right )\left (\sum _{m}b_{m}x^{m}\right )=\sum _{n=0}\left (\sum ^{n}_{k=0}a_{n-k}b_{k}\right )x^{n}. This is a unital ring when R is unital.

Let R be a Ring. A Subring of R is a ring S such that S\subseteq R and 0\in S and +_{R}|_{S}=+_{S} and \star _{R}|_{S}=\star _{S}. In other words, every element of S is an element of R, and R's binary operators restricted to S coincide with S's binary operators.
If R is a unital ring and 1\in S, then we say S is a Unital Subring of R.
We see \mathbb {Z}\subseteq \mathbb {Q}\subseteq \mathbb {R}\subseteq \mathbb {C}\subseteq \mathbb {H} are subrings.
Let n\in \mathbb {N} and R be a Ring. Then some common subrings of \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(R) include:

fr:ol.fr:li: Diagonal matrices form a subring
Upper-triangular matrices form a subring
Lower-triangular matrices form a subring

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Exercise: Do the collection of orthogonal matrices form a subring or not?
Exercise: Do the collection of unitary matrices form a subring of \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(\mathbb {C}) or not?

Let R be a Ring. The Center of R is the subring Z(R) consisting of z\in R such that for all r\in R we have zr=rz and also (for non-associative rings) for all r,s\in R and for all z\in Z(R) we have z(rs)=(zr)s and r(zs)=(rz)s and (rs)z=r(sz). In other words, Z(R) consists of elements which commute and associate with all elements of the ring.
Uniqueness: If there are two possible centers, it's obvious they contain the same elements, which means they are equal to each other.

Existence: We see that the underlying set is nonempty and well-defined. We just need to show it is closed under addition and multiplication and contains 0\in Z(R)...well, 0r=0=r0 for all r\in R, so 0\in Z(R).
We see for any z,w\in Z(R) that for all r\in R, (z+w)r=zr+wr=rz+rw=r(z+w) which means z+w\in Z(R). So it's closed under addition
We see for any z,w\in Z(R) that for all r\in R, (zw)r=z(wr)=(wr)z=(rw)z=r(wz)=r(zw) which means zw\in Z(R). So it's closed under multiplication.
Taken together, this means there exists a well-defined center Z(R) which is a subring of R.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: For associative rings R, we only need to check that zr=rz for all z\in Z(R) and for all r\in R, since it's associative.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Exercise: If R is unital, is 1\in Z(R) or not? Prove it.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ring morphism
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R and S be Rings. We define a Ring Morphism (or just a Morphism if unambiguous) to be a function \varphi \colon R\to S such that:

fr:ol.fr:li: Additive: for any x,y\in R we have \varphi (x+y)=\varphi (x)+\varphi (y)
Preserves zero: \varphi (0_{R})=0_{S}
Multiplicative: for any x,y\in R we have \varphi (xy)=\varphi (x)\varphi (y)
Preserves one (when between unital rings): \varphi (1_{R})=1_{S} when there is a 1_{R}\in R and 1_{S}\in S

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Exercise: Do we really need \varphi (0)=0 or is this a consequence of additivity?
Exercise: Do we really need \varphi (1_{R})=1_{S} or is this a consequence of the multiplicative property?

fr:title.text: Inclusion of factor into direct product

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inclusion of factor into direct product

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Consider i\colon \mathbb {Q}\hookrightarrow \mathbb {Q}\times \mathbb {Q} defined by i(x)=(x,0). We claim i is not a Ring morphism.
We see that i(1)=(1,0)\neq (1,1) so i cannot possibly be multiplicative.

fr:title.text: Not all rings have morphisms between them

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Not all rings have morphisms between them

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let p\in \mathbb {N} be prime. Then there is no ring morphism \varphi \colon \mathbb {F}_{p}\to \mathbb {Z} from any finite field to the integers.

Assume there were a ring morphism. Then \varphi (1+(p-1))=\varphi (1)+\varphi (p-1) by additivity, but \varphi (1+(p-1))=\varphi (p)=\varphi (0)=0, so we must have \varphi (1)+\varphi (p-1)=0 which then implies 0=\varphi (1)+\varphi (p)-\varphi (1)=\varphi (p). But this means p=\varphi (\sum ^{p}_{i=1}1)=0 which is a contradiction.

fr:title.text: Identity function is a ring morphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity function is a ring morphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Ring. Then \mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{R}\colon R\to R is a Ring morphism.
Let R and S be Rings. Let \varphi \colon R\to S be a Ring morphism. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: For any x\in R, \varphi (-x)=-\varphi (x)
For any x,y\in R, \varphi (x-y)=\varphi (x)-\varphi (y)
If R is unital, then either \varphi (1)=1 or \varphi (1)=0.
For any ring T and Ring morphism \psi \colon S\to T, we see \psi \circ \varphi \colon R\to T is a ring morphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Left ideal of a ring
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let R be a Ring. A Left Ideal of R is a nonempty subset I\subseteq R such that
for any r\in R and x\in I we have rx\in I; and
for any x,y\in I we have x+y\in I.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We could speak of ideals in more general settings, e.g., rings without negation.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Right ideal of a ring
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let R be a Ring. A Right Ideal of R is a nonempty subset I\subseteq R such that
for any r\in R and x\in I we have xr\in I; and
for any x,y\in I we have x+y\in I.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ideal
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Ring. A (Two-Sided) Ideal of R is a nonempty subset I\subseteq R such that I is a left ideal and a right ideal of R.
Furthermore, when I\neq R we say I is a Proper (two-sided) ideal of R.

Some authors use the notation I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq }R to indicate I is an ideal of R, as well as I\mathrel {\triangleleft }R for proper ideals, analogous to the notation used for Normal subgroups.
(1) For commutative rings, any left ideal is also a right ideal, and so we just speak of "ideals".
(2) "Ideal" originally described "ideal elements" adjoined to a ring, which are not "real".
(3) A two-sided ideal forms a Subring of R, same for one-sided ideals of R.

(4) Traditionally, the historic notation used to indicate we're working with ideals was to use fraktur letters (\mathfrak {a}, \mathfrak {b}, \mathfrak {c}, and so on). This was a horrible decision. Modern conventions use I, J, and variants using apostrophes or indices.

fr:title.text: Collection of ideals forms a set

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Collection of ideals forms a set

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Ring. Then the collection of left/right/two-sided ideals of R forms a set.

Look at the set \mathcal {I}=\{I\in \mathcal {P}(R)\mid I\hbox { is an ideal}\}, where "is an ideal" means the subset is a left/right/two-sided ideal (depending on what the reader wants). This is clearly a subset of \mathcal {P}(R), which means \mathcal {I} is the set sought.
Let R be a Ring. Let I and J be left/right/two-sided ideals of R. Then we define their sum to be the left/right/two-sided ideal I+J=\{a+b\in R\mid a\in I,b\in J\}.

Let R be a Ring. Let I and J be left/right/two-sided ideals of R. Then we define their product to be the left/right/two-sided ideal consisting of all possible finite linear combinations IJ=\{a_{1}b_{1}+…+a_{n}b_{n}\in R\mid n\in \mathbb {N},a_{i}\in I,b_{i}\in J\hbox { for }i=1,…,n\}.

Let \varphi \colon R\to S be a Ring morphism. We define the Kernel of \varphi to be the (two-sided) Ideal \ker (\varphi ) of R defined by: for all x\in R we have x\in \ker (\varphi ) if and only if \varphi (x)=0.
Let R be any Ring. Then \{0\} gives us an Ideal of R called the Trivial Ideal.

fr:title.text: Intersection of ideals is an ideal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Intersection of ideals is an ideal

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Ring. Let I and J be left (resp., right, two-sided) ideals of R. Then I\cap J is a left (resp., right, two-sided) ideal of R.

fr:title.text: Division rings have trivial left ideals

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Division rings have trivial left ideals

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let D be a Division ring. Then the only left ideals of D are D itself and the Trivial ideal.
Let I be a left ideal of D. Let x\in I be nonzero x\neq 0. Then there exists a x^{-1}\in D such that x^{-1}x=1\in I and then all of D is contained in I.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Quotient Ring
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 7.3.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Ring and I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R be an Ideal of R. Then the additive quotient group R/I is a ring under the following binary operators (r+I)+(s+I)=(r+s)+I and (r+I)(s+I)=(rs)+I for all r,s\in R.

Furthermore,
If R is commutative, then R/I is commutative.
If R is unital, then R/I is unital.

To prove well-definedness, we should prove R/I equipped with these operators form a ring (since existence and uniqueness follow from the quotient group). Specifically, that multiplication exists and satisfies the various axioms.
Let R be a Ring, let I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R be an Ideal of R. The Canonical Morphism \pi \colon R\to R/I is defined by: for any a\in R, \pi (a)=a+I.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: There is no standard notation for the canonical morphism, and I was debating between \gamma (Greek lowercase "c" for "canonical") and \pi since it's a sort of projection.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R and S be Rings. A Ring Isomorphism from R to S is a Ring morphism \varphi \colon R\to S such that there exists a ring morphism \psi \colon S\to R satisfying \varphi \circ \psi =\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{S} and \psi \circ \varphi =\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{R}.
We say rings R and S are isomorphic (denoted R\cong S) if there exists a ring isomorphism \varphi \colon R\to S.
Let \varphi \colon R\to S be a Ring morphism. Then \varphi is a Ring Isomorphism if and only if \varphi is bijective.
Let \varphi \colon R\to S be a Ring morphism. Then the following all holds:

fr:ol.fr:li: \ker (\varphi )\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R is an Ideal of R
\mathop {\textrm {Im}}\nolimits (\varphi )\subseteq S is a Subring.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Canonical ring morphism of \ker (\varphi ) is the Ring Isomorphism being sought.
Let R be a Ring, let A\subseteq R be a Subring of R, and let I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R be an Ideal of R. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: A+I\subseteq R is a subring
A/(A\cap I)\cong (A+I)/I with the isomorphism defined by a\mapsto a+I

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Only the first two results needs to be proven.
Let R be a Ring. Let I,J\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R be Ideals of R. If I\subseteq J, then J / I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R / I and \frac {R / I}{J / I}\cong R / J.
Let R be a Ring. Then:

fr:ol.fr:li: A Left Principal Ideal of R is the ideal Ra=\{xa\in R\mid x\in R\} for some fixed a\in R.
A Right Principal Ideal of R is the ideal aR=\{ay\in R\mid y\in R\} for some fixed a\in R.
A Left Principal Ideal of R is the ideal RaR=\{xay\in R\mid x,y\in R\} for some fixed a\in R.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: When R is a Commutative Ring, all three notions coincide and we write (a) for the principal ideal generated by a.
Let R be a Ring.

fr:ol.fr:li: A Maximal Right Ideal is a proper right ideal I\subset R such that for any other right ideal J\subseteq R, if I\subseteq J then either I=J or J=R.
A Maximal Left Ideal is a proper left ideal I\subset R such that for any other left ideal J\subseteq R, if I\subseteq J then either I=J or J=R.
A Maximal (Two-Sided) Ideal is a proper ideal I\mathrel {\triangleleft } R such that for any other ideal J\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R, if I\subseteq J then either I=J or J=R.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: When we drop the condition that I is proper, then we have a Quasi-Maximal left/right/two-sided ideal.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: For commutative rings R, all three notions coincide.

fr:title.text: Ideal is maximal iff quotient ring is field

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ideal is maximal iff quotient ring is field
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 7.4.12

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring, let M\mathrel {\triangleleft } R be an ideal. Then M is Maximal ideal if and only if the Quotient Ring R/M is a Field.
Let R be a Commutative Ring. An ideal P\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R is Quasi-Prime if for any a,b\in R such that ab\in P, then either a\in P or b\in P.
If P\mathrel {\triangleleft } R is a proper quasi-prime ideal, then we say it is a Prime Ideal.

(1) This notion does not generalize to noncommutative rings. If we tried "naively" looking for ideals of \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{2}(\mathbb {C}) which are prime, then we will not find any. It remains an open problem how to define prime ideals for noncommutative rings.

(2) Hungerford Algebra Exercise 9(b) in Section III.2 asks the reader to prove: if D is a division ring and R=\mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(D), then R has zero divisors and so the trivial ideal (0) is prime, which means R\cong R/(0) but R is not an integral domain. This is because R is not a commutative ring. (See? Things get really weird when trying to think about prime ideals in a noncommutative ring.)

fr:title.text: Ideal is prime iff quotient ring is integral domain

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ideal is prime iff quotient ring is integral domain
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 7.4.13

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring, let P\mathrel {\triangleleft } R be an ideal. Then P is Prime Ideal if and only if the Quotient Ring R/P is a Integral domain.

fr:title.text: Maximal ideals of a commutative ring are prime

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Maximal ideals of a commutative ring are prime

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring. If M\mathrel {\triangleleft } R is a Maximal ideal, then M is prime.
Assume M is maximal. Then R/M is a field (since Ideal is maximal iff quotient ring is field). Then R/M is a Field. Then M is prime by Ideal is prime iff quotient ring is integral domain.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Existence of Maximal Ideals
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Krull's Idealtheorie in Ringen ohne Endlichkeitsbedingung (1929)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R\neq 0 be a nonzero unital Ring. Then there exists a maximal ideal M\mathrel {\triangleleft } R of R.

The typical proof offered is: consider the lattice of proper ideals of R ordered by inclusion. There exists at least one ideal of R (e.g., the Trivial ideal). Then Zorn's lemma implies there exists a maximal element of a chain containing the trivial ideal.
(1) This is often called "Krull's theorem", which is unfortunate because there are about a half dozen different results in ring theory called "Krull's theorem".

(2) The condition that R is unital is really critical. For example, we can turn any additive group G into a nonunital ring by defining multiplication x\star y=0 for all x,y\in R. There is no maximal ideal for such a ring

(3) In ZF set theory, this theorem implies the axiom of choice. Hodges first proved it. For a review of this, see Alexei Entin's "Maximal Ideals in Commutative Rings and the Axiom of Choice" (arXiv:2404.18351).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ideal generated by a set
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a unital Ring with 1\neq 0. Let A\subseteq R be any subset of R. Then the Ideal Generated by A is the ideal \langle A\rangle of R equal to \langle A\rangle = \bigcap _{A\subseteq I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R}I. This is the smallest ideal of R containing A.
When A=\{a_{1},…,a_{n}\} is a finite set, then we just write \langle a_{1},…,a_{n}\rangle or (a_{1},…,a_{n}) for the ideal generated by A.
Exercise: What is \langle \emptyset \rangle the ideal generated by the empty set?
Exercise: If we allow R to be a nonunital ring, then is the ideal generated by a set still well-defined?

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Fields only have trivial ideals
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 7.4.9(2)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring. Then R is a Field if and only if its only ideals are 0 and R.
We see R is a field iff every nonzero element is a unit (by definition of a field).
(\Longrightarrow ) If R is a field, then every nonzero ideal contains a unit, which means that R is the only nonzero ideal.

(\Longleftarrow ) Suppose the only ideals of R is the trivial ideal and R itself. Let u be any nonzero element of R. Then (u)=R so 1\in (u). Hence there must be some v\in R such that 1=vu (i.e., u is a unit). Therefore every nonzero element of R is a unit, hence R must be a field.

fr:title.text: Field morphisms are injective nonzero ring morphisms

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field morphisms are injective nonzero ring morphisms
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Corollary 7.4.10

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If \mathbb {F} is a Field, then any nonzero Ring morphism from \mathbb {F} into another ring must be an Injective function.
The Kernel of a ring morphism is an ideal. The kernel of a nonzero morphism is a proper ideal, hence must be 0 by Field morphisms are injective nonzero ring morphisms.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Principal Ideal Domain
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An Integral domain R is called a Principal Ideal Domain if every ideal is principal (i.e., generated by a single element).

Let R be a Principal Ideal Domain. Let I_{1},I_{2},…,I_{n},I_{n+1},…,\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R be ideals of R such that I_{1}\subseteq I_{2}\subseteq …\subseteq I_{n}\subseteq I_{n+1}\subseteq …. Then there exists an n_{0}\in \mathbb {N} such that I_{n}=I_{n_{0}} for all n\geq n_{0}.
Let I=\bigcup _{n}I_{n}. If a,b\in I, then a\in I_{m} and b\in I_{n} for some m,n\in \mathbb {N}. If p=\max (m,n) and a,b\in I_{p}, then a\pm b\in I_{p}\subseteq I. So I forms a group under addition.
For any a\in I, there is an n\in \mathbb {N} such that a\in I_{n}. Then for any r\in R we have ra\in I_{n}\subseteq I. So I forms an ideal.

Since R is a Principal Ideal Domain, there exists an a_{0} such that I=(a_{0}). But then there exists an n_{0} such that a\in I_{n_{0}}. So I=(a_{0})\subseteq I_{n_{0}}. Then for any n\geq n_{0}, we have I\subseteq I_{n_{0}}\subseteq I_{n}\subseteq I which proves the chain of ideals stabilizes.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Euclidean Domain
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 8.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An Integral domain R is said to be a Euclidean Domain if there is a norm N\colon R\to \mathbb {N}_{0} such that for any two elements a,b\in R with b\neq 0, there exists elements [the quotient] q\in R and [the remainder] r\in R such that a=qb+r and r=0\quad \hbox {or}\quad N(r)<N(b).
The integers form a Euclidean Domain when given the absolute value as its norm N(x)=|x|. This is because of the Division algorithm.

fr:title.text: Euclidean Domains are Principal Ideal Domains

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Euclidean Domains are Principal Ideal Domains
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 8.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Every ideal in a Euclidean Domain is principal: if R is any Euclidean domain and I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R with 0\neq I, then I=(d) where d is any nonzero element of I of minimum norm.

Let R be a Commutative Ring. Let a,b\in R with b\neq 0. We say a is a Multiple of b if there exists some x\in R such that a=bx. In this case, we say b divides a (or b is a divisor of a) and we write b\mathrel {\bigm |} a.

Let R be a Commutative Ring. Let a,b\in R with b\neq 0. A Greatest Common Divisor of a and b is a nonzero element d\in R such that:
It's a common divisor: d\mathrel {\bigm |} a and d\mathrel {\bigm |} b, and
It's greatest: for any d'\in R such that d'\mathrel {\bigm |} a and d'\mathrel {\bigm |} b, we have d'\mathrel {\bigm |} d. A greatest common divisor of a and b is denoted by \gcd (a,b) or (abusing notation) by (a,b).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This isn't necessarily unique, we may have multiple distinct greatest common divisors of a and b. When it is unique, we call the ring a GCD Domain (and it turns out to be an Integral domain).

fr:title.text: Existence and Uniqueness of GCD in Euclidean Domains

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Existence and Uniqueness of GCD in Euclidean Domains

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let R be a Euclidean Domain. Then for any nonzero a,b\in R,
There exists a unique d\in R (up to unit multiple) such that d=\gcd (a,b); and
there exists x,y\in R such that \gcd (a,b)=ax+by.

This follows by performing Euclid's algorithm; i.e., we repeatedly apply the division algorithm to find b=q_{1}a+r_{1}, a=q_{2}r_{1}+r_{2}, r_{1}=q_{3}r_{2}+r_{3}, …, r_{n+1}=q_{n+3}r_{n+2}. Then r_{n+2}=\gcd (a,b) since:
(1) (r_{n+2})\subseteq (a,b)
(2) (a,b)\subseteq (r_{n+2})
Hence by (1) and (2) and since Euclidean Domains are Principal Ideal Domains, we have (r_{n+2})=(a,b) which implies the result.
Let R be a Commutative Ring, let p\in R be a nonzero element which is not a unit. We say p is Prime if whenever p\mathrel {\bigm |} ab then either p\mathrel {\bigm |} a or p\mathrel {\bigm |} b.
Exercise: Can this be generalized to a unital associative ring?

fr:title.text: Element is prime iff it generates a nonzero prime ideal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Element is prime iff it generates a nonzero prime ideal

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring where 1\neq 0, let p\in R. Then p is a Prime element if and only if (p) is a nonzero Prime Ideal.

(\Longrightarrow ) Let p be a Prime element. Then for any a,b\in R, \begin {align*}ab\in (p) &\iff \exists r\in R\ldotp ab=pr\\ &\iff p\mathrel {\bigm |} ab \hbox { iff }p\mathrel {\bigm |} a\hbox { or }p\mathrel {\bigm |} b\\ &\iff a\in (p)\hbox { or }b\in (p)\\ &\iff (p) \hbox { is a prime ideal}\end {align*}

(\Longleftarrow ) Let P=(p) be a nonzero prime ideal. For any a,b\in R, if p\mathrel {\bigm |} ab, then ab\in P, which implies a\in P or b\in P by definition of prime ideals. So we have p\mathrel {\bigm |} a or p\mathrel {\bigm |} b. Hence p is a prime element of R.
Let R be a Commutative Ring, let p\in R be a nonzero element which is not a unit. We say p is Irreducible if whenever d\mathrel {\bigm |} p, then we have either d=pu or d=u for some unit u\in R.
When p is not irreducible, we say it is Reducible.
Exercise: Can this be generalized to a unital associative ring?

Let R be a Commutative Ring, let p\in R be an element of R. Then p is irreducible if and only if its Principal Ideal (p) is a nonzero Maximal ideal among principal ideals (i.e., (p) may be a proper subideal of some ideal I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R where I may or may not be a proper ideal, just so long as I is not a principal ideal).
If a=pu, then (a)=(p), hence (p) is maximal among proper principal ideals.

(\Longleftarrow ) Suppose (p) is maximal among principal proper ideals. We want to show p is irreducible. Suppose there exists some a\in R such that a\mathrel {\bigm |} p, which is equivalent to saying (a)\subseteq (p). Then either (a)=R (which means a\in R^{\times } is a unit) or (a)=(p) (which implies a=pu for some unit u\in R^{\times }). In both cases, we have p is irreducible.

fr:title.text: Irreducible elements are prime in a PID

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Irreducible elements are prime in a PID

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be Principal Ideal Domain, let p\in R be an element of R. If p is irreducible, then p is prime.
Assume p is irreducible. Then we proved this is equivalent to (p) is maximal among principal ideals. Then (p) is prime, which implies p is prime.

fr:title.text: Nonzero prime elements of an integral domain are irreducible

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Nonzero prime elements of an integral domain are irreducible

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be an Integral domain, let p\in R be a nonzero element p\neq 0. If p is a prime element of R, then p is irreducible.

Let p\in R^{*} be a nonzero element. Assume p is prime. Then for any a,d\in R such that p\mathrel {\bigm |} ad we have \hbox {either }p\mathrel {\bigm |} a\hbox { or }p\mathrel {\bigm |} d, by definition of prime.
Now, by definition of irreducible, suppose we had some d\in R d\mathrel {\bigm |} p. We will show that either d=pu or d=u for some unit u\in R.

Since d\mathrel {\bigm |} p, this means there exists an a\in R such that p=ad. Since p is prime and p\mathrel {\bigm |} p (i.e., p\mathrel {\bigm |} ad), this means p\mathrel {\bigm |} a or p\mathrel {\bigm |} d. Then we argue by cases.

Case 1: p\mathrel {\bigm |} a. Then there exists a b\in R such that a=pb. But then p=ad=(pb)d, using distributivity and subtraction gives us (1-bd)p=0. Then bd=1 since p\neq 0. Then d is a unit, since R is an integral domain. Then p is irreducible by definition.
Case 2: p\mathrel {\bigm |} d. The argument is similar to case 1.

Let R be Commutative Ring, let p\in R and q\in R be irreducible elements of R. We say p and q are associates (or p is associated to q) if there exists some unit u\in R^{\times } such that p=uq. This is a predicate, so it's well-defined.
This is a symmetric predicate since u^{-1}\in R^{\times } so we have u^{-1}p=q, too.
It's not too hard to see it's really an Equivalence relation.
Some examples we have seen before:

fr:ol.fr:li: The integers \mathbb {Z} form a unique factorization domain.
The Gaussian integers \mathbb {Z}[i]\subseteq \mathbb {C} form a unique factorization domain.

The integers \mathbb {Z}[\sqrt {-5}] adjoined with \sqrt {-5} is not a unique factorization domain, since 6=2\dot 3=(1+\sqrt {-5})(1-\sqrt {-5}) are two possible factorizations. Hell, \mathbb {Z}[\sqrt {-5}] isn't even a Principal Ideal Domain.

fr:title.text: In a UFD, elements are irreducible iff prime

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: In a UFD, elements are irreducible iff prime
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 8.3.12

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Unique Factorization Domain, let p\in R be an element of R. Then p is prime if and only if p is irreducible.
(\Longrightarrow ) Well, since a UFD is an integral domain, this follows immediately from Nonzero prime elements of an integral domain are irreducible.
(\Longleftarrow ) Assume p is irreducible. We want to prove p is prime.

Let a,b\in R be arbitrary. Assume p\mathrel {\bigm |} ab. Then there exists some c\in R such that ab=pc. We can write the unique factorization of a as a=u\prod ^{N}_{i=1}p_{i}^{n_{i}} and the unique factorization of b as b=v\prod ^{M}_{j=1}q_{j}^{m_{j}} and the unique factorization of c as c=w\prod ^{L}_{k=1}r_{k}^{\ell _{k}}. Then p must associate with one of the irreducibles appearing in the factorization of a or {b}. We have ab=pc be uv\prod ^{N}_{i=1}p_{i}^{n_{i}}\prod ^{M}_{j=1}q_{j}^{m_{j}}=wp\prod ^{L}_{k=1}r_{k}^{\ell _{k}}, and by uniqueness of the factorizations N+M-1=L, and either p_{i}=pu'\quad \hbox {for some }i\hbox { and }u'\in R^{\times } (which means p\mathrel {\bigm |} a), or q_{j}=pu'\quad \hbox {for some }j\hbox { and }u'\in R^{\times } (which means p\mathrel {\bigm |} b). Hence p\mathrel {\bigm |} ab implies p\mathrel {\bigm |} a or p\mathrel {\bigm |} b, which implies p is a prime element of R.

fr:title.text: Uniqueness of GCD in a UFD

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Uniqueness of GCD in a UFD

fr:title.text: Principal ideal domains are unique factorization domains

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Principal ideal domains are unique factorization domains
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 8.3.14

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Principal Ideal Domain, let a\in R be a nonzero non-invertible element of R. Then there exists irreducible elements p_{1},…,p_{n}\in R such that a=p_{1}(…)p_{n}. Further, if q_{1},…,q_{m}\in R are irreducible and such that a=q_{1}(…)q_{m} then m=n and for each i=1,…,n we have q_{i}=u_{i}p_{i} where u\in R^{\times } is a unit.
In other words, R is a Unique Factorization Domain.
There are two claims: (1) there is a factorization, and (2) the factorization is unique.
Claim 1: Existence of a factorization. Assume for contradiction a\in R does not have a factorization. Then ua\in R does not have a factorization for any unit u\in R^{\times }.
We setup a set S:=\{(r)\mathrel {\triangleleft } R\mid r\hbox { does not have a factorization into irreducibles}\}. Assume for contradiction that S\neq \emptyset .

Let (a) be a maximal element of S by Zorn's lemma. We have a is not irreducible, so by definition we can write it as a=xy where x,y\notin R^{\times } are not units, so (a)\subset (x) and (a)\subset (y) are proper subsets.

But since (a) is a maximal element of a chain, (x)
otin S and (y)
otin S, so x and y have a factorization. This gives us a contradiction, which means our assumption S
eq \emptyset is wrong. We conclude S=\emptyset . Hence we've proven the factorization of elements exists.

Claim 2: Uniqueness of factorization. This may be proven in many, many ways. Assume for contradiction this is not true, so we may factorize \prod ^{n}_{i}p_{i}=\prod ^{m}_{j}q_{j}, where n is minimal (i.e., the factorization \prod ^{n}_{i}p_{i} is the smallest possible factorization with fewest possible factors).

We have n\geq 1, p=p_{1} divides p\mathrel {\bigm |}\prod q_{j}. Then there exists a j_{0} such that p\mathrel {\bigm |} q_{j_{0}} since p_{i} and q_{j} are all prime and irreducible. Then p=uq_{j_{0}} for some unit u\in R^{\times } (since p and q_{j_{0}} are irreducible). Then p_{1}\prod ^{n}_{i=2}p_{i}=(uq_{j_{0}})u^{-1}\prod ^{m}_{j\neq j_{0}}q_{j} which implies \prod ^{n}_{i=2}p_{i}=u^{-1}\prod ^{m}_{j\neq j_{0}}q_{j}. This contradicts the assumption that \prod ^{n}_{i=1}p_{i} is the minimal factorization.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Corollary 8.3.15

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The integers are a unique factorization domain.

Consider the mapping \mathbb {Z} / mn\mathbb {Z}\to \mathbb {Z} / m\mathbb {Z}\times \mathbb {Z} / n\mathbb {Z} given by x\mapsto (x\bmod {m},x\bmod {n}) is an isomorphism of additive groups. Surjectivity means a solution exists, injectivity means the solution is unique.

fr:title.text: Generalizing Chinese Remainder theorem to rings

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Generalizing Chinese Remainder theorem to rings

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We want to generalize the Chinese Remainder Theorem from integers to arbitrary Rings.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Comaximal ideals
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a unital Commutative Ring. Let A\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R and B\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R be ideals of R. We say A and B are Comaximal if their sum is the entire ring A+B=R.
We see that this is a symmetric predicate in A and B since A+B=B+A.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Abstract Chinese Remainder Theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 7.6.17

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let R be a Ring. Let I and J be comaximal two-sided ideals of R. Then
the map R/(I\cap J)\to (R/I)\times (R/J) defined by sending x\mapsto (x+I,x+J) is a Ring Isomorphism; and
furthermore if we write I\cdot J=\langle \{ab\in R\mid a\in I,b\in J\}\rangle for the two-sided ideal generated by products of elements of I and J, then I\cdot J=I\cap J.

(1) Let \varphi \colon R\to (R/I)\times (R/J) be the mapping such that \varphi (x)=(x+I,x+J) for any x\in R. Its kernel is I\cap J. Then by the first isomorphism theorem \varphi '\colon R/(I\cap J)\to (R/I)\times (R/J) is injective because it has a trivial kernel. We need to show it is surjective.

(2) Since I and J are comaximal, there exists a\in I and b\in J such that a+b=1. We want to show I\cap J\subseteq I\cdot J. Let x\in I\cap J. Then x=x\cdot 1=xa+xb, so xa\in JI and xb\in IJ, hence x\in I\cdot J.
We see I\cap J\supseteq I\cdot J obviously.

We can "define" the rational numbers \mathbb {Q} from the integers \mathbb {Z} intuitively as \mathbb {Q}=\{\frac {a}{b}\mid a,b\in \mathbb {Z},b\neq 0\}, but \frac {a}{b}=\frac {c}{d}\iff ad=bc. Furthermore, the operations on \mathbb {Q} are defined using the operations from \mathbb {Z} as \frac {a}{b}+\frac {c}{d}=\frac {ad+bc}{bd} and \frac {a}{b}\cdot \frac {c}{d}=\frac {ac}{bd}. This construction generalizes to any Integral domain.

Note: \mathbb {Q} is the "smallest" field containing \mathbb {Z} in the sense that if \varphi \colon \mathbb {Z}\hookrightarrow \mathbb {F} is an injection into a field, then there exists an extension \overline {\varphi }\colon \mathbb {Q}\hookrightarrow \mathbb {F} such that \overline {\varphi }(m)=\varphi (m) for all m\in \mathbb {Z}.

fr:title.text: Universal property of field of fractions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Universal property of field of fractions

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be any Integral domain. Then there exists a unique Field \mathbb {F} (unique up to isomorphism) and an injection i\colon R\hookrightarrow \mathbb {F} such that for all other fields \Bbbk if \varphi \colon R\hookrightarrow \Bbbk , then there exists an extension \overline {\varphi }\colon \mathbb {F}\hookrightarrow \Bbbk such that the following diagram commutes:
We call \mathbb {F} the Ring of Fractions of R.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This can be generalized to any commutative ring; Matsumara calls it the "total quotient ring" (or the "total ring of fractions").

fr:ol.fr:li: When applied to R=\mathbb {Z}, we obtain \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {Q}.
When applied to any field R=\Bbbk , we obtained \mathbb {F}=\Bbbk the field is its own field of fractions.
When applied to the polynomial ring R=\mathbb {Q}[x], we obtain \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {Q}(x) the ring of rational polynomials.
If \mathbb {F} is the field of fractions of R, then \mathbb {F}(x) is the field of fractions for R[x].

If R=\mathbb {Q}[{[x]}] is the ring of formal power series, then its field of fractions is \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {Q}(\mkern -3mu(x)\mkern -3mu) the ring of formal Laurent series \sum ^{\infty }_{k=-n}a_{k}x^{k}.

fr:title.text: Ring of polynomials is a UFD iff ring of coefficients is a UFD

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ring of polynomials is a UFD iff ring of coefficients is a UFD

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a ring. Then R is a Unique Factorization Domain if and only if R[x] is a Unique Factorization Domain.

fr:title.text: Properties of ring of polynomials over UFDs

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of ring of polynomials over UFDs

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Unique Factorization Domain. Let \mathbb {F}=\mathop {\textrm {Frac}}\nolimits (R) be the field of fractions of R. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: R[x] is a Unique Factorization Domain.
If p\in R^{*} is irreducible, then p\in R[x] is irreducible.
If f(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] is primitive and irredubile, then f(x)\in R[x] is irreducible and these are all the irreducible elements of R[x].

fr:title.text: Primitive Polynomial and Content of Polynomial

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Primitive Polynomial and Content of Polynomial

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Unique Factorization Domain, let x be a formal variable. Let f(x)\in R[x] be a nonconstant polynomial. Then we define the Content of f to be the c(f)\in R^{*} equal to the greatest common divisor of its nonzero coefficients, and the Primitive Part of f to be the polynomial f_{0}\in R[x] such that c(f_{0})=1 and f(x)=c(f)f_{0}(x). We say f is Primitive if f=f_{0}.

fr:title.text: Factorization of formal polynomials with coefficients in UFDs

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Factorization of formal polynomials with coefficients in UFDs
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 9.3.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Unique Factorization Domain, let \mathbb {F}=\mathop {\textrm {Frac}}\nolimits (R) be its field of fractions, let x be a formal variable. Let p(x)\in R[x].

If p(x) is reducible in \mathbb {F}[x], then p(x) is reducible in R[x]. More precisely: if p(x)=A(x)B(x) for some nonconstant polynomials A(x),B(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x], then there are nonzero elements r,s\in \mathbb {F} such that rA(x)=a(x) and sB(x)=b(x) both lie in R[x] and p(x)=a(x)b(x) is a factorization in R[x].

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This is called "Gauss's Lemma", but as far as I can tell, like most things named after Gauss, it's completely unmerited.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Eisenstein criteria of reducibility
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 9.4.13

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be an Integral domain, let x be a formal variable. Let f(x)\in R[x] be a (nonconstant) monic polynomial f(x)=x^{n}+a_{n-1}x^{n-1}+…+a_{1}x+a_{0}. Let P\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R be a prime ideal of R. Suppose for all j=1,…,n we have p_{j}\in R and a_{0}\notin P^{2}. Then f(x) is irreducible.

Since P is a prime ideal, R/P is an integral domain (by Ideal is prime iff quotient ring is integral domain). Then both \overline {a(x)} and \overline {b(x)} have 0 constant terms, i.e., the constant terms of both a(x) and b(x) belong to P.
But then the constant term a_{0} of f(x) may be written as the product of these two, which contradicts the hypothesis that a_{0}\notin P^{2}.
Exercise: Is p(x)=x^{5}-4x^{4}+2 irreducible in \mathbb {Q}[x] or not?

Let R be a Ring. A Left Module over R is an additive group M equipped with a function R\times M\to M denoted (r,m)\mapsto r\cdot m called scalar multiplication, such that
For any m_{1},m_{2}\in M and r\in R, we have r(m_{1}+m_{2})=(rm_{1})+(rm_{2})
For any m\in M and r_{1},r_{2}\in R we have (r_{1}+r_{2})m=(r_{1}m)+(r_{2}m)
Associativity of scalar multiplication: For any m\in M and r_{1},r_{2}\in R we have (r_{1}r_{2})m=r_{1}(r_{2}m)
If R is unital, then we call M Unital when for any m\in M we have 1\cdot m=m.
Exercise: Prove these axioms imply 0_{R}\cdot m=0_{M} for any m\in M.
Exercise: Prove or find a counter-example: a left ideal of a ring is a left module over that ring.

Let R be a Ring. A Right Module over R is an additive group M equipped with a function M\times R\to M denoted (m,r)\mapsto m\cdot r called scalar multiplication, such that
For any m_{1},m_{2}\in M and r\in R, we have (m_{1}+m_{2})r=(m_{1}r)+(m_{2}r)
For any m\in M and r_{1},r_{2}\in R we have m(r_{1}+r_{2})=(mr_{1})+(mr_{2})
Associativity of scalar multiplication: For any m\in M and r_{1},r_{2}\in R we have m(r_{1}r_{2})=(mr_{1})r_{2}
If R is unital, then we call M Unital when for any m\in M we have m\cdot 1=m.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: When R is a Commutative Ring, then a right module over R is also usually turned into a Left Module over R by defining left scalar multiplication as just the same result as right scalar multiplication, i.e., for any r\in R and m\in M we have: rm:=mr. In this case, we usually just write scalar multiplication on the left as a matter of convention. Furthermore, we will just speak of "modules over R" for commutative R.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Exercise: Prove or find a counter-example: a right ideal of a ring is a right module over that ring.

fr:title.text: Modules over fields are synonymous with vector spaces

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Modules over fields are synonymous with vector spaces

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let M be either a Left Module over \mathbb {F} or a Right Module over \mathbb {F}. Then M is a Vector Space.
Moreover, any vector space over \mathbb {F} is automatically a module over \mathbb {F}.
Consequently, we treat "vector spaces over fields" as synonymous with "modules over fields".

Let R and S be two Rings. Then an (R,S)-Bimodule is an additive group M such that
M is a Left Module over R; and
M is a Right Module over S; and
Compatibility: For all r\in R and s\in S and m\in M, we have (rm)s=r(ms).
Prove or find a counter-example: a two-sided ideal of a ring is a module over that ring.

We will adopt the convention tacitly used in textbooks: when R is a ring, we say M is an R-module to mean it is either a left module over R or a right module over R, and we will also unambiguously write scalar multiplication as if it were a left module over R.

fr:title.text: Ring of polynomials is a module

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ring of polynomials is a module

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring, let x be a formal variable. Then the ring of polynomials R[x] is a module over R.
Proof idea: We see that R[x] is closed under addition, and it's closed under scalar multiplication.

fr:title.text: Associative rings are modules over themselves

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Associative rings are modules over themselves

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be an associative Ring. Then it is a Left Module over itself, and a Right Module over itself. If R is unital, then these modules are unital.
When R is nonassociative, then it is no longer a module over itself.

Let R be a Ring. Let M be a left/right/bi- module over R. We say M is Free if there exists a basis of M, i.e., a set B\subseteq M such that
Spans the module: every element of M is a linear combination of finitely many elements of B, and
Smallest spanning set: there is no proper subset C\subset B such that any element of M can be written as a linear combination of finitely many elements of C.

Let R be an associative Ring. Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. We define the n-Dimensional Free Module to be the left/right/bi- module R^{n} consisting of n-tuples of elements of R equipped with left/right/two-sided scalar multiplication induced by multiplying tuples componentwise \lambda (x_{1},…,x_{n})=(\lambda x_{1},…, \lambda x_{n}) and (x_{1},…,x_{n})\lambda =(x_{1}\lambda ,…,x_{n}\lambda ) for any \lambda \in R and (x_{1},…,x_{n})\in R^{n}.
Moreover, when R is unital, the elements e_{i}\in R^{n} which is zero except in the i^{\text {th}} component form a basis of R^{n}. This means that R^{n} is free when R is unital.

fr:title.text: Criteria for an additive group to be a module

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criteria for an additive group to be a module

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let M be an additive Abelian group. Let R be a Ring. Then M is a module over R if and only if there exists a ring morphism R\to \mathop {\textrm {End}}\nolimits (M).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Studying R-modules amounts to studying the ring morphism R\to \mathop {\textrm {End}}\nolimits (M). How can we "fit" R "into" \mathop {\textrm {End}}\nolimits (M) is the big question.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: At this point, we have studied two algebraic gadgets (groups and rings), as well as many other gadgets in other fields.
There are common things to look for when we define a "gadget":

fr:ul.fr:li: Products of gadgets
Sub-gadgets
Quotients of gadgets
Morphisms between gadgets
Isomorphism theorems
Some attempt to classify gadgets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Ring, let M be a module. A Submodule of M is a module N such that it's a subgroup N\leq M and N is closed under scalar multiplication:

fr:ul.fr:li: If M is a left module over R, then for all r\in R and n\in N we have rn\in N
If M is a right module over R, then for all r\in R and n\in N we have nr\in N

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We will continue writing N\leq M to indicate N is a submodule of M, and N\mathrel {<} M if furthermore N is a Proper submodule of M (i.e., N\neq M).

fr:title.text: Sums of submodules are a submodule

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sums of submodules are a submodule

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Ring, let M be a module over R, let N and K be Submodules of M. Then K+N=\{k+n\in M\mid k\in K,n\in N\} is a submodule of M.
(1) K+N is closed under addition since (k+n)+(k'+n')=(k+k')+(n+n').
(2) 0\in (K+N) which means K+N is a subgroup of M.
(3) For any r\in R and (k+n)\in K + N we see r(k+n)=(rk)+(rn) and rk\in K and rn\in N which implies (rk)+(rn)\in K+N.

fr:title.text: Intersection of submodules is a submodule

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Intersection of submodules is a submodule

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Ring, let M be a module over R, let N and K be Submodules of M. Then K\cap N is a submodule of M.

fr:title.text: IM is a submodule of M

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: IM is a submodule of M

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Proof idea: It's closed under addition (since adding two finite sums of these linear combinations yields yet another finite sum of these linear combinations) and it's closed under scalar multiplication (since multiplying on the left will just change the coefficients a_{i}\in I to ra_{i}\in I, by definition of a left ideal). Hence it's a submodule.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Submodule criteria
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 10.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let R be a Ring, let M be an R-module, and let N\subseteq M be a subset of M. Then N is a submodule of M if and only if
N\neq \emptyset and
for all r\in R and x,y\in N, we have x+ry\in N.
Let R be a Ring. Let M be a module over R. Let N\leq M be a Submodule of M. Is M/N a module?
We know N\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } M is a normal subgroup of the underlying additive Abelian group of M, so the quotient group M/N is well-defined.

We need to check that scalar multiplication is well-defined r(m+N)=(rm)+N. If we change the representative of m+N to m'+N, then m-m'\in N, so there is some n\in N such that m-m'=n. Multiplying by r gives us rm-rm'=rn\in N. Then rm+N=rm'+N, which confirms scalar multiplication is well-defined.
Checking the axioms are "follow your nose"
We define the Quotient Module M/N to be the module over R equipped with the module structure we just described. Proving it satisfies the axioms is "follow your nose".

Let R be a ring, let M and N be modules over R. A Morphism from M to N is a function \varphi \colon M\to N such that
It's a morphism of the underlying Abelian groups \varphi (m_{1}+m_{2})=\varphi (m_{1})+\varphi (m_{2}) for any m_{1},m_{2}\in M; and
It preserves scalar multiplication: for any r\in R and m\in M we have \varphi (rm)=r\varphi (m). We also say that \varphi is R-Linear.
We write \mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits _{R}(M,N) for the set of all morphisms from M to N.
Exercise 1: For any m\in M, we have a function f\colon R\to M defined by f(r)=rm scalar multiplication. When (if ever) is this R-linear?
Exercise 2: For any r\in R, we have a function g\colon M\to M defined by g(m)=rm scalar multiplication. When (if ever) is this R-linear?

fr:title.text: Identity map is a module morphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity map is a module morphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Ring and let M be an R-module. Then \mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{M}\colon M\to M is a module morphism.

Let R be a ring, let M and N be modules over R. An Isomorphism from M to N is an R-linear mapping \varphi \colon M\to N such that there exists an R-linear mapping \psi \colon N\to M such that \varphi \circ \psi =\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{N} and \psi \circ \varphi =\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{M}.
We say M and N Are Isomorphic if there exists an isomorphism M\to N. In this case, we denote this by M\cong N. It forms an equivalence relation.

Let R be a Ring, let M and N be modules over R, let \varphi \colon M\to N be a morphism of modules. We define the Kernel of \varphi to be the submodule \ker (\varphi )\leq M such that for all m\in M we have m\in \ker (\varphi ) if and only if \varphi (m)=0.

Let R be a Ring, let M and N be modules over R, let \varphi \colon M\to N be a morphism of modules. We define the Image of \varphi to be the submodule \mathop {\textrm {Im}}\nolimits (\varphi ) of N such that for all n\in N we have n\in \mathop {\textrm {Im}}\nolimits (\varphi ) if and only if there exists an m\in M such that \varphi (m)=n.
Let R be a Ring, let M and N be modules over R, let \varphi \colon M\to N be a morphism of modules. Then M/\ker (\varphi )\cong \mathop {\textrm {Im}}\nolimits (\varphi ).
Let M be an R-module, let N and K be Submodules of M. Then (N+K) / K\cong N / (N\cap K).
Let M be an R-module, let N and K be Submodules of M. If N\subseteq K, then \frac {M / N}{K / N}\cong M / K.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Universal property of free modules
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 10.3.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a set, let R be a Ring. There exists an R-module F(A) called the Free Module of A such that: for any R-module M and function of sets \varphi \colon A\to M, there exists a unique R-linear map \Phi \colon F(A)\to M such that for all a\in A we have \Phi (a)=\varphi (a) for all a\in A.

Let R be a Ring. Let M be an R-module, let S\subseteq M be a nonempty subset of M. We define the Annihilator of S to be the subset \mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(S)=\{r\in R\mid \forall s\in S\ldotp rs=0\}.
If S=\{m\} is a singleton, we often just write \mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(m):=\mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(\{m\}).
When R is not a commutative ring, we speak of "left annihilator" and "right annihilator" depending on if M is a left or right module over R.
Exercise: When (if ever) is \mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(S) an ideal of R?

Let R be a Ring, let M be an R-module. We define the Annihilator of M to be the subset \mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(M) of R equal to \mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(M):=\{\lambda \in R\mid \forall m\in M\ldotp \lambda m=0\}.
Exercise: Calculate the Annihilator of \mathbb {F}[x,y]/(x^{3}+x^{2}-y^{2}) where \mathbb {F} is some field.

fr:title.text: Annihilator of Module is intersection of all annihilators of each element of the module

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Annihilator of Module is intersection of all annihilators of each element of the module

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module. Then \mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(M)=\bigcap _{m\in M}\mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(m).
Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module, let N\leq M be a submodule of M (possibly M=N). We say N is Cyclic if there exists an m\in M such that N=Rm=\{rm\mid r\in R\}.

fr:title.text: Cyclic modules are quotients of ring with annihilator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cyclic modules are quotients of ring with annihilator

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module. Then M is cyclic if and only if there exists an m\in M such that M\cong R/\mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(m).
Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module. We say M is Irreducible if any submodule N\leq M we have N=0 or N=M.
Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module. If M is cyclic, then M is cyclic.
Let m\in M be nonzero. Then we can consider the submodule Rm\leq M. It is nonzero. Hence Rm=M by definition of irreducibility.

fr:title.text: Cyclic modules are irreducible iff its annihilator is a maximal ideal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cyclic modules are irreducible iff its annihilator is a maximal ideal

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a ring, let M be a cyclic R-module. Then M is irreducible if and only if \mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(M) is a maximal ideal of R.
Let R be any ring. Then there exists an irreducible R-module.

Let R be a ring, M be an R-module, let m\in M be an element of M. We say m is Torsion if its annihilator is nonzero \mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(m)\neq 0. Specifically, the annihilator contains a non-zero-divisor nonzero element.
Let R be a ring, M be an R-module. We say M is a Torsion Module if every element of M is a Torsion element.

fr:title.text: Rationals modulo integers is a torsion module

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Rationals modulo integers is a torsion module

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The quotient \mathbb {Q} / \mathbb {Z} is a torsion \mathbb {Z}-module.
Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module. The Torsion Submodule \mathop {\textrm {Tor}}\nolimits (M) consists of all Torsion elements of M.
When R is commutative, this is actually an R-module.
When R is noncommutative, we need some additional properties imposed on R for \mathop {\textrm {Tor}}\nolimits (M) to be a right R-module.
Let R be a ring, M be an R-module. We say M is Faithful if its annihilator is the trivial ideal: \mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(M)=(0).
Let R be a ring, M be an R-module. We say M is Torsion-Free if there is no Torsion element of M.

fr:title.text: Not all torsion-free modules are free

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Not all torsion-free modules are free

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The ideal (2,x)\mathrel {\trianglelefteq }\mathbb {Z}[x] is torsion-free but not free.

fr:title.text: Endomorphisms of an Abelian Group form an Abelian Group (and sometimes a module)

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Endomorphisms of an Abelian Group form an Abelian Group (and sometimes a module)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Ring, let M and N be R-modules. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: The set of R-linear maps \mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits _{R}(M,N) forms an Abelian group.
If R is a Commutative Ring, then \mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits _{R}(M,N) forms an R-module.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Exercise: Prove there is a canonical isomorphism \mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits _{R}(R,M)\cong M. (Hint: \phi \mapsto \phi (1).)

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Schur's lemma
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Problem set 5 from Caltech Math 5B Winter 2018

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a ring, let M be a cyclic R-module. Let N be an R-module. Let I be a left ideal of R. Let us write N[I]=\{n\in N\mid \forall a\in I\ldotp an=0\}.

fr:ol.fr:li: Prove N[I] is closed under addition.
Let M\cong Rm for some nonzero m\in M. Prove \mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits _{R}(M,N)\cong N[\mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(m)] as Abelian groups.
Schur's Lemma: If M is irreducible, then \mathop {\textrm {End}}\nolimits _{R}(M) is a division ring.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Now assume further that R is commutative, but everything else remains the same (M is a cyclic R-module, etc.).

fr:ol.fr:li: Prove N[I] is a submodule of N
Prove \mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits _{R}(M,N)\cong N[\mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(m)] as R-modules.
If R is irreducible, then \mathop {\textrm {End}}\nolimits _{R}(M) is a division ring containing in its center the field F=R/\mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(M).

fr:title.text: Not everything we write down is a module

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Not everything we write down is a module

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Ring. Let M be a module over R. Using the notation from exercises on Schur's lemma, prove or find a counter-example for each of these claims:

fr:ol.fr:li: If \mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(M) is a left ideal of R, then M[\mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(M)] is an Abelian subgroup of M but not a submodule of M.
If \mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(M) is a two-sided ideal of R, then M[\mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(M)] is a submodule of M.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The moral of this exercise is that we should be thinking of modules in terms of mappings.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module, let A\subseteq M be a subset of M. Then the Submodule Generated by A is the set of all finite linear combinations RA:=\{\sum _{\text {finite}}r_{i}a_{i}\mid r_{i}\in R,a_{i}\in A\}. This is a submodule of M.

Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module, let N be a submodule of M (possibly N=M), let A\subseteq M be a subset of M. If N=RA, then we call A a Set of Generators (or Generating Set) for N, and we say N is Generated by A.
Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module, let N be a submodule of M (possibly N=M). We say N is Finitely-Generated if there is a finite subset A\subseteq M such that N=RA.

fr:title.text: Finitely-generated modules are not all free

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Finitely-generated modules are not all free

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Abelian group \mathbb {Z} / 2\mathbb {Z} is a finitely-generated module over \mathbb {Z}, but it is not a free module.

fr:title.text: Finitely-generated module with relations among generators is not free

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Finitely-generated module with relations among generators is not free

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We may want to think of a generating set as synonymous with a Basis of vector space, but this is incorrect when the generating set has relations among the generators.

For example, let \mathbb {F} be a Field, then we could look at R=\mathbb {F}[x,y] as a ring and M=\mathbb {F}[x,y]/(x^{3}+x^{2}-y^{2}) as an R-module where scalar multiplication is given by the canonical morphism and multiplication in M as a ring. Then M is finitely-generated but not free.

Let R be a ring, let M be a module. Then M is finitely-generated if and only if there exists an n\in \mathbb {N} and a surjective R-linear mapping \varphi \colon R^{n}\to M. Furthermore, if \varphi is an isomorphism, then M is free.

Proof idea: We need to check this is a well-defined term. Existence and uniqueness are obvious, but we still need to prove this is actually an R-module. So we need to prove the distributivity axioms, associativity of scalar multiplication, and the unit condition 1\cdot (m,n)=(m,n).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Why do we use \oplus instead of \times for the product module? It's tradition. (Really? Well, sort of, but a more satisfying answer requires category theory, which we have yet to introduce…).

fr:title.text: Products and Direct Sums of Infinitely many modules

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Products and Direct Sums of Infinitely many modules

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The direct sum and product of finitely many R-modules describe the same thing.

When we have an infinite family of R-modules \{M_{i}\}_{i\in \mathbb {N}}, they are different. The product \prod _{i\in \mathbb {N}}M_{i} describes all possible formal linear combinations, whereas the direct sum \bigoplus _{i\in \mathbb {N}}M_{i} describes only finite linear combinations.
This should ring a bell, reminding the reader of the Direct sum of groups and the Product of family of groups.

fr:title.text: Inclusion maps into product module are module morphisms

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inclusion maps into product module are module morphisms

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Furthermore, i_{1}(M)+i_{2}(N)=M\oplus N and i_{1}(M)\cap i_{2}(N)=(0).
Let R be a ring, let M, N, T be R-modules. Suppose M and N are submodules of T. If (1) M+N=T and (2) M\cap N=(0), then M\oplus N\cong T.
Proof idea: Step 1: define a map \varphi \colon M\times N\to T as sets, sending \varphi (m,n)=m+n.

fr:title.text: Universal Property of Direct Sums of Modules

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Universal Property of Direct Sums of Modules

fr:ol.fr:li: This is well-defined;
It is a morphism of Abelian groups;
If R is commutative, then it is R-linear;
It is a bijection.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We'll just prove one of these claims, the others left as an exercise for the reader.
Claim: \Phi is a bijection.
Conversely, for any \varphi \colon M\oplus N\to P, we need to check the restrictions \Phi (\varphi |_{M},\varphi |_{N})=\varphi . The result follows from this.

fr:title.text: Module morphisms from free module isomorphic to direct sum of copies of codomain

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Module morphisms from free module isomorphic to direct sum of copies of codomain

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We know finite-dimensional inner product spaces have orthogonal complements, but can we generalize this idea to generic modules? Let us make this question more precise:
Let R be a ring, let T be an R-module, let N\leq T be a submodule.
When does there exist an R-module M such that M\oplus N=T?
Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module. When is M free?
We have some "special cases" like M is free if and only if R^{n}\cong M, but is there something more...useful?

Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module. We define a Basis of M to be a subset B\subseteq M such that for any m\in M there exists a unique finite subset \{b_{1},…,b_{n}\}\subseteq B and unique \lambda _{1},…,\lambda _{n}\in R such that m = \lambda _{1}b_{1}+…+\lambda _{n}b_{n}.
Compare this to the same notion from intermediate linear algebra.

fr:title.text: A module is free iff it has a basis

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A module is free iff it has a basis

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module. Then M is free if and only if there exists a basis of M.
Let R be a Commutative Ring, let m,n\in \mathbb {N} be positive integers. When are the R-modules R^{n}\cong R^{m}?

If x_{j}\in I for each j=1,…,m, then we see that \begin {pmatrix}x_{1}\\ \vdots \\ x_{m}\end {pmatrix}\mapsto \begin {pmatrix}y_{1} = \sum _{j}a_{1,j}x_{j}\\ \vdots \\ y_{n}=\sum _{j}a_{n,j}x_{j}\end {pmatrix}, and we know y_{j}\in I for j=1,…,n. We get an induced map \overline {\varphi }\colon \mathbb {F}^{m}\to \mathbb {F}^{n} and an induced inverse, i.e., \overline {\varphi } is an isomorphism. Then we use the fact that \mathbb {F}^{m}\cong \mathbb {F}^{n} iff m=n. Hence the result.
Let R be an Integral domain. Let M be an R-module. We define the Rank of M to be the maximum number of R-linearly independent elements of M, denoted \mathop {\textrm {rank}}\nolimits (M).
Exercise: Let B is a basis of M. Prove or find a counter-example: \mathop {\textrm {rank}}\nolimits (M)=|B|.

fr:title.text: Does the general linear group over a ring consist of all matrices with nonzero determinant?

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Does the general linear group over a ring consist of all matrices with nonzero determinant?

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We assert \det (AB)=\det (A)\det (B) the determinant is multiplicative for square matrices over a commutative ring.
For A\in \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(R) invertible, we see that \det (AA^{-1})=\det (A)\det (A^{-1})=1 which implies \det (A)\in R^{\times }.

fr:title.text: A Matrix over unital commutative rings is invertible iff its determinant is a unit

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A Matrix over unital commutative rings is invertible iff its determinant is a unit

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a unital Commutative Ring. Let n\in \mathbb {N}. Let A\in \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(R). Then A is invertible if and only if \det (A)\in R^{\times }.

fr:title.text: Submodule complement is isomorphic to quotient module, if it exists

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Submodule complement is isomorphic to quotient module, if it exists

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module, let N\leq M be a submodule of M. Then there exists an R-module T such that N\oplus T=M if and only if T\cong M/N.
This follows from Second Isomorphism Theorem.

fr:title.text: If quotient module is free, then a complement submodule exists

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: If quotient module is free, then a complement submodule exists

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module, let N\leq M be a submodule of M. If M/N is free, then there exists an R-module T such that M\cong N\oplus T.

Look at the canonical map \pi \colon M\twoheadrightarrow M/N where \ker (\pi )\cong N. We want to find a \psi \colon M/N\to M such that \pi \circ \psi =\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{M/N}. Then the image of \psi (M/N)=T.
(1) Since M/N is free, we can always find such a \psi . To see this, let \{e_{i}\} be a basis of M/N, then \pi (\psi (e_{i}))=e_{i} for each i.
(2) T=\psi (M / N) is such a complement. We just need to check T\cap N=\emptyset , which is an exercise.

fr:title.text: When is a module the direct sum of a free module and its torsion?

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: When is a module the direct sum of a free module and its torsion?

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module. When (if ever) can we write M=F\oplus T where F is free and T is the torsion submodule?
Well, we need T=\mathop {\textrm {Tor}}\nolimits (M) such that M/T is free. But not all torsion-free modules are free.
We need R to be a Principal Ideal Domain and M to be finitely-generated, then we obtain the result.

fr:title.text: Torsion-free finitely-generated modules over PIDs are free

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Torsion-free finitely-generated modules over PIDs are free

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Principal Ideal Domain and let M to be finitely-generated R-module. If M is torsion-free, then M is free.
(1) If I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R, then I is a free module over R. Moreover, there exists an a\in I such that I=(a)=Ra\cong R.
(2) If M\leq R^{n} and n\geq 1, then M is free.

fr:title.text: Submodules of a rank n free module over a PID are free and have rank less than or equal to n

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Submodules of a rank n free module over a PID are free and have rank less than or equal to n
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 12.1.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Principal Ideal Domain, let M be an R-module. If M\leq R^{n} is free, then M is free and the rank of M is bounded as \mathop {\textrm {rank}}\nolimits (M)\leq n.
By induction on n. The base case is trivial.

The inductive case, we write R^{n}=R^{n-1}\oplus R and take F_{0}=R^{n-1}. Then M\cap F_{0}\subseteq M. Let us call this M_{0}=M\cap F_{0}. By induction M_{0} is free, finitely-generated of rank at most n-1.
If M=M_{0}, then we're done.

If M\neq M_{0}, then we have to consider some element of R which generates the rest of M. We look at I=\{\alpha \mid \alpha e_{n}+f_{0}\in M,f_{0}\in F_{0}\}, and the claim is that I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R is a nonzero ideal. This is because I=(0) iff M\subseteq F_{0}. So I\neq (0) is generated by a single nonzero element (since R is a principal ideal domain), say I=(\gamma ). Then M=M_{0}\oplus R\omega where \omega =e_{n}\gamma +f\in M.

fr:title.text: Submodules of finitely-generated modules are finitely-generated

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Submodules of finitely-generated modules are finitely-generated

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Principal Ideal Domain, let M be a finitely-generated R-module, let N\leq M be a submodule of M. Then N is finitely-generated.
Exercise: Does this work if R is just an Integral domain?
