Since M is finitely-generated, there is a surjective morphism \pi \colon R^{n}\to M. Then look at N_{0}:=\pi ^{-1}(N)\leq R^{n}, and \pi |_{N_{0}}\colon N_{0}\twoheadrightarrow N is surjective. Since R is a Principal Ideal Domain, N_{0} is free of rank less than or equal to n, and N is finitely-generated.

fr:title.text: Modules over PIDs are torsion-free iff isomorphic to a submodule of a free module

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Modules over PIDs are torsion-free iff isomorphic to a submodule of a free module

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Principal Ideal Domain, let M be a finitely-generated R-module. Then M is torsion-free if and only if R is isomorphic to a submodule of a free module.
(\Longleftarrow ) Any submodule of a free module over an integral domain is torsion-free.

(\Longrightarrow ) Assume M is torsion-free. Let S be the set of all linearly-independent subsets of M. We can check that S is nonempty (since M being torsion-free and R being an integral domain that \{m\} is linearly independent for any m\in M nonzero m\neq 0) and all ascending chains in S admit an upper bound. Then by Zorn's lemma there exists a maximal element in S. That is to say, there exists a maximal free submodule F of M.

We claim that M/F is torsion. If m+F\in M is not torsion, then the submodule Rm+F of M is free and it properly contains F. Since M is assumed to be torsion free, Rm is free and thus it suffices to check Rm\cap F=(0). But rm\in F iff r(m+F)=0. Since M is finitely-generated then M/F is finitely-generated and torsion. Then there exists some a\in R nonzero a\neq 0 such that a(M/F)=0. Equivalently aM\subseteq F. Since M is torsion-free, M is isomorphic to aM.

fr:title.text: Finite-rank modules over PIDs are direct sums of free and torsion modules

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Finite-rank modules over PIDs are direct sums of free and torsion modules

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Principal Ideal Domain, let M be a finitely-generated R-module. Then there exists a free finitely-generated R-module F and a finitely-generated torsion R-module T such that M=T\oplus F.
Let T=\mathop {\textrm {Tor}}\nolimits (M). Since R is a commutative integral domain, T is a submodule of M.

Claim: M/T is torsion-free. For any m\in M we see r(m+T)=T implies rm\in T. Since T is torsion, there exists a nonzero a\in R such that a(rm)=0. Since R is an integral domain, we deduce that m is torsion and m+T=T.

Then by Modules over PIDs are torsion-free iff isomorphic to a submodule of a free module and Submodules of a rank n free module over a PID are free and have rank less than or equal to n we deduce M/T is free of finite rank. Then If quotient module is free, then a complement submodule exists implies the result.

fr:title.text: Fundamental theorem of finitely-generated modules over PIDs

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Fundamental theorem of finitely-generated modules over PIDs

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Principal Ideal Domain, let M be a finitely-generated R-module. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: We have M\cong \bigoplus R/(p_{j}^{\alpha _{j}}) where each p_{j} are prime and \alpha _{j}\in \mathbb {N}.
We have M\cong \bigoplus R/(m_{j}) where m_{1}\mathrel {\bigm |} m_{2} and m_{2}\mathrel {\bigm |} m_{3} and ….

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: (1) The first claim, viewed as Abelian groups, holds "on the nose" (i.e., we have equality of the underlying Abelian groups).
(2) The second claim is when we want to consider if our module is cyclic, or if we want to consider the annihilator of M.

We can see the equivalence of the two claims writing m_{r}=\prod p^{\alpha _{p,r}} and if m_{i}\mathrel {\bigm |} m_{r} then m_{i}=\prod p^{\alpha _{p,i}} for \alpha _{p,i}\leq \alpha _{p,r}. The Abstract Chinese Remainder Theorem gives us R/m\cong \bigoplus _{p}R/p^{\alpha _{p}}. Then we can convert the summands from one form to the other, and reorder as needed. Also note if p_{1}\neq p_{2}, then these give us Comaximal ideals.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: p-Primary Component
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 12.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let R be a Principal Ideal Domain, let M be a finitely-generated R-module. Let p be a prime element of R. Then a p-Primary Component of M is a submodule M(p) of M such that:
M=\bigoplus _{p}M(p), and
If M=M(p), then M=\bigoplus _{i}^{m}R/p^{\alpha _{i}}.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We have two conditions: either M(p)=\{x\in M\mid p^{r}x=0,r\geq 0\}, or M[p^{r}]=\{x\in M\mid p^{r}x=0\} where p^{r}\mathrel {\bigm |}\mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(M).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This follows immediately from the Fundamental theorem of finitely-generated modules over PIDs and the fact that Abelian groups are \mathbb {Z}-modules.

fr:title.text: Canonical forms of matrices from fundamental theorem of finitely-generated modules over PIDs

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Canonical forms of matrices from fundamental theorem of finitely-generated modules over PIDs

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We should observe that if \mathbb {F} is a field, then \mathbb {F}[x] is a principal ideal domain. The idea is that if we have a linear operator L\colon M\to M where M is a finitely-dimensional vector space over \mathbb {F}, then M is a finitely-generated module over \mathbb {F}[x] where x acts on M as described by L.
Then the decomposition of M as a finitely-generated module over \mathbb {F}[x] into a direct sum of submodules gives us a decomposition of L into a block diagonal matrix.
Depending on which form of the fundamental theorem we use, we end up with two different decompositions of L into either the rational canonical form or the Jordan canonical form.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This is also kind of a convoluted application of the fundamental theorem. Marc van Leeuwen gave a simpler derivation of the rational canonical form of a matrix without this convoluted dependence on the fundamental theorem of finitely-generated modules over principal ideal domains.

fr:title.text: {F}[x]-modules are {F}-vector spaces equipped with an endomorphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: \mathbb {F}[x]-modules are \mathbb {F}-vector spaces equipped with an endomorphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field. Let M be a module over \mathbb {F}[x]. Then M is a vector space over \mathbb {F} equipped with an endomorphism \alpha \colon M\to M defined by \alpha (m)=x\cdot m for any m\in M.
This follows from the Fundamental theorem of finitely-generated modules over PIDs.
(1) We see V is a finitely-generated torsion module over \mathbb {F}[x] if and only if V is a finite-dimensional vector space over \mathbb {F}.

(2) If we have two square n\times n matrices A, B over \mathbb {F}, then they correspond to endomorphisms on an n-dimensional vector space over \mathbb {F}. These give us modules over \mathbb {F}[x] describing the action of x. Then A is similar to B if and only if the corresponding modules over \mathbb {F}[x] are isomorphic.
Let \mathbf {M} be a n\times n matrix over the reals (or some Field). We define the Characteristic Polynomial of \mathbf {M} to be the polynomial p(\lambda )=\det (\mathbf {A}-\lambda \mathbf {I}).

Why is this a good notion? Well, with the eigenstuff for a matrix \mathbf {M}v=\lambda v we have \mathbf {M}v-\lambda v=0. But this is really (\mathbf {M}-\lambda \mathbf {I})v=0. Then \mathbf {M}-\lambda \mathbf {I} is a linear operator, and we're looking for its kernel. The kernel is nontrivial if the determinant is zero, which means we want to find the values \lambda such that \det (\mathbf {M}-\lambda \mathbf {I})=0. But this is precisely the characteristic polynomial as we have defined it.

fr:title.text: Characteristic polynomial of a matrix is monic

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Characteristic polynomial of a matrix is monic

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field, let A be a matrix over \mathbb {F}. Then the characteristic polynomial c_{A}(x) of A is a monic polynomial in x.

The leading term of c_{A}(x) is given by the diagonal contribution to the determinant is (up to a factor of \pm 1), f(x)=\prod ^{n}_{j=1}(x-a_{j,j}) and all other contributions are lower-order terms. When we expand f(x) out, we see it is monic, and adding a lower-order polynomial to a monic polynomial is monic.

Let \mathbb {F} be a field. Let X\in \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(\mathbb {F}) be an n\times n matrix over \mathbb {F}. Let I_{X}=\{p\in \mathbb {F}[x]\mid p(X)=0\}, where p(X)=0 is the zero matrix, and we see I_{X} is a proper ideal of the principal ideal domain \mathbb {F}[x]. Then there exists a unique monic polynomial m_{X}(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] such that I_{X}=(m_{X}(x)). We call this m_{X}(x) the Minimal Polynomial of X.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: It's not hard to see that the minimal polynomial is the unique monic polynomial which generates the Annihilator of a module \mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits (V) in \mathbb {F}[x].

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field, let f(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] be a monic polynomial f(x)=x^{n}+a_{n-1}x^{n-1}+…+a_{1}x+a_{0}. Then the Companion Matrix of f(x) is the n\times n matrix over \mathbb {F} denoted C_{f(x)} (or C_{f}) consisting of 1 on the lower subdiagonal, the last column is (C_{f})_{n,i}=-b_{i-1}. All other components are zero, so it generically looks like: C_{f} = \begin {pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 & … & 0 & -b_{0}\\ 1 & 0 & 0 & … & 0 & -b_{1}\\ 0 & 1 & 0 & … & 0 & -b_{2}\\ \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & … & 1 & -b_{n-1}\end {pmatrix}

fr:title.text: Characteristic polynomial of a companion matrix is the monic polynomial

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Characteristic polynomial of a companion matrix is the monic polynomial

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field, let f(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] be a nonconstant monic polynomial. Then the characteristic polynomial of the companion matrix of f(x) is equal to f(x), i.e., c_{C_{f}}(x)=f(x).

We can write down \det (Ix - C_{f}) = \left |\begin {matrix}x & 0 & 0 & … & a_{0}\\ -1 & x & 0 & … & a_{1}\\ 0 & -1 & x & … & a_{2}\\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \ddots & \vdots \\ 0 & 0 & … & -1 & x + a_{n-1}\end {matrix}\right | We can add x times the last row to the previous row, and then add x times that resulting row to the previous row, and so on, and we get (since the determinant is invariant under elementary row operations), \det (Ix - C_{f}) = \left |\begin {matrix}0 & 0 & 0 & … & f(x)\\ -1 & 0 & 0 & … & *\\ 0 & -1 & 0 & … & *\\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \ddots & \vdots \\ 0 & 0 & … & -1 & *\end {matrix}\right | We see this is equal to \begin {align*}\det (Ix-C_{f})&=(-1)^{\deg (f)-1}f(x)\left |\begin {matrix}-1 & & \\ & \ddots & \\ & & -1\end {matrix}\right |\\ &=(-1)^{\deg (f)-1}f(x)\det (-I_{\deg (f)-1})\\ &=(-1)^{\deg (f)-1}f(x)(-1)^{\deg (f)-1}\\ &=f(x).\end {align*} Hence the result.

Let \mathbb {F} be a field, let X\in \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(\mathbb {F}) be an n\times n matrix, let V=\mathbb {F}^{n} be a free vector space over \mathbb {F}. We can decompose V=V_{1}\oplus …\oplus V_{m} where each V_{i} is an Invariant subspace under X and the dimension \dim (V_{1})=\deg (m_{X}(x)) is the degree of the minimal polynomial of X and \dim (V_{i})\leq \dim (V_{i+1}).

fr:title.text: Rational Canonical Form of a Matrix

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Rational Canonical Form of a Matrix

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field, let X\in \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(\mathbb {F}) be an n\times n matrix over \mathbb {F}. The Rational Canonical Form of X is the block diagonal matrix consisting of companion matrices of the invariant factors of X.
We will write \mathop {\textrm {RCF}}\nolimits (X) for the rational canonical form matrix of X.

fr:title.text: Matrices are similar iff they have the same rational canonical form

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Matrices are similar iff they have the same rational canonical form

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field, let A\in \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(\mathbb {F}) be an n\times n matrix over \mathbb {F}. Let c_{A}(x)=\det (x I_{n}-A) be the characteristic polynomial of A, and let m_{A}(x) be the minimal polynomial of A. Then the minimal polynomial of A divides the characteristic polynomial for the matrix m_{A}(x)\mathrel {\bigm |} c_{A}(x). Moreover there exists an m\in \mathbb {N} such that c_{A}(x)\mathrel {\bigm |} m_{A}(x)^{m}, where m is the number of invariant factors of X.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: An immediate consequence of this is that c_{A}(A)=0 is the zero matrix, since m_{A}(A)=0 and m_{A}(x)\mathrel {\bigm |} c_{A}(x). Usually, C_{A}(A)=0 is the result known as the Cayley-Hamilton theorem.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For this particular case, it turns out A\sim _{\mathbb {Q}}B\iff A\sim _{\mathbb {C}}B. This is called Stable Conjugacy. This is a consequence of version (1) of the fundamental theorem of modules over principal ideal domains...and why the Rational Canonical Form of a Matrix is so important. A matrix in rational canonical form over \mathbb {Q} is also in rational canonical form over \mathbb {C}, and then we use the fact Matrices are similar iff they have the same rational canonical form.

Let R=\mathbb {C}[x] (or if \mathbb {F} is any algebraically closed field, then we could also consider R=\mathbb {F}[x]). Now, we need to list all irreducible elements of R (which is why we need coefficients in an algebraically closed field: the irreducible elements all look like x-\lambda for some \lambda \in \mathbb {C}).

We have the eigenvalues \lambda _{1}, …, \lambda _{n}. The invariant factors f_{1}(x), …, f_{m}(x) of a matrix A factors completely in the sense that f_{j}(x)=\prod ^{n}_{i=1}(x-\lambda _{i})^{\alpha _{j}(\lambda _{i})} where \alpha _{j}(\lambda _{i}) is the multiplicity of eigenvalue \lambda _{i} in the invariant factor f_{j}. We see that for any i we have \alpha _{1}(\lambda _{i})\geq \alpha _{2}(\lambda _{i})\geq …\geq \alpha _{m}(\lambda _{j}) since f_{k}\mathrel {\bigm |} f_{j} for any k\geq j. This means \mathop {\textrm {JCF}}\nolimits (A)=\bigoplus ^{n}_{i}\left (\bigoplus ^{m}_{j=1}J_{\alpha _{j}(\lambda _{i})}(\lambda _{i})\right ) where J_{\alpha _{j}(\lambda )}(\lambda ) is the Jordan block of size \alpha _{j}(\lambda ) with eigenvalue \lambda .
How does this relate to the decomposition of modules? Well, each Jordan block acts on a cyclic submodule of the form \mathbb {C}[x] / (x-\lambda )^{\alpha (\lambda )}.

Let R be a unital Ring, let \lambda \in R, let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. A Jordan Block of size n with eigenvalue \lambda is an n\times n matrix which looks like \begin {pmatrix} \lambda & 1 & & & \\ & \lambda & \ddots & & \\ & & \ddots & 1 & \\ & & & \lambda & 1 \\ & & & & \lambda \end {pmatrix}. That is to say, the upper subdiagonal are all 1, the diagonal entries are all \lambda , and all other entries are zero.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This is also called an n\times n elementary Jordan matrix with eigenvalue \lambda , among other various similar terms.

fr:title.text: Criteria for diagonalizability of a matrix

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criteria for diagonalizability of a matrix

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer, let A\in \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(\mathbb {C}) be a complex n\times n matrix. The following are equivalent:

fr:ol.fr:li: The matrix A is diagonalizable.
There are n distinct eigenvalues of A.
The minimal polynomial factorizes as m_{A}(x)=\prod _{i}(x-\lambda _{i}) where each \lambda _{i} is distinct.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: If A is diagonalizable, then its Jordan Canonical Form consists of 1\times 1 Jordan blocks.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Galois theory combines everything we've studied so far in abstract algebra: we have fields which are super nice rings (relying on everything discussed in the Traditional Introduction to Rings) and we may view some fields as vector spaces over another (relying on everything discussed in the Traditional Introduction to Modules).

We can translate "roots of a polynomial" into "field extensions", and then study the symmetries of field extensions leaving the base field invariant. This relies on everything we learned in the Traditional Introduction to Groups.

In other words, Galois theory combines everything we have learned into a single application (i.e., solving polynomials over fields). Emmy Noether is responsible for this presentation of material, but Bartel L. van der Waerden usually gets credit for it since it's basically the content of Modern Algebra, Vol. I...but people don't realize that Emmy Noether is the person who wrote the outline and highlighted the importance of this structure to the presentation of material.
Before I forget, these are mostly based on my notes and the notes of Zavosh Amir-Khosravi (who used them for Caltech's Math 5C course for Spring quarter 2018).
There are plenty of good lecture notes on Galois theory nowadays. An incomplete selection which I found useful:

fr:ul.fr:li: Tom Leinster's "Galois Theory" arXiv:2408.07499 (152 pages)
Brent Everitt's "Galois Theory - a first course" arXiv:1804.04657 (94 pages)

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A Field is traditionally defined as a set F with two binary operators, addition (denoted +) and multiplication (denoted \cdot ), satisfying the field axioms:

fr:ol.fr:li: Associativity of addition: for all x,y,z\in F, (x+y)+z=x+(y+z)
Commutativity of addition: for all x,y\in F, x+y=y+x
Additive identity: there exists a 0\in F such that for all x\in F we have 0+x=x and x+0=x
Additive inverses: for each x\in F there is a unique y\in F such that x+y=0 and y+x=0; in this case, we usually denote y as (-x)
Associativity of multiplication: for all x,y,z\in F, (x\cdot y)\cdot z=x\cdot (y\cdot z)
Commutativity of multiplication: for all x,y\in F, x\cdot y=y\cdot x
Multiplicative identity: there exists a 1\in F such that for all x\in F we have 1\cdot x=x and x\cdot 1=x
Multiplicative inverses: for each x\in F which is nonzero x\neq 0 there is a unique y\in F such that x\cdot y=1 and y\cdot x=1; usually we denote y as x^{-1}
Distributivity of multiplication over addition: for all x,y,z\in F, we have x\cdot (y+z)=(x\cdot y)+(x\cdot z) and (x+y)\cdot z=(x\cdot z)+(x\cdot y)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Note that some of these are redundant.
Also note: fields are usually written in blackboard bold, and the generic field is either \mathbb {F} or \Bbbk (since the German word for field is "Körper").

Let \mathbb {F} be a field. There is a unique ring morphism \phi \colon \mathbb {Z}\to \mathbb {F} where \phi (1)=1. We define the Characteristic of \mathbb {F} to be the smallest positive integer n such that (n)=\ker (\phi ), if such an n>0 exists. Otherwise the characteristic of \mathbb {F} is 0.
We write \mathop {\textrm {char}}\nolimits (\mathbb {F}) for the characteristic of \mathbb {F}.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The \mathop {\textrm {char}}\nolimits (\mathbb {F}) is either a prime number or zero.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field. The Prime Subfield is the subfield generated by the multiplicative unit 1\in \mathbb {F}.

fr:title.text: Characteristic zero fields have rational numbers as its prime subfield

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Characteristic zero fields have rational numbers as its prime subfield

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field. If \mathop {\textrm {char}}\nolimits (\mathbb {F})=0, then the Prime Subfield of \mathbb {F} is \mathbb {Q}.

The \phi \colon \mathbb {Z}\to \mathbb {F} is injective since its kernel is trivial. The prime subfield of \mathbb {F} must contain \mathbb {Z}. Hence the prime subfield must contain the field of fractions \mathbb {Q}=\mathop {\textrm {Frac}}\nolimits (\mathbb {Z}). Hence \mathbb {Q} itself is the prime subfield.

fr:title.text: Characteristic p fields have a finite prime subfield

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Characteristic p fields have a finite prime subfield

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let p be a prime number, let \mathbb {F} be a field. If the Characteristic of \mathbb {F} is p=\mathop {\textrm {char}}\nolimits (\mathbb {F}), then the finite field \mathbb {F}_{p} is the prime subfield of \mathbb {F}.

fr:title.text: Morphisms of fields are injective or zero

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Morphisms of fields are injective or zero

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We recall that Field morphisms are injective nonzero ring morphisms or field morphisms are zero morphisms. We only really care about injective nonzero morphisms, since they describe "extensions" of fields.
Moral: nonzero field morphisms are necessarily injective.

Let \mathbb {F} be a field. A Field Extension of \mathbb {F} is a field denoted \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is a field \Bbbk containing \mathbb {F} as a subfield. We say, "\Bbbk is over \mathbb {F}" and write this as:

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This idea generalizes to rings instead of fields (and we speak of "ring extensions"). Galois theory focuses on field extensions, however.

fr:title.text: Adjoining a root to rationals is a field extension

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Adjoining a root to rationals is a field extension

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We can adjoin \mathrm {i}=\sqrt {-1} to \mathbb {Q} to obtain the Field extension \mathbb {Q}(\mathrm {i}).

More generally, if p(x)\in \mathbb {Q}[x] is a nonconstant polynomial, then we see p(x)\in \mathbb {C}[x] and so by the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra there is a root c\in \mathbb {C} such that p(c)=0. We can adjoin c to the rationals to get a field extension \mathbb {Q}(c) / \mathbb {Q}.

fr:title.text: Irreducible polynomial has a root in a field extension

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Irreducible polynomial has a root in a field extension

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field, let p(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] be a nonconstant irreducible polynomial. Then there always exists a field extension \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} such that p has a root in \Bbbk .

fr:title.text: Field extension is a vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field extension is a vector space

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be a Field extension over \mathbb {F}. Then \Bbbk is a Vector Space over \mathbb {F}.

Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be a Field extension. The Degree of \Bbbk / \mathbb {F}, denoted [\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}], is equal to \dim _{\mathbb {F}}(\Bbbk ) the dimension of \Bbbk as a vector space over \mathbb {F}.
If [\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}]<\infty , then we say \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is a Finite Extension.

fr:title.text: Generic form a finite field extension

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Generic form a finite field extension
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 13.1.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field, let p(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] be a nonconstant irreducible polynomial of degree \deg (p)=n, and let \Bbbk =\mathbb {F}[x]/(p(x)). Let \alpha \in \Bbbk be the image of x under the quotient map \pi \colon \mathbb {F}[x]\twoheadrightarrow \Bbbk , then \{1,\alpha ,…,\alpha ^{n-1}\} is a basis for \Bbbk as a vector space over \mathbb {F}. In particular, [\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}]=n.
We see \{1,\alpha ,…,\alpha ^{n-1}\} spans \Bbbk over \mathbb {F} as a vector space since it is the image of \{1,x,…,x^{n-1},…\} and that spans \mathbb {F}[x] over \mathbb {F}.

Let \beta \in \Bbbk be the image of some b(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x]. By the division algorithm, b(x)=q(x)p(x)+r(x) where 0\leq \deg (r)<n=\deg (p). Observe if \alpha is the image of x under the quotient map, then b(\alpha )=q(\alpha )\cdot 0+r(\alpha )=r(\alpha ). Since \deg (r)<n, we have b(\alpha )=c_{0}+c_{1}\alpha +…+c_{n-1}\alpha ^{n-1}, which implies b(\alpha )=\beta \in \mathop {\textrm {span}}\nolimits (1,\alpha ,…,\alpha ^{n-1}). Since \beta \in \Bbbk was arbitrary, and we showed it was a linear combination of the proposed basis, we have obtained the result.
Let's give a grocery list of example.

fr:ol.fr:li: We see \{1,\mathrm {i}\} is a \mathbb {Q}-basis for \mathbb {Q}(\mathrm {i}).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F}\subseteq \Bbbk be a subfield (usually proper, otherwise this will be boring). Let \alpha ,\beta ,\gamma ,…\in \Bbbk be nonzero elements of \Bbbk . Then the Field Generated by \alpha ,\beta ,\gamma ,… over \mathbb {F} is the field denoted \mathbb {F}(\alpha ,\beta ,\gamma ,…) is the smallest subfield of \Bbbk containing \mathbb {F} and \alpha , \beta , \gamma , ….
A Simple Field Extension is a Field extension generated by a single element \mathbb {F}(\alpha ). We call \alpha a Primitive Element.
Fact: If \mathop {\textrm {char}}\nolimits (\mathbb {F})=0, then all finite extensions of \mathbb {F} are simple.
Let n\in \mathbb {N}. We will adopt the notation \zeta _{n}=\mathop {\textrm {exp}}\nolimits (\mathrm {i} 2\pi / n) for the n^{\text {th}} root of unity.

fr:title.text: Simple field extensions are isomorphic to quotient fields with respect to principal ideals generated by irreducible polynomials

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Simple field extensions are isomorphic to quotient fields with respect to principal ideals generated by irreducible polynomials
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 13.1.6

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The choice of \alpha in this theorem is irrelevant.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We see \mathbb {F}[x]/(p(x)) is a field since p(x) is irreducible. Since e_{\alpha } is nonzero, it must be injective. Then the image of e_{\alpha } must be a subfield of \Bbbk and also contained in \mathbb {F}(\alpha ), in particular the image of e_{\alpha } must contain \alpha . Since F(\alpha ) is the minimal such field, e_{\alpha } must be surjective.

Consider p(x)=x^{4}+x^{3}+x^{2}+x+1=\frac {x^{5}-1}{x-1} By Eisenstein's criteria, it's irreducible. We see \mathbb {F}:=Q[x]/(p(x)). Let \zeta =\mathop {\textrm {exp}}\nolimits (\mathrm {i} 2\pi / 5)\in \mathbb {C}, then \mathbb {Q}(\zeta )\subseteq \mathbb {C} is a field containing a root of p.

The numbers \mathop {\textrm {exp}}\nolimits (\mathrm {i} 2\pi / n) are Roots of Unity, and adjoining a root of unity to the rationals is an example of a simple field extension. (The resulting field is called a Cyclotomic field).

Moreover, since Simple field extensions are isomorphic to quotient fields with respect to principal ideals generated by irreducible polynomials, we see \mathbb {F} and \mathbb {Q}(\zeta ) are isomorphic fields.

fr:title.text: Isomorphic field extensions which are not equal to each other

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Isomorphic field extensions which are not equal to each other

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let F_{1}=\mathbb {Q}(\sqrt [3]{2})\subseteq \mathbb {R}, F_{2}=\mathbb {Q}(\zeta _{3}\sqrt [3]{2})\subseteq \mathbb {C}. Both \sqrt [3]{2} and \zeta _{3}\sqrt [3]{2} are irreducible over \mathbb {Q}. By Simple field extensions are isomorphic to quotient fields with respect to principal ideals generated by irreducible polynomials, F_{1} and F_{2} are both isomorphic to \mathbb {Q}[x] / (x^{3}-2). In particular F_{1}\cong F_{2} even though F_{1}\neq F_{2}.

fr:title.text: Isomorphisms of fields extends to isomorphisms of simple field extensions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Isomorphisms of fields extends to isomorphisms of simple field extensions

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} and \Bbbk '/\mathbb {F}' be field extensions, and \phi \colon \mathbb {F}\to \mathbb {F}' an isomorphism. Suppose \alpha \in \Bbbk is a root of an irreducible p(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x], and \beta \in \Bbbk ' is a root of q(x)=\phi (p(x))\in \mathbb {F}'[x]. Then \phi extends to an isomorphism \widetilde {\phi }\colon \mathbb {F}(\alpha )\to \mathbb {F}(\beta ).

We want to show \mathbb {F}[x]/(p(x))\cong \mathbb {F}'[x]/(\phi (p(x))) are isomorphic. We see \phi extends to \Phi \colon \mathbb {F}[x]\to \mathbb {F}'[x] induces an isomorphism \psi \colon \mathbb {F}[x]/(p(x))\to \mathbb {F}'[x]/(q(x)). Since Simple field extensions are isomorphic to quotient fields with respect to principal ideals generated by irreducible polynomials, we have isomorphisms \phi _{1}\colon \mathbb {F}[x]/(p(x))\to \mathbb {F}(\alpha ) and \phi _{2}\colon \mathbb {F}[x]/(q(x))\to \mathbb {F}'(\beta ). Then \widetilde {\phi }=\phi _{2}\circ \psi \circ \phi _{1}^{-1}\colon \mathbb {F}(\alpha )\to \mathbb {F}'(\beta ) is an isomorphism sending \alpha to \beta , and restricts to \phi on \mathbb {F}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Algebraic Element
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 13.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be a Field extension. An element \alpha \in \Bbbk is called Algebraic Over \mathbb {F} if there is some nonzero p(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] such that p(\alpha )=0. Otherwise we say \alpha is Transcendental over \mathbb {F}.

When all elements of \Bbbk are algebraic elements over \mathbb {F}, we say the field extension \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is an Algebraic Extension. Otherwise we say \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is a Transcendental Extension.

fr:title.text: Examples of algebraic and transcendental extensions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Examples of algebraic and transcendental extensions

fr:ol.fr:li: Let \mathbb {F} be a field. Let \mathbb {F}(x) be the field of rational functions. Then x is a transcendental element of \mathbb {F}.

The field \mathbb {Q}(\pi ) generated by \pi \in \mathbb {R} over \mathbb {Q} is transcendental, because \pi is not the root of any polynomial. Therefore \mathbb {Q}(\pi ) / \mathbb {Q} is transcendental.

We see \sqrt [3]{2}\in \mathbb {Q}(\sqrt [3]{2}) is algebraic over \mathbb {Q} because it's a root of x^{3}-2. But does this means that \mathbb {Q}(\sqrt [3]{2}) / \mathbb {Q} is algebraic? We need to better understand algebraicity to answer this question.

fr:title.text: Existence and uniqueness of minimal polynomial for primitive algebraic elements

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Existence and uniqueness of minimal polynomial for primitive algebraic elements

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be a Field extension, let \alpha \in \Bbbk be algebraic over \mathbb {F}. Then there exists a unique monic irreducible polynomial m_{\alpha }(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] having \alpha as a root.

Existence: Consider the map \begin {split}\psi \colon &\mathbb {F}[x]\to \Bbbk \\ &q(x)\mapsto q(\alpha )\end {split} Let M=\ker (\psi ). Then \mathbb {F}(\alpha )=\mathop {\textrm {Im}}\nolimits (\psi )\cong \mathbb {F}[x]/M, which implies M is a maximal ideal. Since \mathbb {F}[x] is a principal ideal domain, there exists a p(x) such that M=(p(x)). There is only one way to turn p(x) into a monic polynomial, m_{\alpha }(x)=c\cdot p(x), for some c\in \mathbb {F}^{\times }. The polynomial m_{\alpha }(x) is irreducible since the ideal it generates is maximal.

Uniqueness: Let p(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] be any polynomial with \alpha as a root p(\alpha )=0. Then p(x)\in M, so p(x)=m_{\alpha }(x)q(x) for some q(x). If p(x) is irreducible, q(x) must be a constant polynomial equal to a unit. If p(x) is also monic, then q(x)=1 and therefore p(x)=m_{\alpha }(x). Hence m_{\alpha }(x) is unique.

fr:title.text: Degree of simple field extension is degree of minimal polynomial

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Degree of simple field extension is degree of minimal polynomial

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be a Field extension, let \alpha \in \Bbbk be algebraic over \mathbb {F}. Then [\mathbb {F}(\alpha ) : \mathbb {F}]=\deg (m_{\alpha }(x)).

We know e_{\alpha }\mathbb {F}[x]/(m_{\alpha }(x))\to \mathbb {F}[\alpha ] is an isomorphism. We also know the image of \{1,x,…,x^{d-1}\} under e_{\alpha } forms a \mathbb {F}-basis of \mathbb {F}[\alpha ], where d=\deg (m_{\alpha }(x)).

Let \alpha \in \Bbbk be algebraic over \mathbb {F}, the unique monic polynomial m_{\alpha }\in \mathbb {F}[x], which has \alpha as a root, is called the Minimal Polynomial of \alpha over \mathbb {F}. The degree of \alpha over \mathbb {F} is the degree of its minimal polynomial.
(We've already proved this is well-defined.)

fr:title.text: An element is algebraic iff it is the primitive element of a finite extension

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: An element is algebraic iff it is the primitive element of a finite extension

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \alpha \in \Bbbk , let \Bbbk be a field over \mathbb {F}. Then \alpha is algebraic over \mathbb {F} if and only if \mathbb {F}(\alpha ) / \mathbb {F} is a finite extension.
(\Longrightarrow ) Obvious, since \alpha being algebraic over \mathbb {F} implies [\mathbb {F}(\alpha ) : \mathbb {F}] is finite.

fr:title.text: Simple field extension is algebraic iff adjoined with algebraic element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Simple field extension is algebraic iff adjoined with algebraic element

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The simple field extension \mathbb {F}(\alpha )/\mathbb {F} is algebraic if and only if \alpha is algebraic over \mathbb {F}.
(\Longrightarrow ) If \mathbb {F}(\alpha )/\mathbb {F} is an algebraic extension, then \alpha \in \mathbb {F}(\alpha ) is obviously algebraic.

(\Longleftarrow ) Suppose \alpha is algebraic over \mathbb {F}. Since An element is algebraic iff it is the primitive element of a finite extension, we see \mathbb {F}(\alpha )/\mathbb {F} is a finite extension. Let \beta \in \mathbb {F}(\alpha ) be an arbitrary element. Then \mathbb {F}(\beta ) is a \mathbb {F}-subspace of \mathbb {F}(\alpha ), so [\mathbb {F}(\beta ) : \mathbb {F}]\leq [\mathbb {F}(\alpha ) : \mathbb {F}]<\infty . Then \beta is algebraic, and since \beta is arbitrary, this means the entire extension \mathbb {F}(\alpha )/\mathbb {F} is algebraic.
A finite extension \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is algebraic.

Assume \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is finite. Let \alpha \in \Bbbk . Since \mathbb {F}(\alpha )\subseteq \Bbbk , \dim _{\mathbb {F}}(\mathbb {F}(\alpha ))\leq \dim _{\mathbb {F}}\Bbbk <\infty and so \mathbb {F}(\alpha )/\mathbb {F} is finite. It then follows that \alpha is algebraic. Since this is true for all \alpha \in \Bbbk , \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is an algebraic extension.

fr:title.text: Degree of Field Extensions is Multiplicative

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Degree of Field Extensions is Multiplicative

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {L} / \Bbbk and \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be field extensions. Then [\mathbb {L} : \mathbb {F}]=[\mathbb {L} : \Bbbk ][\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}].

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This is also known as "the degree equation", "the tower rule", and "the tower law", since a [finite] chain of field extensions is known as a "tower of fields".

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An extension \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is Finitely Generated if \Bbbk =\mathbb {F}(\alpha _{1},…,\alpha _{n}) where \alpha _{1},…,\alpha _{n}\in \Bbbk .
(1) Finitely generated extensions are not necessarily finite extensions.
(2) This should remind the reader of finitely generated modules.

fr:title.text: A finite sequence of simple extensions is a finitely generated extension

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A finite sequence of simple extensions is a finitely generated extension

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Proof by induction on r.
Base case: r=1. The result is immediate.

Inductive case: For any r, suppose the result F_{r}=\mathbb {F}(\alpha _{1},…,\alpha _{r}). We want to prove the claim for r+1, i.e., \mathbb {F}(\alpha _{1},…,\alpha _{r})(\alpha _{r+1})=\mathbb {F}(\alpha _{1},…,\alpha _{r},\alpha _{r+1}). But this is literally the base case.

fr:title.text: An extension is finite iff it is finitely-generated by algebraic elements

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: An extension is finite iff it is finitely-generated by algebraic elements

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An extension \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is finite if and only if \Bbbk =\mathbb {F}(\alpha _{1},…,\alpha _{n}) for \alpha _{i}\in \Bbbk being algebraic over \mathbb {F} for each i.

(\Longrightarrow ) If \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is finite, then it is algebraic. This means \Bbbk has an \mathbb {F}-basis \alpha _{1},…,\alpha _{n} (where each \alpha _{i} is algebraic). We have \Bbbk =\mathop {\textrm {span}}\nolimits _{\mathbb {F}}(\alpha _{1},…,\alpha _{n})\subseteq \mathbb {F}(\alpha _{1},…,\alpha _{n})\subseteq \Bbbk hence \Bbbk =\mathbb {F}(\alpha _{1},…,\alpha _{n}).

(\Longleftarrow ) We have the finite sequence of fields F_{0}=\mathbb {F}, F_{i}=\mathbb {F}_{i-1}(\alpha _{i}) for i\geq 1. Each \alpha _{i} is algebraic over \mathbb {F}, hence it's algebraic ove \mathbb {F}_{i-1}, hence F_{i}=F_{i-1}(\alpha _{i}) is finite over F_{i-1}. Then [\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}]=[F_{r} : \mathbb {F}]=[F_{r} : F_{r-1}](…)[F_{1} : F_{0}]<\infty But each factor on the right-hand side is finite (and the finite product of finite numbers is finite). So [\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}]<\infty is finite.

fr:title.text: Algebraic elements over a field forms a field

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Algebraic elements over a field forms a field

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be a field extension. The elements \alpha \in \Bbbk which are algebraic over \mathbb {F} form a subfield of \Bbbk .
Let L be the set of all elements \alpha \in \Bbbk which are algebraic over \mathbb {F}.

Claim 1: \mathbb {F}\subseteq L. We see that for any a\in \mathbb {F} the polynomial (x-a)\in \mathbb {F}[x] has a root (namely a) which belongs to L. Hence \forall a\in \mathbb {F}\ldotp a\in L, i.e., \mathbb {F}\subseteq L.

Claim 2: L is closed under field operations. Let \alpha , \beta \in \Bbbk be algebraic over \mathbb {F}. Then \mathbb {F}(\alpha ,\beta )/\mathbb {F} is an algebraic extension (since An extension is finite iff it is finitely-generated by algebraic elements). Then \mathbb {F}(\alpha ,\beta )\subseteq L. In particular this means \alpha \pm \beta \in L and \alpha \beta \in L and when \beta \neq 0 also \alpha / \beta \in L.
Hence L is a field and a subfield of \Bbbk .

Let \overline {\mathbb {Q}}\subseteq \mathbb {C} be the subset of all numbers that are algebraic over the complex numbers. Since algebraic elements over a field forms a field, \overline {\mathbb {Q}} forms a field containing all the roots of all the polynomials with coefficients in \mathbb {Q}. In particular, all finite extensions of \mathbb {Q} are subfields of \overline {\mathbb {Q}}, and \overline {\mathbb {Q}} is of infinite degree over \mathbb {Q}. Algebraic number theory is (to a large extent) the study of the extension \overline {\mathbb {Q}} / \mathbb {Q}.

fr:title.text: How do different field extensions interact?

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: How do different field extensions interact?

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We now have a basic understanding of algebraic extensions \Bbbk / \mathbb {F}. The next thing we want to investigate is how different algebraic extensions interact. One possibility is an extension of an extension, something like \mathbb {L} / \Bbbk and \Bbbk / \mathbb {F}.
Another possible situation is an extension with two subextensions, something like:

fr:title.text: Algebraic elements over an algebraic extension are algebraic over the base field

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Algebraic elements over an algebraic extension are algebraic over the base field

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F}\subseteq \Bbbk \subseteq \mathbb {L} be fields. Suppose \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is an algebraic extension. If \alpha \in \mathbb {L} is algebraic over \Bbbk , then \alpha is algebraic over \mathbb {F}.

Let m_{\alpha }(x)=x^{n}+c_{n-1}x^{n-1}+…+c_{1}x+c_{0} be the minimal polynomial of \alpha over \Bbbk . Since \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is algebraic, the coefficients c_{i} are algebraic over \mathbb {F}, and so \mathbb {F}'=\mathbb {F}(c_{0},…,c_{n-1}) is a finite extension of \Bbbk (since finitely-generated extensions with algebraic primitives is an algebraic extension).

Since m_{\alpha }(x) is irreducible over \Bbbk and \mathbb {F}'\subseteq \Bbbk , it's also irreducible over \mathbb {F}'. Then \mathbb {F}'(\alpha )\cong \mathbb {F}'[x]/(m_{\alpha }(x)) and [\mathbb {F}'(\alpha ) : \mathbb {F}']=n. Since degree of fields is multiplicative, we see [\mathbb {F}'(\alpha ) : \mathbb {F}]=[\mathbb {F}'(\alpha ) : \mathbb {F}'][\mathbb {F}' : \mathbb {F}]<\infty , so \mathbb {F}'(\alpha )/\mathbb {F} is a finite extension, hence it's an algebraic extension. In particular, \alpha is algebraic over \mathbb {F}.
If \mathbb {L} / \Bbbk is an algebraic extension, and if \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is an algebraic extension, then \mathbb {L} / \mathbb {F} is an algebraic extension.

Since \mathbb {L} / \Bbbk is algegbra, any \alpha \in \mathbb {L} is algebraic over \Bbbk . Then \alpha is algebraic over \mathbb {F} since elements of \mathbb {L} which are algebraic over \Bbbk are also algebraic over \mathbb {F}.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: I've also seen this described as the "amalgam" of \Bbbk _{1} and \Bbbk _{2}, but I don't think this is terribly common terminology.

fr:title.text: Composite Field of Algebraic Extensions is an Algebraic Extension

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Composite Field of Algebraic Extensions is an Algebraic Extension

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Bbbk _{1}/\mathbb {F} and \Bbbk _{2}/\mathbb {F} be field extensions (possibly of infinite degree) contained within a larger field \mathbb {L}. Let S=\{\alpha _{i}\}_{i\in I} and T=\{\beta _{j}\}_{j\in J} be \mathbb {F}-bases for \Bbbk _{1} and \Bbbk _{2}, respectively. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: R=\mathop {\textrm {span}}\nolimits _{\mathbb {F}}\{\alpha _{i}\beta _{j}\}_{i\in I,j\in J} is a subring of \mathbb {L}

If further both \Bbbk _{1}/\mathbb {F} and \Bbbk _{2}/\mathbb {F} are algebraic extensions, then \Bbbk _{1}\Bbbk _{2}=\mathop {\textrm {span}}\nolimits _{\mathbb {F}}\{\alpha _{i}\beta _{j}\}_{i\in I,j\in J}.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: (1) We see R contains 0, 1, and is closed under addition. We will show it is closed under multiplication (which will prove R is a subring of \mathbb {L}).
(2) We have R\subseteq \Bbbk _{1}\Bbbk _{2} since R is a linear combination of \alpha _{i}\beta _{j}.
If R is a field, then \Bbbk _{1}\Bbbk _{2}\subseteq R which will prove the claim. So we will now prove R is a field.

Claim 1: Every element of R is algebraic over \mathbb {F}. Since \Bbbk _{1}/\mathbb {F} and \Bbbk _{2}/\mathbb {F} are algebraic extensions, \alpha _{i} and \beta _{j} are algebraic over \mathbb {F}. Then we know so are \alpha _{i}\beta _{j} and their \mathbb {F}-linear combinations \sum _{i,j}c_{i,j}\alpha _{i}\beta _{j} for c_{i,j}\in \mathbb {F}. Hence every element of R is algebraic over \mathbb {F}.

Claim 2: R is a field. Let \gamma \in R be nonzero. Since \gamma is algebraic over \mathbb {F}, it follows that \mathbb {F}(\gamma ) is the image of \mathbb {F}[x]\to \mathbb {L} sending f(x)\mapsto f(\gamma ). Since p(\gamma )\in R for any p(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x], we have F(\gamma )\subseteq R. Since F(\gamma ) is a field, we see \gamma ^{-1}\in R. This, taken together with claim 1, shows that R is a field. Hence R=\Bbbk _{1}\Bbbk _{2}.

fr:title.text: Composite Field of Simple Extensions of Rational Numbers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Composite Field of Simple Extensions of Rational Numbers

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Consider the two simple extensions \mathbb {Q}(\sqrt {5})/\mathbb {Q} and \mathbb {Q}(\sqrt [7]{2})/\mathbb {Q}. Then their composite field is an algebraic extension. We can draw a diagram of the field extensions with edges labeled by the degrees of the extensions:

We see \sqrt [7]{2} is a root of x^{7}-2 which is irreducible over \mathbb {Q}. We also see that the degree [\mathbb {Q}(\sqrt {5},\sqrt [7]{2}) : \mathbb {Q}(\sqrt {5})]=7, which is the degree of the minimal polynomial of \sqrt [7]{2} over \mathbb {Q}(\sqrt {5}). Then x^{7}-2 must be this minimal polynomial. In particular, x^{7}-2 is irreducible over \mathbb {Q}(\sqrt {5}).
(This is an obligatory topic of discussion with field extensions, the uninterested reader may skip it entirely if they wish to deprive themselves of all the fun of planar geometry.)

There have been a number of famous geometry problems dating back to the ancient Greeks which we can settle using field extensions, problems like:
Squaring the circle: Given a circle, can we construct a square with the same area?
Doubling the cube: given a cube with volume V, can we construct a cube with twice the volume (i.e., with volume V) using straightedge and compass along?
Trisecting an angle: Given an angle \theta , can we trisect it to produce an angle \alpha =\theta / 3? All three of these problems are, alas, impossible. And we can prove it!

fr:title.text: Allowed constructions with straightedge and compass

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Allowed constructions with straightedge and compass

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
With a straightedge and compass, we may only allow the first three of Euclid's postulates, i.e.:
draw a straightline (possibly passing through two given points), and
draw a circle. It follows that the only points we may construct with straightedge and compass along are:
The intersection of two lines;
The intersection of two circles; and
The intersection of a line and a circle.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We stress that a "straightedge" is an "unmarked ruler" which cannot measure lengths. If we allow the user to write "markings" on the straightedge (i.e., work with a ruler), then the allowed constructions are known as Neusis constructions. We will not discuss them any further here.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let S be a set of points. A point P is called Directly Constructible from S if it's the marked point obtained by any of the Allowed constructions with straightedge and compass.
Let S be a set of points. A length \ell is Constructible from S if there are two Constructible points P\in S and Q\in S such that \ell is the distance between P and Q.

fr:title.text: Identify Cartesian Plane with Set of Points

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identify Cartesian Plane with Set of Points

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We can now use algebraic geometry (a tool unavailable to the Ancient Greeks) to answer the questions posed to us. We take the Cartesian plane \mathbb {R}^{2} as the set of points, identifying each point with their coordinates (x,y).

This is done by starting with the affine real plane \mathbb {A}^{2}, picking some point O as the origin, and picking some point P\in \mathbb {A}^{2} as having coordinates (1,0). We can construct a line passing through OP as the x-axis, and then we can construct an orthogonal line passing through O as the y-axis.
A length \ell is constructible from S if and only if the point (0,\ell ) is constructible.
(\Longleftarrow ) If (0,\ell ) is constructible, its distance from (0,0) is \ell , so \ell is constructible.

(\Longrightarrow ) Assume \ell is a constructible length. Then there exists points P\in S and Q\in S which has length \ell . We will prove (0,\ell ) is constructible. There are three possible cases: (1) PQ does not pass through O, (2) O is either P or Q, (3) P, Q, O are distinct points lying on the same line.

Case 1: Suppose PQ does not pass through O. Draw the line parallel to OP passing through Q, and draw the line parallel to PQ passing through O. Let R be the intersection of these two lines. Then we have a parallelogram OPQR, and OR has the same length as PQ. Draw a circle centered at O passing through R, and then we see the circle intersects the y-axis at the point (0,\ell ).
Case 2: Suppose O is either P or Q. Then drawing a circle at O passing through the other point will intersect the y-axis as (0,\ell ).

Case 3: Suppose O, P, Q are three distinct points lying on the same line L. Draw a line L_{2} perpendicular to L passing through P. Draw a circle C(P,Q) centered at P passing through Q. Let Q'\in L_{2}\cap C(P,Q) be the intersection of the perpendicular line at P with the circle we just constructed. We can draw a line L_{1} which is perpendicular to L passing through O, which is parallel to L_{2}. We draw a line parallel to L passing through Q' which intersects L_{1} at P'. Draw a circle centered at O passing through P'. Since the length of OP' is the same as the length of PQ' (which is the same as the length of PQ, i.e., it's the same as \ell ), drawing a circle at O passing through P' will intersect the y-axis at (0,\ell ), as desired.

fr:title.text: Points with coordinates in a field have intersecting lines at points with coordinates in a field

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Points with coordinates in a field have intersecting lines at points with coordinates in a field

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let S be a set of points whose coordinates lie in a field \mathbb {F}\subseteq \mathbb {R}. If P is directly constructed from S by intersecting two lines, then P will also have coordinates in \mathbb {F}.

Suppose we have two points (x_{0},y_{0}) and (x_{1},y_{1}) which are given. The line passing through these points have the form Ax+By+C=0, where A=y-y_{0},\quad B=x-x_{0},\quad C=x_{0}y_{1}-x_{1}y_{0}. We see the coefficients are polynomials in the coordinates of the given points.

The intersection of two lines Ax+By+C=0, and A'x+B'y+C'=0, is nonempty if and only if AB'-A'B\neq 0, in which case the intersection point has coordinates, x_{i}=\frac {BC-B'C'}{AB'-A'B},\quad y_{i}=\frac {A'C'-AC}{AB'-A'B}. The coordinates of the intersection point are rational functions in the coefficients for equations of the given lines.

fr:title.text: Coordinates of intersection of a circle and a line lie in a quadratic extension

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Coordinates of intersection of a circle and a line lie in a quadratic extension

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let S be a set of points in the plane with coordinates in the field \mathbb {F}\subseteq \mathbb {R}. Let O,P,P_{1},P_{2}\in S. Then the coordinates for the point constructed from intersecting the circle C(O,P) with the line P_{1}P_{2} lies in a quadratic extension of \mathbb {F}.

We see that two points with coordinates (x_{0},y_{0}) and (x_{1},y_{1}) has a line segment connecting them with length \sqrt {(x_{1}-x_{0})^{2}+(y_{1}-y_{0})^{2}}. Using a compass, we can draw a circle with a center at a given point (a,b) that passes through another point (x_{0},y_{0}). The equation describing the coordinates for points on the circle is (x-x_{0})^{2}+(y-y_{0})^{2}=(x_{0}-a)^{2}+(y_{0}-b)^{2}. Observe the coefficients of this equation are again polynomials in a, b, x_{0}, y_{0}.

Suppose we have a line and a circle given by equations Ax+By+C=0, and (x-x_{0})^{2}+(y-y_{0})^{2}=r^{2}. To find the coordinates of the intersection point (x_{i},y_{i}) we will have to solve a quadratic equation. The formula for x_{i} will look like ax_{i}^{2}+bx_{i}+c=0 where a, b, c are quantities which may be expressed as polynomials in A, B, C, x_{0}, and y_{0}. We stipulate by hypothesis these quantities like in the field \mathbb {F}. The quadratic formula x_{\pm }=\frac {-b\pm \sqrt {\Delta }}{2a} where \Delta =b^{2}-4ac will then imply that x_{i} lies in a quadratic extension of \mathbb {F}, namely \mathbb {F}(\sqrt {\Delta }). Since y_{i} is a rational function of x_{i}, it follows that y_{i}\in \mathbb {F}(\sqrt {\Delta }). Hence the result.

fr:title.text: A point whose coordinates like in a quadratic extension of the field is directly constructible

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A point whose coordinates like in a quadratic extension of the field is directly constructible

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let S be a set of points in the plane. Suppose the points in S have coordinates in the field \mathbb {F}\subseteq \mathbb {R}. If a point P has coordinates lying in a quadratic field extension of \mathbb {F}, then P is directly constructible from S.

Suffices to prove the intersection of two circles have coordinates in a quadratic extension of \mathbb {F} (since we have shown the intersection of two lines lie in \mathbb {F} and the intersection of a line and a circle lie in a quadratic extension of \mathbb {F}).

If we have two circles whose points satisfy the equation (x-x_{0})^{2}+(y-y_{0})^{2}=r_{0}^{2}, or (x-x_{0})^{2}+(y-y_{0})^{2}=r_{1}^{2}. If we expand and subtract one equation from another, we obtain the equation where the quadratic terms cancel out; it has the form Ax+By+C=0, where \begin {align*}A&=2x(x_{1}-x_{0})\\ B&=2y(y_{1}-y_{0})\\ C&=x_{0}^{2}-x_{1}^{2}+y_{0}^{2}-y_{1}^{2}-r_{0}^{2}+r_{1}^{2}.\end {align*} Then the intersecting the two circles is the same as intersecting either of them with the line above. Note the coefficients A, B, C are again polynomials in the coordinates x_{0}, y_{0}, x_{1}, y_{1}, and the lengths r_{0}, r_{1}.
Hence the result follows immediately.

Let S be a set of points on the plane containing the origin and two points P, Q such that their length |PQ|=1. Let \mathbb {F} be the field generated over \mathbb {Q} by the coordinates of the points of S. A length \ell is constructible from S if and only if there exists a finite sequence \mathbb {F}=F_{0}\subset F_{1}\subset …\subset F_{n}, where each F_{i} is a quadratic extension of F_{i-1}, and \ell \in F_{n}.

(\Longrightarrow ) Since a constructible length is obtained by finitely many constructible points, and each directly constructible point gives us a quadratic field extension, the forward proof is obvious.

(\Longleftarrow ) Suffices to show \sqrt {\ell } is constructible, but this is the well-known construction using the "geometric mean theorem". Given a length \ell , we draw a line PQ passing through P and {Q} and find the intersection P' of the circle centered at P of length \ell with the line PQ such that |P'Q|=\ell +1.

Now, we find the midpoint between P' and Q and call this M (for "midpoint"). We draw a circle C(M,Q) centered at M passing through Q (and P'). We draw a perpendicular line with PQ passing through P which intersects C(M,Q) at Q'. Then the length of |PQ'|=\sqrt {\ell } by the well-known geometric mean theorem. Hence the result.

fr:title.text: Constructible points live in field extensions of degree 2^{k}

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Constructible points live in field extensions of degree 2^{k}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let S be a set of points in the plane containing the origin and points P,Q\in S whose line segment connecting them has unit length |PQ|=1. Let \mathbb {F} be the field generated over \mathbb {Q} by the coordinates of the points in S. If \ell \in \mathbb {R} is constructible, then it is algebraic over \mathbb {F} of degree 2^{k} for some k\in \mathbb {N}_{0}.

We have by the criteria of constructible lengths [F_{n} : F_{0}]=2^{n}. If \Bbbk =\mathbb {F}(\ell ), then \ell has degree [\Bbbk : \mathbb {Q}] which divides [F_{n} : \mathbb {F}]=2^{n} and so must be 2^{k} for some k\in \mathbb {N}_{0}.

fr:title.text: It is impossible to square the circle, double the cube, or trisect an angle

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: It is impossible to square the circle, double the cube, or trisect an angle

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: It is impossible using only the allowed constructions with straightedge and compass to square the circle, double the cube, or trisect an angle.

Claim 1: It is impossible to square the circle. We could do this if \sqrt {\pi } were a constructible length. But that would mean \sqrt {\pi } is algebraic over \mathbb {Q}, which it isn't. So \sqrt {\pi } is not a constructible length, which means we cannot square the unit circle.

Claim 2: It is impossible to double the cube. Suppose we had a unit cube. Then we will want to construct a cube whose edges are length \ell such that \ell ^{3}=2. This requires \ell =\sqrt [3]{2} which has degree 3 over \mathbb {Q} which is impossible to construct.

Claim 3: It is impossible to trisect an angle. To construct an angle \theta is equivalent to give a point with coordinates (\cos (\theta ),\sin (\theta )). We know the triple angle formula \cos (3\theta )=4\cos ^{3}(\theta )-3\cos (\theta ). Let \theta =20^{\circ }. Then \ell =2\cos (\theta ) satisfies \frac {1}{2}=4(\ell / 2)^{3}-3\ell / 2\iff \ell ^{3}-3\ell -1=0. This line making angle 3\theta =60^{\circ } with the x-axis passes through the point (1,\sqrt {3}). In particular, 60^{\circ } is a constructible angle. But the polynomial x^{3}-3x-1 is irreducible over \mathbb {Q}, so \ell has degree 3 over \mathbb {Q} and cannot be constructible.

fr:title.text: Can we do Physics with constructible numbers?

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Can we do Physics with constructible numbers?

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Isaac Newton's Principia Mathematica used (ostensibly) Euclidean geometry alone to do physics.
Does this actually work? Can we do physics (at least, classical mechanics with gravity and other simple forces) with constructible numbers alone? Or did Newton "cheat" somewhere?
Newton also did a lot of fluid mechanics in book II of his Principia, can we describe fluid mechanics using constructible numbers alone?
Can we do calculus with constructible numbers alone? Perhaps this might be easier to answer.

The interested reader may consult Jacques Fleuriot A combination of geometry theorem proving and nonstandard analysis with application to Newton's Principia and Lars Werne's Mechanising Newtonian Mechanics in Isabelle for formalizations of Newton's Principia in the Isabelle proof assistant.

fr:title.text: For any polynomial there exists a field over which it splits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: For any polynomial there exists a field over which it splits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field, let f(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] be a polynomial. If n=\deg (f), then there exists a field extension \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} of degree at most n!such that f(x) splits completely over \Bbbk , i.e., f(x) factors into linear factors in \Bbbk [x].
Proof by induction on n=\deg (f).
Base case: n=1, so f(x)=x-\alpha . Then \alpha \in \mathbb {F}, so \alpha \in \Bbbk .

Inductive case: Suppose this is true for any polynomial of degree strictly less than n. Let f_{1}(x) be an irreducible factor of f(x), we suppose \deg (f)=n. Let F_{1}=\mathbb {F}[x]/(f_{1}(x))\cong \mathbb {F}(\alpha ) for a root \alpha of f_{1} (which is also a root of f(x)).

But then f(x)=(x-\alpha )g(x) for some polynomial g(x) with \deg (g)<\deg (f). Then by the inductive hypothesis, there exists an extension \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} over which g(x) splits completely with [\Bbbk : F_{1}]\leq \deg (g)!=(n-1)! Then [\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}]\leq n! and f splits completely over \Bbbk .

fr:title.text: Splitting field for x^{3}-2 over the rationals

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Splitting field for x^{3}-2 over the rationals

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Consider the polynomial f(x)=x^{3}-2 over \mathbb {Q}. We see F_{1}=\mathbb {Q}[x]/(f(x)) with \mathbb {Q}(\sqrt [3]{2}) because we can factorize f(x)=x^{3}-2=(x-\sqrt [3]{2})(x^{2}+\sqrt [3]{2}x+\sqrt [3]{4}). Then F_{2}=\mathbb {Q}(\sqrt [3]{2})[x]/(x^{2}+\sqrt [3]{2}x+\sqrt [3]{4}) has degree 3\cdot 2=6 over \mathbb {Q} and may be identified with \mathbb {Q}(\sqrt [3]{2},\zeta _{3}\sqrt [3]{2})=\mathbb {Q}(\sqrt [3]{2},\zeta _{3})=\mathbb {Q}(\sqrt [3]{2},\sqrt {-3})\subseteq \mathbb {C}, where \zeta _{3}=\mathop {\textrm {exp}}\nolimits (\mathrm {i} 2\pi / 3)=(-1+\sqrt {-3})/2 and x^{3}-2=(x-\sqrt [3]{2})(x-\zeta _{3}\sqrt [3]{2})(x-\zeta _{3}^{2}\sqrt [3]{2}).

fr:title.text: Splitting field for x^{3}-2 over the {F}_{7}

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Splitting field for x^{3}-2 over the \mathbb {F}_{7}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Consider the same polynomial as before but over a different field: f(x)=x^{3}-2 over \mathbb {F}_{7}. We see for any c\in \mathbb {F}_{7} that c^{3}\equiv \pm 1\pmod {7}, so f(x) has no root in \mathbb {F}_{7}. Hence f(x) is irreducible.

Let \Bbbk =\mathbb {F}_{7}[x]/(f(x)) which we write as \mathbb {F}_{7}(\alpha ) for \alpha ^{3}=2. We see \{2,4,1\}\subseteq \mathbb {F}_{7}^{\times } are third roots of unity, so f(2\alpha )=f(4\alpha )=1. Then x^{3}-2=(x-\alpha )(x-2\alpha )(x-4\alpha )\in \Bbbk [x], so that x^{3}-2 factors completely over an extension of \mathbb {F}_{7} of degree 3.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This is an example where f(x) splits completely over an extension of degree strictly smaller than \deg (f)!.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let f(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] be a polynomial. A Splitting Field of f(x) over \mathbb {F} is an extension \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} such that
f(x) factors completely over \Bbbk ; and
f(x) does not factor completely over a proper subfield of \Bbbk .
Existence: Every polynomial has a splitting field.
Uniqueness: this follows from the second condition (\Bbbk being the smallest such field extension).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This is technically not well-defined, because the second condition only specifies the splitting field up to isomorphism.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Exercise: The Hermite polynomials are defined recursively as H_{0}(x)=1, H_{1}(x)=x, and H_{n+1}(x)=xH_{n}(x)-nH_{n-1}(x) for all n>1. What are the splitting fields for the Hermite polynomials H_{n}(x) for 1<x<5 over \mathbb {Q}? Over \mathbb {F}_{p}?

fr:title.text: Every polynomial has a splitting field

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Every polynomial has a splitting field

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] be a polynomial over \mathbb {F}. Then there exists a splitting field \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} for f(x).

We see there exists a finite extension \mathbb {L} / \mathbb {F} in which f(x) factors completely. Let \alpha _{1}, …, \alpha _{n}\in \mathbb {L} be the roots of f(x). If \Bbbk \subseteq \mathbb {L} is a subfield of \mathbb {L} containing \mathbb {F}, then f(x) splits over \Bbbk if and only if \Bbbk contains all the roots \alpha _{i}\in \Bbbk for i=1,…,n. The field \mathbb {F}(\alpha _{1},…,\alpha _{n}) is the minimal such field with respect to this property, hence it is a splitting field of f(x).

fr:title.text: Field isomorphisms extends to splitting fields

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field isomorphisms extends to splitting fields
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 13.4.27

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f(x)=a_{n}x^{n}+…+a_{1}x+a_{0}\in \mathbb {F}[x] be a polynomial, let \varphi \colon \mathbb {F}\to \mathbb {F}' be a field isomorphism, and g(x)\in \mathbb {F}'[x] be a polynomial obtained by applying \varphi to the coefficients of f(x). If \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is a splitting field of f(x), and \Bbbk '/\mathbb {F}' is a splitting field of g(x), then \varphi extends to an isomorphism \varphi '\colon \Bbbk \to \Bbbk '.
Proof by induction on \deg (f).

Base case: \deg (f)=1, then f(x)=x-\alpha for some \alpha \in \mathbb {F} and g(x)=x-\varphi (\alpha ). Then \mathbb {F} is the splitting field of f(x) and \mathbb {F}' the splitting field of g(x), and \varphi is an isomorphism of the two trivially extending itself.
Inductive case: Suppose the result holds for polynomials of degree strictly less than n (where n=\deg (f)).
Let \alpha _{1}\in \Bbbk be a root of f(x) and f_{1}(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] is an irreducible factor of f(x) such that f_{1}(\alpha )=0.

Set F_{1}=\mathbb {F}(\alpha _{1}). Let g_{1}(x) be the polynomial obtained from f_{1}(x) by applying \varphi to the coefficients. Then g_{1}(x) is irreducible over \mathbb {F}' since f_{1}(x) is irreducible over \mathbb {F}. Let \beta _{1}\in \Bbbk ' be a root of g_{1}(x) and set F'_{1}=\mathbb {F}'(\beta ). Isomorphisms of fields extends to isomorphisms of simple field extensions implies the isomorphism \varphi \colon \mathbb {F}\to \mathbb {F}' extends to an isomorphism \varphi _{1}\colon F_{1}\to F'_{1}. Writing f(x)=(x-\alpha )f_{0}(x) and g(x)=(x-\beta )g_{0}(x), we have g_{0}\in F'_{1}[x] is obtained by applying \varphi _{1} to the coefficients of f_{0}(x)\in F_{1}[x].
By the inductive hypothesis, the field \Bbbk is a splitting field for f_{0}(x) over \mathbb {F}_{1}.
Similarly, \Bbbk ' is a splitting field for g_{0}(x) over F'_{1}.

Since \deg (f_{0})=\deg (g_{0})=n-1<n, the inductive hypothesis ensures the existence of an isomorphism \varphi '\colon \Bbbk \to \Bbbk ' extending \varphi _{1}\colon F_{1}\to F'_{1}, which itself extends \varphi \colon \mathbb {F}\to \mathbb {F}'. The result follows immediately.

fr:title.text: Splitting field is unique up to isomorphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Splitting field is unique up to isomorphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} and \Bbbk '/\mathbb {F} be two splitting fields for f(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x]. Then there exists an \mathbb {F}-linear isomorphism \Bbbk \to \Bbbk '.

This follows from \mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{\mathbb {F}}\colon \mathbb {F}\to \mathbb {F} being an \mathbb {F}-linear isomorphism, then extending this isomorphism to the splitting fields yields an isomorphism. Hence the result.

Let \mathbb {F} be a field. An algebraic extension \mathbb {L} / \mathbb {F} is called an Algebraic Closure of \mathbb {F} if every polynomial f(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] splits completely over \mathbb {L}.
Notation: We typically denote the algebraic closure of \mathbb {F} with an overline \overline {\mathbb {F}}.
Existence: To prove this is a well-defined notion, we need to prove the existence of the algebraic closure of \mathbb {F}. We defer this until later.

(1) Steinitz proved the existence of the algebraic closure of a field, and that it is unique up to isomorphism, in Algebraische Theorie der Körper (1910) which essentially invented Field Theory from scratch.

(2) Without the axiom of choice, the algebraic closure may not even exist. See, e.g., Banaschewski's Algebraic Closure without Choice for a proof of its existence and uniqueness requiring "only" the Boolean Ultrafilter Theorem (which seems to be equivalent to the axiom of countable choice).
A field \Bbbk is called Algebraically Closed if every polynomial f(x)\in \Bbbk [x] splits completely over \Bbbk .
Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be an Algebraic Closure of \mathbb {F}. Then \Bbbk is Algebraically Closed Field.

Let f(x)\in \Bbbk [x] and suppose \alpha is a root of f in \Bbbk (\alpha ). Then \alpha is algebraic over \Bbbk , and \Bbbk is algebraic over \mathbb {F}, hence \alpha is algebraic over \mathbb {F}. Therefore there exists a polynomial g(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] such that g(\alpha )=0. As \Bbbk is an algebraic closure of \mathbb {F}, g(x) splits completely over \Bbbk , and so \alpha \in \Bbbk . Then all roots of f(x) belongs to \Bbbk , and so f(x) splits over \Bbbk .

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Existence of Algebraic Closures
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 13.4.30

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field. Then there exists an algebraically closed field \mathbb {L} containing \mathbb {F}.

Let \mathbb {L} be a field such that
\mathbb {F}\subseteq \mathbb {L}, and
|\mathbb {L}| > \max (|\mathbb {F}|,\aleph _{0})=:\mathcal {N} (to ensure \mathbb {L} is a set, not a proper class). Then we can turn this into a lattice with ordering given by inclusion. Then by Zorn's lemma, there exists a maximal element L_{0} which we will prove is the algebraic closure of \mathbb {F}.

Proof by contradiction: Assume for contradiction L_{0} is not an algebraic closure of \mathbb {F}. Then there exists a nonconstant polynomial f(x)\in L_{0}[x] which has no root in L_{0}. Then there exists an algebraic extension W of L_{0} which has a root of f(x) (say, the splitting field of f(x) over L_{0}). Since W is an algebraic extension of L_{0}, we have |L_{0}|\leq |W|\leq \mathcal {N}, hence |S\setminus L_{0}|=|S|>|W\setminus L_{0}|. So there exists an injection i\colon W\to S such that i(x)=x for all x\in L_{0}. If we induce by i an algebraic structure from W onto i(W) we obtain a new maximal element of the lattice which is greater than L_{0}, giving us our contradiction. Hence L_{0} must be an algebraic closure of \mathbb {F}.

(1) Jelonek proved this in 1993, which cleaned up a more sloppy version of the same proof by Artin. Lang's Algebra (Theorem V.2.6 and its Corollary) follows Artin's proof, as well, but carefully patches it. In fact, it seems Lang's approach has become more or less standard.
(2) Jelonek's proof also establishes that the cardinality of the algebraic closure of \mathbb {F} is \max (|\mathbb {F}|,\aleph _{0}). In particular, the algebraic closure is always infinite.

fr:title.text: Lifting embedding of a field into an extension to an embedding of the extension into the algebraic closure

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Lifting embedding of a field into an extension to an embedding of the extension into the algebraic closure

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let \mathbb {F} be a field, let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be an algebraic extension, and i:\mathbb {F}\hookrightarrow \mathbb {L} be an embedding of \mathbb {F} into an algebraically closed field \mathbb {L}. Then:
There exists an extension of i to an embedding of \Bbbk in \mathbb {L}; and
If \Bbbk is algebraically closed and \mathbb {L} is algebraic over i(\mathbb {F}), then any such extension of i is an isomorphism of \Bbbk onto \mathbb {L}.

Let S be the set of all pairs (F,\tau ) where F is a subfield of \Bbbk containing \mathbb {F} and \tau is an extension of i to an embedding of \tau \colon F\hookrightarrow \mathbb {L} (where \tau |_{\mathbb {F}}=i).

If (F,\tau ) and (F',\tau ') are such pairs, we write (F,\tau )\leq (F',\tau ') if F\subseteq F' and \tau '|_{F}=\tau . Note: S is not empty (it contains (\mathbb {F},i)) and it is inductively ordered: if (F_{i},\tau _{i}) is a totally ordered subset, we let F=\bigcup F_{i} and define \tau on F to be equal to \tau _{i} on each F_{i}.

Then (F,\tau ) is an upper bound for the totally ordered subset. Using Zorn's lemma, let (K,\lambda ) be a maximal element in S. Then \lambda is an extension of i, and the claim is K=\Bbbk . Otherwise there exists an \alpha \in \Bbbk such that \alpha \notin K. But our embedding \lambda has an extension to K(\alpha ) thereby contradicting the maximality of (K,\lambda ). This proves there exists an extension of i to \Bbbk . We will just abuse notation and denote this extension by i again.
If \Bbbk is algebraically closed and \mathbb {L} is algebraic over i(\mathbb {F}), then i(\Bbbk ) is algebraically closed and \mathbb {L} is algebraic over i(\Bbbk ). Hence \mathbb {L}=i(\Bbbk ).

fr:title.text: Algebraic Closure is Unique up to Isomorphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Algebraic Closure is Unique up to Isomorphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If \Bbbk _{1}/\mathbb {F} and \Bbbk _{2}/\mathbb {F} are algebraic closures of \mathbb {F}, then \Bbbk _{1} is isomorphic to \Bbbk _{2}.

Extending the identity map on \mathbb {F} to an embedding of \Bbbk _{1} into \Bbbk _{2} and applying lifts of embeddings of a field \mathbb {F}\hookrightarrow \Bbbk _{1} to an embedding \Bbbk _{1}\hookrightarrow \Bbbk _{2} is an isomorphism, we have the result.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: There are many different isomorphisms between algebraic closures of \mathbb {F}, so we can't really speak of "the" algebraic closure of a field.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We just need to prove this is a field morphism. It's clear \phi (1)=1 and \phi (xy)=xy. We see: \begin {align*} \phi (x+y) &= (x+y)^{p}\\ &= x^{p}+\binom {p}{1}x^{p-1}y+\binom {p}{2}x^{p-2}y^{2}+…+\binom {p}{1}xy^{p-1}+y^{p} \end {align*} We see if 0<k<p, the numerator of the binomial coefficient \binom {p}{k} is divisible by p, but not its denominator. Since \binom {p}{k} is an integer, it must be a multiple of p, hence equal to 0 in \mathbb {F}. Therefore \phi (x+y)=x^{p}+y^{p}=\phi (x)+\phi (y). Hence \phi is a field morphism.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This seems to have first appeared in Ferdinand Georg Frobenius's "Über Beziehungen zwischen den Primidealen eines algebraischen Körpers und den Substitutionen seiner Gruppe" (Sitzungsberichte der Königlich Preußischen Akademie der Wissenschaften zu Berlin 2 (1896) 689–703; reprinted in his Gesammelte Abhandlungen [Collected Papers], Springer, vol. 2, 1968, pages 719-733).

fr:title.text: Frobenius morphism is bijection on finite fields of finite characteristic

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Frobenius morphism is bijection on finite fields of finite characteristic

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If \mathbb {F} is a finite field with characteristic p>0, then the Frobenius morphism is a bijection.
The Frobenius morphism is a nonzero morphism, so it's an injective function on a finite set. Therefore it must be surjective, hence bijective.

fr:title.text: Finding the roots of a polynomial over a finite field

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Finding the roots of a polynomial over a finite field

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let F=\mathbb {F}_{p}(t) be our field, which has Characteristic p but it's also an infinite field. Consider the polynomial f(x)=x^{p}-t\in F[x]. Let \Bbbk / F be a splitting field for f(x), and let \alpha \in \Bbbk be a root of f(x). Then we have f(x)=x^{p}-\alpha ^{p}=(x-\alpha )^{p}. Then all the roots of f(x) in \Bbbk are equal.

Let m_{\alpha }(x) be the minimal polynomial of f(x) over F. Then it must equal m_{\alpha }(x)=(x-\alpha )^{k}. If p=kq+r (where 0\leq r<p), then f(x)=\bigl (m_{\alpha }(x)\bigr )^{q}\cdot (x-\alpha )^{r}, so that (x-\alpha )^{r}\in F[x]. Since (x-\alpha )^{k} is the minimal polynomial, and r < k, it follows that r=0.
It follows that x^{p}-t is irreducible over \mathbb {F}_{p}(t), yet all its roots in the splitting field are equal.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: When we study Galois theory, we will want to study the splitting field of a polynomial by studying the symmetries of its roots. But in this example, there are no symmetries to investigate because there's only a single root. This forces us to make a careful distinction between general splitting fields.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A polynomial p(x) over a field \mathbb {F} is called Separable if its roots are all distinct in its splitting field over \mathbb {F}. Otherwise, we say p(x) is Inseparable.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Consider the example where we were Finding the roots of a polynomial over a finite field. All the roots for the polynomial were "inseparable" (i.e., they were "the same" when our intuition from the fundamental theorem of algebra would mislead us into thinking there were p roots). This is the motivation for the terminology here.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Puzzle: do we need to find the splitting field for p(x) to determine if it's separable or not?

fr:title.text: Criteria for polynomials to be separable

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criteria for polynomials to be separable

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A polynomial p(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] is separable if and only if p(x) and p'(x) have no common root.
Note: by p'(x) we mean the formal derivative. That is, if p(x)=a_{n}x^{n}+a_{n-1}x^{n-1}+…+a_{1}x+a_{0}, then p'(x)=na_{n}x^{n-1}+(n-1)a_{n-1}x^{n-2}+…+a_{1}.

Let p(x)=c(x-\alpha _{1})(…)(x-\alpha _{n}) be the factorization of p(x) over the splitting field. Then by the product rule for differentiation, p'(x)=c\left (\frac {p(x)}{x-\alpha _{1}}+\frac {p(x)}{x-\alpha _{2}}+…+\frac {p(x)}{x-\alpha _{n}}\right ). We see each term in the sum is a polynomial.

(\Longleftarrow ) (Proof by contrapositive.) If p(x) is inseparable, then \alpha _{i}=\alpha _{j} for some i\neq j. Then \alpha _{i} is a root of p(x)/(x-\alpha _{k}) for all k, hence p'(\alpha _{i})=0, and \alpha _{i} is a common root of p(x) and p'(x).

(\Longrightarrow ) (Direct proof.) Assume p(x) is separable over its splitting field, then we see its roots satisfy \alpha _{i}-\alpha _{j}
eq 0 for i
eq j. Then we see p'(\alpha _{i})=c\prod _{i
eq j}(\alpha _{i}-\alpha _{j}), so that \alpha _{i} is not a root of p'(x). Hence the result.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Note that p(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] and q(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] have no common root if and only if \gcd (p(x),q(x))=1, which can be checked in \mathbb {F}[x] using the Euclidean algorithm, without any need to compute any extensions.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Exercise: For p(x)=x^{p}-t\in \mathbb {F}_{p}(t), calculate p'(x) and \gcd (p(x),p'(x)) to prove p(x) is inseparable.

fr:title.text: Irreducible polynomials are separable iff its derivative is not identically zero

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Irreducible polynomials are separable iff its derivative is not identically zero

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An irreducible polynomial p(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] is separable if and only if p'(x)\neq 0.
(\Longrightarrow ) (Proof by contrapositive.) Assume p'(x)=0. Then p(x)\mathrel {\bigm |} p'(x), hence p(x) is separable by the criteria for polynomials to be separable.
(\Longleftarrow ) (Proof by contradiction.) Assume p'(x)\neq 0. Then p(x)=p'(x)q(x)+r(x), where \deg (r)<\deg (p') by the division algorithm.

Now assume for contradiction p(x) has a double root \alpha , then r(\alpha )=p(\alpha )-p'(\alpha )q(\alpha )=0. Then the minimal polynomial divides the remainder polynomial m_{\alpha }(x)\mathrel {\bigm |} r(x), so that m_{\alpha }(x)\neq p(x) and so p(x) is reducible. This contradicts the hypothesis that p(x) is irreducible. Hence the result.

fr:title.text: Irreducible polynomials are separable over fields of characteristic zero

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Irreducible polynomials are separable over fields of characteristic zero

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If \mathbb {F} have Characteristic zero, then every irreducible polynomial p(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] is separable.
We see p'(x)\neq 0 over \mathbb {F}, hence the result.

fr:title.text: Inseparable polynomial over field with characteristic p has p divide the nonzero coefficients of its derivative

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inseparable polynomial over field with characteristic p has p divide the nonzero coefficients of its derivative

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field with Characteristic p>0 and f(x)=a_{n}x^{n}+…+a_{1}x+a_{0}. If f(x) is inseparable, then p\mathrel {\bigm |} k for each k where a_{k}\neq 0.

We see the coefficients of f'(x) are ka_{k}. If f(x) is irreducible and inseparable, then its derivative vanishes identically f'(x)=0. Then we see for each k, ka_{k}=0. Hence p\mathrel {\bigm |} k if a_{k}\neq 0.
A field \mathbb {F} is called Perfect if every irreducible p(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] is seperable.
Exercise: Prove or find a counter-example: Fields of characteristic zero are perfect.
Puzzle: Are there any finite fields which are perfect?
A field extension \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is called Separable if the minimal polynomial m_{\alpha }(x) is separable for all \alpha \in \Bbbk .
Exercise: Prove or find a counter example: a field \mathbb {F} of characteristic zero have every finite extension \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be separable.

fr:title.text: Criteria for perfect fields of finite characteristic

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criteria for perfect fields of finite characteristic

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field of characteristic p>0. Then the following are equivalent:

fr:ol.fr:li: \mathbb {F} is perfect;
The Frobenius morphism \phi (x)=x^{p} is surjective; and
Every finite extension of \mathbb {F} is separable.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: (1)\implies (2): Assume \mathbb {F} is perfect. Let a\in \mathbb {F}. Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be the splitting field of x^{s}-a and let \beta \in \Bbbk be such that \beta ^{p}=a. Then the characteristic polynomial m_{\beta }(x) over \mathbb {F} is irreducible, and divides x^{p}-a=x^{p}-\beta ^{p}=(x-\beta )^{p}. Since \mathbb {F} is perfect, m_{\beta } has no repeated roots, so m_{\beta }=x-\beta , and \beta \in \mathbb {F}.

(2)\implies (3): (Proof by contradiction.) Assume \phi is surjective. Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be a finite extension, let \alpha \in \Bbbk , and let m_{\alpha }(x)=a_{n}x^{n}+a_{n-1}x^{n-1}+…+a_{1}x+a_{0}. Assume for contradiction m_{\alpha }(x) is inseparable, so that m'_{\alpha }(x)=0 and then we see p\mathrel {\bigm |} k whenever a_{k}\neq 0. Since \phi is surjective, each a_{k}=b_{k}^{p} for some b_{k}\in \mathbb {F}. Then m_{\alpha }(x)=(b_{m}x^{m})^{p}+(b_{m-1}x^{m-1})^{p-1}+…+(b_{1}x)^{p}+b_{0}^{p}=(q(x))^{p}, where q(x)=b_{m}x^{m}+…+b_{1}x+b_{0}, which contradicts the irreducibility of m_{\alpha }(x). Hence m_{\alpha }(x) must be separable.

(3)\implies (1): Suppose p(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] is irreducible. Then \Bbbk =\mathbb {F}[x]/(p(x)) is a separable extension of \mathbb {F}. If \alpha \in \Bbbk is the image of x\in \mathbb {F}[x], then m_{\alpha }(x)=p(x) is separable.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: An immediate corollary: Finite fields are perfect.

fr:title.text: Existence and uniqueness of finite extensions for fields of nonzero characteristic

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Existence and uniqueness of finite extensions for fields of nonzero characteristic
