fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. There exists a unique (up to isomorphism) extension of \mathbb {F}_{p} of degree n, and it is the splitting field of x^{p^{n}}-x.
Suppose \Bbbk / \mathbb {F}_{p} is a finite extension of degree n.

Claim 1: \Bbbk is the splitting field of x^{p^{n}}-x. Since \Bbbk / \mathbb {F}_{p} has degree n, then \Bbbk is a finite field with p^{n} elements. The group \Bbbk ^{\times } has p^{n}-1 elements, and so for all a\in \Bbbk ^{\times } we have a^{p^{n}-1}=1. Then every a\in \Bbbk is a root of x^{p^{n}}-x. On the other hand, x^{p^{n}}-x\in \mathbb {F}_{p}[x] has degree p^{n}, so \Bbbk is exactly the splitting field of x^{p^{n}}-x over \mathbb {F}_{p}.
(This also proves the existence of an extension of degree n of \mathbb {F}_{p}.)
(1) Since the field extension is unique, we denote it by \mathbb {F}_{p^{n}}.

(2) This proposition gives us all finite fields of characteristic p>0 are of the form \mathbb {F}_{p^{n}}. Moreover, they form a tower of extensions \mathbb {F}_{p}\subset \mathbb {F}_{p^{2}}\subset \mathbb {F}_{p^{3}}\subset …
(3) The Frobenius morphism extends to \mathbb {F}_{p^{n}}\to \mathbb {F}_{p^{n}} by \phi (x)=x^{p} for each n>1.

fr:title.text: Group of n^{{th}} roots of unity

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Group of n^{\text {th}} roots of unity
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 13.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The group of all n^{\text {th}} roots of unity (equipped with multiplication) is denoted \mu _{n}.
Exercise: Prove \mu _{n}\cong \mathbb {Z} / n\mathbb {Z} as groups (with addition on the right-hand side, but multiplication on the left-hand side).
The Primitive n^{\text {th}} roots of unity are the \zeta \in \mu _{n} such that they generate the group \langle \zeta \rangle =\mu _{n}.
The n^{\text {th}} Cyclotomic Polynomial is defined as \Phi _{n}(x)=\prod _{\substack {\zeta \in \mu _{n}\\\zeta \text { primitive}}}(x-\zeta ).
Exercise 1: When p is prime, prove every element of \mu _{p} is primitive.
Exercise 2: When p is prime, prove \Phi _{p}(x)=\frac {x^{p}-1}{x-1}=x^{p-1}+x^{p-2}+…+x+1.
Exercise 3: Prove \deg (\Phi _{n}(x))=\phi (n) where \phi (n) is the Euler totient function.
Exercise 4: Prove x^{n}-1=\sum _{\zeta \in \mu _{n}}(x-\zeta )=\prod _{d\mathrel {\bigm |} n}\prod _{\text {prim }\zeta \in \mu _{d}}(x-\zeta )=\prod _{d\mathrel {\bigm |} n}\Phi _{d}(x).
Exercise 5: Prove \Phi _{4}(x)=x^{2}+1, \Phi _{6}(x)=x^{2}-x+1, \Phi _{8}(x)=x^{4}+1, and \Phi _{9}(x)=x^{6}+x^{3}+1. (Hint: use exercise 4 and calculate x^{n}-1 for n=4,6,8,9.)

Caution: it is false that all coefficients of \Phi _{n}(x) are \pm 1 or 0. But the first counter-example appears at n=105 which has two terms with coefficient -2. However, it is true that all coefficients of every Cyclotomic polynomial are integers.

fr:title.text: Cyclotomic polynomials are irreducible polynomials in {Z}[x]

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cyclotomic polynomials are irreducible polynomials in \mathbb {Z}[x]

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For each n, the cyclotomic polynomial \Phi _{n}(x) is a monic irreducible polynomial in \mathbb {Z}[x].
Cyclotomic polynomials are monic… this should be obvious.
Claim 1: \Phi _{n}\in \mathbb {Z}[x] for any n\in \mathbb {N}.
Proof by induction on n.
Base case: n=1. We see \Phi _{1}(x)=x-1 is clearly irreducible.
Inductive hypothesis: Assume \Phi _{d}(x)\in \mathbb {Z}[x] for any d<n.

Inductive case: We see \Phi _{n}(x)f(x)=x^{n}-1 where f(x)=\prod _{d\mathrel {\bigm |} n}\Phi _{d}(x)\in \mathbb {Z}[x] by the inductive hypothesis. Then x^{n}-1=f(x)\Phi _{n}(x) is a factorization over \mathbb {Q}. But by Gauss's lemma, since both f(x) and \Phi _{n}(x) are monic, we see \Phi _{n}(x)\in \mathbb {Z}[x].

Claim 2: \Phi _{n}(x) is irreducible. Suppose we have some factorization \Phi _{n}(x)=f(x)g(x) where f(x)\in \mathbb {Z}[x] is irreducible and g(x)\in \mathbb {Z}[x]. Let \zeta be a root of f(x), so \zeta \in \mu _{n} primitive.

We claim: for any a\in \mathbb {Z}, if a is coprime to n, then \zeta ^{a} is a root of f(x). It suffices to prove this for a=p prime. We have \Phi _{n}(\zeta ^{p})=0 imply either f(\zeta ^{p})=0 or g(\zeta ^{p})=0.

Subcase 2: Assume f(\zeta ^{p})=0. Then for any a\in \mathbb {Z}, if a is coprime with n, then \zeta ^{a} is a root of f(x). This implies \Phi _{n}(x)\mathrel {\bigm |} f(x), which means \Phi _{n}(x)=f(x). Hence \Phi _{n}(x) is irreducible.

fr:title.text: Degree of rationals adjoined with n^{{th}} root of unity is given by Euler totient of n

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Degree of rationals adjoined with n^{\text {th}} root of unity is given by Euler totient of n

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We claim [\mathbb {Q}(\zeta _{n}) : \mathbb {Q}]=\phi (n) where \phi (n) is the Euler totient.

The proof is based loosely on two ideas:
We may compare the factorization of x^{n}-1 over \mathbb {Q} with that of x^{n}-1 over \mathbb {F}_{p} with p\nmid n.
Investigate how automorphisms of a finite field permute the roots of polynomials. More about the second idea: suppose F(x) is a polynomial over \mathbb {F}_{p} and F(x)=f(x)g(x) for some f(x),g(x)\in \mathbb {F}_{p}[x]. The splitting field of F(x) is \mathbb {F}_{p^{n}} for some n, and the Frobenius morphism \phi (x)=x^{p} is an automorphism of this splitting field. Since \phi is the identity function on \mathbb {F}_{p}, it must permute the roots of F(x). Suppose \alpha is a root of F(x). Then \phi (\alpha )=\alpha ^{p} is a root of either f(x) or g(x). But g(\alpha ^{p})=g(\alpha )^{p}, so g(\alpha ^{p})=0 implies g(\alpha )=0. So if F(x) is separable, then the Frobenius morphism permutes the roots of different factors of F(x) separately.
Studying how automorphisms of a splitting field for a polynomial acts on the roots of the polynomial naturally leads to Galois theory.
Let \Bbbk be a field. An Automorphism of \Bbbk is a field isomorphism \sigma \colon \Bbbk \to \Bbbk .
We denote by \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk ) the group of all field automorphisms of \Bbbk equipped with function composition.

Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be a field extension. An Automorphism of \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is a Field automorphism \sigma \colon \Bbbk \to \Bbbk such that when restricted to \mathbb {F} it is the identity function \sigma |_{\mathbb {F}}=\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{\mathbb {F}}.
We denote by \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}) the group consisting of the collection of automorphisms of \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} equipped with composition of functions.
Notation: People also write \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits _{\mathbb {F}}(\Bbbk ) instead of \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}) since it's a bit cleaner.

fr:title.text: Automorphism group of field is the same as automorphism group of field extending its prime subfield

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Automorphism group of field is the same as automorphism group of field extending its prime subfield

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Bbbk _{0} be the prime subfield of \Bbbk . Then \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk ) = \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \Bbbk _{0}).

Since \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \Bbbk _{0})\subseteq \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk ), we just need to prove the reverse inclusion. Let \sigma \colon \Bbbk \to \Bbbk be such that \sigma (1)=1 and so \sigma (n)=n.
If \mathop {\textrm {char}}\nolimits (\Bbbk )>0, then the prime subfield is generated by one \Bbbk _{0}=\langle 1\rangle and so \sigma |_{\Bbbk _{0}}=\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{\Bbbk _{0}}.

fr:title.text: Galois correspondences are order-reversing bijection between field extensions and their automorphisms

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Galois correspondences are order-reversing bijection between field extensions and their automorphisms

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: (1) There is also a bijective correspondence sending subgroups H of \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}) to subfields \mathbb {L} of \Bbbk containing \mathbb {F} which fixes \mathbb {L} under H (i.e., for any \sigma \in H we have \forall x\in \Bbbk , x\in \mathbb {L}\iff \sigma (x)=x).
It may be tempting to conjecture these two bijections are inverses of each other, but that is not the case.
(2) This correspondence exists, but it is only a conjecture they are bijections. For this reason, this is a "conjecture" not a "proposition".
(3) These correspondences are known as "Galois correspondences".

fr:title.text: Number of extensions to field isomorphisms is at most degree of extensions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Number of extensions to field isomorphisms is at most degree of extensions

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \sigma \colon \mathbb {F}\to \mathbb {F}' be a field isomorphism, let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be the splitting field for some f(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x], and let \Bbbk '/\mathbb {F}' be the splitting field for g(x) (the polynomial obtained by applying \sigma to f(x)).
Then the number of extensions of \sigma to an isomorphism \Bbbk \to \Bbbk ' is at most [\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}]. If f(x) is separable, then it is exactly [\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}].
Proof by induction on n=[\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}].
Base Case: n=1. Then \Bbbk =\mathbb {F}, \Bbbk '=\mathbb {F}', and the unique extension of \sigma to \Bbbk \to \Bbbk ' is just \sigma itself.
Inductive hypothesis: Assume the hypothesis holds for all field extensions of degree [\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}]<n.

Inductive case: Let f_{0}(x) be an irreducible factor of f(x) over \mathbb {F}, let \alpha \in \Bbbk be a root of f_{0}(x). Then \mathbb {F}(\alpha ) is a subextension of \Bbbk / \mathbb {F}. If \widetilde {\sigma }\colon \Bbbk \to \Bbbk ' extends \sigma \colon \mathbb {F}\to \mathbb {F}', then it maps \alpha to a root \beta of some irreducible factor g_{0}(x) of g(x), and induces \sigma _{0}\colon \mathbb {F}(\alpha )\to \mathbb {F}(\beta ). We know [\mathbb {F}(\alpha ) : \mathbb {F}] is equal to the degree of g(x).

On the other hand, there are as many maps \mathbb {F}(\alpha )\to \Bbbk as there distinct roots of g(x). Therefore there are at most [\mathbb {F}(\alpha ) : \mathbb {F}]=\deg (g) choices for \sigma _{0}(\alpha ), with equality iff f_{0}(x) is separable.

By the inductive hypothesis, each such \sigma _{0} has at most [\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}(\alpha )] extensions to \widetilde {\sigma }\colon \Bbbk \to \Bbbk '. Since \Bbbk is also the splitting field of f(x) over \mathbb {F}(\alpha ), there are exactly [\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}(\alpha )] extensions if f(x) is separable.

Then altogether there are at most [\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}(\alpha )][\mathbb {F}(\alpha ) : \mathbb {F}]=[\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}] extensions for \widetilde {\sigma }, and exactly as that many if f(x) is separable.

fr:title.text: Number of Automorphisms of a splitting field is no greater than its degree

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Number of Automorphisms of a splitting field is no greater than its degree

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be the splitting field for some f(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x]. Then |\mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F})|\leq [\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}], with equality if f(x) is separable.
Let \mathbb {F}'=\mathbb {F}, \Bbbk '=\Bbbk , and \sigma =\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits , and the result follows from Number of extensions to field isomorphisms is at most degree of extensions.
Let \Bbbk =\mathbb {F}_{p^{n}} and \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {F}_{p} and suppose p\nmid n. What is \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F})?

We know the Frobenius morphism \phi (x)=x^{p} gives us \phi _{r}(x)=x^{p^{r}}=\underbrace {\phi \circ \cdots \circ \phi }_{r\text { times}}. Hence \langle \phi \rangle =\mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}), which is a finite cycle group of order n.
Observe the minimal polynomial of a has degree \deg (m_{a})=n.

We claim \phi _{r}(a) (for r=0,…,n-1) are the n distinct roots of this polynomial. Otherwise, if there is a r<s such that \phi _{r}(a)=\phi _{s}(a), then we would have a^{p^{r}}=a^{p^{s}}, which means a^{p^{n-s+r}}=a^{p^{n}}=a, which contradicts a^{k}\neq 1 for k<p^{n}-1.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Galois extension and Galois group
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 14.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If f(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] is separable and \Bbbk is the splitting field of f(x), then \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}) is called the Galois Group of f(x).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We follow Dummit and Foote in defining the Galois group of an extension so that \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}) has the maximal number of automorphisms. Some authors are more generous and just treat the Galois group as a synonym for the Automorphism group for field extensions, any arbitrary field extension.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Question: Are Quadratic extensions Galois?
Answer: Yes.

fr:title.text: Lattice of field extensions and subgroups of field extension automorphisms

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Lattice of field extensions and subgroups of field extension automorphisms

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Question: Let \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {Q} and \Bbbk =\mathbb {Q}(\sqrt [3]{2}, \zeta _{3}) where \zeta _{3}=\mathop {\textrm {exp}}\nolimits (\mathrm {i} 2\pi / 3) is a root of unity.

fr:ol.fr:li: Is \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} Galois or not?
What is the lattice of field extensions of \mathbb {F} which are subfields of \Bbbk ?
What is the lattice of subgroups of \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F})?

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Answer 1: We see \Bbbk is the splitting field of x^{3}-2, which implies \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is Galois.
Answer 2: The diagram of subfiels of \Bbbk look like:
Observe the subgroup lattice is doodled thus:
The edges in the subgroup diagram are labeled by the index of the subgroup.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Character
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 14.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A Character of a group G with values in a field \mathbb {F} is a group morphism \chi \colon G\to \mathbb {F}^{\times }. In particular, this means \chi (gh)=\chi (g)\chi (h) for all g,h\in G.

We will write \mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits _{\mathbf {Grp}}(G,\mathbb {F}^{\times }) (or \mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits (G,\mathbb {F}^{\times }) if there's no risk of ambiguity) for the set of all characters of G with values in \mathbb {F}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear Independence of Characters
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 14.2.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If \chi _{1}, …, \chi _{n} are distinct characters of G with values in \mathbb {F}, then they are linearly independent over \mathbb {F}.
(Proof by contradiction) Assume \chi _{1}, …, \chi _{n} are linearly dependent. By removing some \chi _{i}, we can assume any proper subset of \{\chi _{1},…,\chi _{n}\} is independent.

fr:title.text: Distinct embeddings of fields are linearly independent

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Distinct embeddings of fields are linearly independent
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Corollary 14.2.8

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F}, \Bbbk be fields. If \sigma _{1},…,\sigma _{n}\colon \mathbb {F}\to \Bbbk are distinct field embeddings (i.e., nonzero field morphisms), then they are linearly independent.

We see \sigma \colon \mathbb {F}\to \Bbbk is a field morphism iff \sigma \colon \mathbb {F}^{\times }\to \Bbbk ^{\times } is a group morphism. Equivalently, \sigma is a character of \mathbb {F}^{\times } with values in \Bbbk . Since field morphisms preserve zero, we see the Linear Independence of Characters implies the result.

Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be an extension, let G = \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}). Let H\leq G be a subgroup. Then we introduce the notation \Bbbk ^{H} := \{a\in \Bbbk \mid \forall \sigma \in H\ldotp \sigma (a)=a\}. Then \Bbbk ^{H} is a subfield of \Bbbk and also \mathbb {F}\subseteq \Bbbk ^{H}\subseteq \Bbbk .

fr:title.text: Size of finite subgroup of field automorphisms is not greater than index of subfield fixed by the subgroup

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Size of finite subgroup of field automorphisms is not greater than index of subfield fixed by the subgroup

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Bbbk be a field, let H\leq \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk ) be a finite subgroup of field automorphisms. If \mathbb {F}=\Bbbk ^{H} is the subfield fixed by H, then |H|\leq [\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}].
Let n=|H| and m=[\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}]. Either n\leq m (as desired) or n>m (which we want to prove leads to contradiction).
Case 1: n\leq m. This is the desired case, and we have the result.

Case 2: n>m (i.e., there are more automorphisms than there are \mathbb {F}-linarly independent elements of \Bbbk ). Given \alpha \in \Bbbk ^{m} with components \alpha =(\alpha _{1},…,\alpha _{m}), let \sigma \in H be arbitrary. We write for the componentwise application of \sigma to \alpha as: \sigma \alpha =(\sigma \alpha _{1},…,\sigma \alpha _{m}). Then for the n distinct elements of H=\{\sigma _{1},…,\sigma _{n}\}, we see \sigma _{1}\alpha , …, \sigma _{n}\alpha gives the basis for \Bbbk ^{n}: there exists c_{i}\in \Bbbk such that c_{1}\sigma _{1}\alpha +…+c_{n}\sigma _{n}\alpha =0. We write \sigma =c_{1}\sigma _{1}+…+c_{n}\sigma _{n}. But take \alpha _{1}, …, \alpha _{m} as a \mathbb {F}-basis of \Bbbk , then \sigma \alpha _{1}=…=\sigma \alpha _{m}=0 which implies \sigma =0, which contradicts the linear independence of characters.

fr:title.text: Size of finite subgroup of field automorphisms is not less than index of subfield fixed by the subgroup

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Size of finite subgroup of field automorphisms is not less than index of subfield fixed by the subgroup

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Bbbk be a field, let H\leq \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk ) be a finite subgroup of field automorphisms. If \mathbb {F}=\Bbbk ^{H} is the subfield fixed by H, then |H|\geq [\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}].
Let H=\{\sigma _{1},…,\sigma _{n}\} so n=|H|, let m=[\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}]. Either n\geq m (as desired) or n < m (which we will prove leads to contradiction).
Case 1: n\geq m. Well, this is the desired result.
Case 2: n < m (there are fewer automorphisms than \mathbb {F}-linearly independent elements of \Bbbk ).
For each i=1,…,m we write \alpha _{i}=(\sigma _{1}a_{i},\sigma _{2}a_{i},…,\sigma _{n}a_{i})\in \Bbbk ^{n}. Since m>n, the \alpha _{i} must be linearly dependent.
Claim 1: For any \sigma \in H and (c_{1},…,c_{r})\in U, we have (\sigma c_{1},…,\sigma c_{r})\in U.
Claim 2: \dim _{\Bbbk }(U)=1.

Claim 3: Contradiction. Let (c_{1},…,c_{r})\in U be nonzero, and without loss of generality assume c_{1}=1. For each \sigma \in H, we see: (\sigma 1,\sigma c_{2},…,\sigma c_{r})=(1,\sigma c_{2},…,\sigma c_{r}). By claim 2, \dim _{\Bbbk }(V)=1, which implies (1,\sigma c_{2},…,\sigma c_{r}) must be a scalar multiple of (1,c_{2},…,c_{r}). But this implies \sigma c_{i}=c_{i} for each i and for each \sigma \in H. Then c_{i}\in \mathbb {F} by definition of \mathbb {F} (being the subfield of fixedpoints under H). Then we have for each j, \sum ^{r}_{i=1}c_{i}\sigma _{j}(a_{i})=0, which implies \sigma \left (\sum ^{r}_{i=1}c_{i}a_{i}\right )=0, which means \sum ^{r}_{i=1}c_{i}a_{i}=0. This contradicts the linear independence of a_{i}.

fr:title.text: Degree of subfield fixed by a finite subgroup equals the size of the subgroup

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Degree of subfield fixed by a finite subgroup equals the size of the subgroup

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Bbbk be a field, let H\leq \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk ) be a finite subgroup of field automorphisms. If \mathbb {F}=\Bbbk ^{H} is the subfield fixed by H, then |H|=[\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}].
This follows from the inequality |H|\leq [\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}], and the inequality [\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}]\leq |H|, which implies the result.

fr:title.text: Size of automorphism group for finite extension is not greater than the degree of the finite extension

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Size of automorphism group for finite extension is not greater than the degree of the finite extension

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be a finite extension of \mathbb {F}. Then |\mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F})|\leq [\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}]. Moreover, \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is Galois if and only if \mathbb {F} = \Bbbk ^{\mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F})} is the subfield fixed by the automorphism group.

For H=\mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}), we have \mathbb {F}\subseteq \Bbbk ^{H}. Then we have, |\mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F})|=[\Bbbk : \Bbbk ^{H}]\leq [\Bbbk : \Bbbk ^{H}][\Bbbk ^{H} : \mathbb {F}] and equality is precisely when [\Bbbk ^{H} : \mathbb {F}]=1.

fr:title.text: Subfield fixed under finite subgroup of automorphisms is a Galois extension

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subfield fixed under finite subgroup of automorphisms is a Galois extension

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Bbbk be a field and H\leq \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk ) is a finite subgroup. Then \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \Bbbk ^{H})=H, and in particular \Bbbk / \Bbbk ^{H} is Galois.

The failure in bijectivity lies in the composition \mathbb {F}\mapsto \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F})\mapsto \Bbbk ^{\mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F})}. But being Galois means this composition is the identity map.

fr:title.text: Subfields fixed by distinct subgroups of automorphisms are distinct

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subfields fixed by distinct subgroups of automorphisms are distinct

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For distinct finite subgroups H_{1}\leq \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk ) and H_{2}\leq \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk ), the fixed subfields \kK ^{H_{1}} and \Bbbk ^{H_{2}} are distinct.

This follows from H\mapsto \Bbbk ^{H}\mapsto \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \Bbbk ^{H}) being the identity map (from Subfield fixed under finite subgroup of automorphisms is a Galois extension).

Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be a Galois extension, let \alpha \in \Bbbk . The Galois Conjugates of \alpha are elements of the form \sigma \alpha for \sigma \in \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}). These are just the orbits of \alpha under the action of \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}) on \Bbbk .
Exercise: Let z\in \mathbb {C} be a complex number. When, if ever, is the complex conjugate of z a Galois conjugation of z?

fr:title.text: Irreducible polynomials with a root in a Galois extension is separable and splits over that extension

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Irreducible polynomials with a root in a Galois extension is separable and splits over that extension

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be a Galois extension, let G=\mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}), let f(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] be an irreducible polynomial. If there exists some \alpha \in \Bbbk such that f(\alpha )=0, then f(x)=\prod _{\beta \in G\alpha }(x-\beta ), where G\alpha =\{g\alpha \mid g\in G\} is the set of Galois conjugates of \alpha . In particular, f(x) is separable and splits over \Bbbk .

Let g(x)=\prod _{\beta \in G\alpha }(x-\beta ). For each \sigma \in G, let g^{\sigma }(x) be the polynomial obtained by applying \sigma to the coefficients of g. Then g^{\sigma }(x)=\prod _{\beta \in G\alpha }(x-\sigma \beta ). Then g(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x].

We see g(\alpha )=0 and irreducibility implies f is the minimal polynomial of \alpha (i.e., f(x)=m_{\alpha }(x)), which implies f(x)\mathrel {\bigm |} g(x). We see f(\sigma \alpha )=f^{\sigma }(\alpha )=f(\alpha )=0, which implies G\alpha are roots of f. This then implies g(x)\mathrel {\bigm |} f(x). Hence g=f.

fr:title.text: Finite field extensions are Galois iff it is the splitting field of a separable polynomial

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Finite field extensions are Galois iff it is the splitting field of a separable polynomial

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A finite extension \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is Galois if and only if \Bbbk is the splitting field of a separable polynomial f(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x].

Let \alpha _{1}, …, \alpha _{n} be an \mathbb {F}-basis for \Bbbk . Each \alpha _{i} has an orbit G\alpha _{i}\in \Bbbk where G=\mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}). Let G\alpha _{1}, …, G\alpha _{n} be the distinct orbits. We see f_{i}(x)=\prod _{\beta \in G\alpha }(x-\beta ) is irreducible and separable. Then f(x)=\prod ^{n}_{i=1}f_{i}(x) is separable and \Bbbk is the splitting field of \mathbb {F}.
A field extension \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is Normal if \Bbbk is the splitting field of a collection of polynomials f_{i}(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x].
Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be a finite extension. Then the following are equivalent:

fr:ol.fr:li: \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is Galois
\mathbb {F} is the fixed field of \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}) in \Bbbk
\Bbbk is the splitting field of a separable polynomial f(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x]
\Bbbk is a normal separable extension

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: (1)\iff (2) by definition.
(1)\iff (3) and (1)\iff (4) by Subfield fixed under finite subgroup of automorphisms is a Galois extension.
(4)\implies (5) Obvious.

(5)\implies (4) If \Bbbk is normal, then it is the splitting field of some f_{i}(x) which can be taken to be irreducible and distinct. If further \Bbbk is separable, then each f_{i}(x) is separable, hence \Bbbk is the splitting field of f(x)=\prod _{i}f_{i}(x), which is separable as f_{i}(x) are distinct, irreducible, and separable. Hence the claim.
This actually consists of three propositions, and it's easier to prove each proposition separately. But we will recapitulate all these results in "one giant theorem".

fr:title.text: Galois correspondence is bijective iff field extension is Galois

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Galois correspondence is bijective iff field extension is Galois

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Galois correspondence is a bijection if and only if \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is Galois. In particular, if \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is Galois, so is \Bbbk / \mathbb {L} for all subfields \mathbb {L}\subseteq \Bbbk containing \mathbb {F}\subseteq \mathbb {L}.

(\Longrightarrow ) Let \mathbb {L} / \mathbb {F}\subseteq \Bbbk / \mathbb {F}. Then we see \Bbbk ^{\mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {L})}=\mathbb {L} if and only if \Bbbk / \mathbb {L} is Galois. Then the Galois correspondence is a bijection if and only if \Bbbk / \mathbb {L} for every \mathbb {L}\subseteq \Bbbk containing \mathbb {F}\subseteq \mathbb {L}. In particular, it's necessary for \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} to be Galois.

(\Longleftarrow ) Assume \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is Galois. Then we see \Bbbk is the splitting field of a separable f(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x]. Then \Bbbk is the splitting field of f(x)\in \mathbb {L}[x], so \Bbbk / \mathbb {L} is Galois. Hence every \Bbbk / \mathbb {L} is Galois.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Thus \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is Galois exactly when the lattice diagram of subextensions \mathbb {L} / \mathbb {F} \subseteq \Bbbk / \mathbb {L} coincides with the lattice diagram of subgroups of \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}). We make this notion more precise in the following proposition.

fr:title.text: Lattice of subextensions coincides with lattice of subgroups iff the field extension is Galois

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Lattice of subextensions coincides with lattice of subgroups iff the field extension is Galois

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be Galois and G=\mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}). Let H_{1} and H_{2} be subgroups of G corresponding to subfields \mathbb {L}_{1} and \mathbb {L}_{2}, respectively. Then the following all holds:

fr:ol.fr:li: H_{1}\subseteq H_{2} if and only if \mathbb {L}_{2}\subseteq \mathbb {L}_{1}, and in this case we have [\mathbb {L}_{1} : \mathbb {L}_{2}]=[H_{2} : H_{1}];
For every subgroup H\leq G, [\Bbbk : \Bbbk ^{H}]=|H| and also [\Bbbk ^{H} : \mathbb {F}]=[G : H];

Let \langle H_{1},H_{2}\rangle denote the subgroup of G generated by H_{1}\cup H_{2}, and let \mathbb {L}_{1}\mathbb {L}_{2} be the composite of \mathbb {L}_{1} and \mathbb {L}_{2} in \Bbbk . Then H_{1}\cap H_{2}=\mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / (\mathbb {L}_{1}\mathbb {L}_{2})) and \Bbbk ^{\langle H_{1},H_{2}\rangle }=\mathbb {L}_{1}\cap \mathbb {L}_{2}.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: (2) Let H\mathrel {<} G be a proper subgroup. By Lattice of subextensions coincides with lattice of subgroups iff the field extension is Galois, \Bbbk / \Bbbk ^{H} is Galois, therefore we see |H|=|\mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \Bbbk ^{H})| = [\Bbbk : \Bbbk ^{H}]. Since \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is Galois, we also have |G|=[\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}]. Then [\Bbbk ^{H} : \mathbb {F}]=\frac {[\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}]}{[\Bbbk : \Bbbk ^{H}]}=\frac {|G|}{|H|}=[G : H], as desired.

(1) We have already seen the Galois correspondence is order-reversing. For the second part, suppose H_{1}\subseteq H_{2}, so \Bbbk ^{H_{2}}\subseteq \Bbbk ^{H_{1}}. We then have \begin {align*} [\Bbbk ^{H_{1}} : \Bbbk ^{H_{2}}] &= \frac {[\Bbbk ^{\mathbb {H}_{1}} : \mathbb {F}]}{[\Bbbk ^{H_{2}} : \mathbb {F}]}\\ &=\frac {[G : H_{1}]}{[G : H_{2}]}\\ &=[H_{2} : H_{1}]\end {align*}
The second claim in (3) requires first establishing:

Subclaim 1: \mathbb {L}_{1}\cap \mathbb {L}_{2}\subseteq \Bbbk ^{\langle H_{1},H_{2}\rangle } because both H_{1} and H_{2} both fix \mathbb {L}_{1}\cap \mathbb {L}_{2}, so \langle H_{1},H_{2}\rangle \subseteq \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / (\mathbb {L}_{1}\cap \mathbb {L}_{2})) which proves the claim.

Subclaim 2: \Bbbk ^{\langle H_{1},H_{2}\rangle }\subseteq \mathbb {L}_{1}\cap \mathbb {L}_{2} because \Bbbk ^{\langle H_{1},H_{2}\rangle }\subseteq \Bbbk ^{H_{i}}=\mathbb {L}_{i} for both i=1,2, which proves the second claim.
Then these two subclaims imply \Bbbk ^{\langle H_{1},H_{2}\rangle }=\mathbb {L}_{1}\cap \mathbb {L}_{2} which concludes proving (3).

fr:title.text: Where do the missing automorphisms go?

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Where do the missing automorphisms go?

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Claim 1: The map \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F})\to \mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits _{\mathbb {F}}(\mathbb {L},\mathbb {K}) is surjective.
Claim 2: The map from claim 1 induces a bijection of sets G/H\longleftrightarrow \mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits _{\mathbb {F}}(\mathbb {L},\Bbbk ).
Claim 3: \mathbb {L} / \mathbb {F} is normal iff H\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G.

fr:ol.fr:li: \mathbb {F}\subset \mathbb {L}_{1}\subseteq \mathbb {L}_{2}\subseteq \Bbbk if and only if \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {L}_{2})\subseteq \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {L}_{1});

If H\mapsto \Bbbk ^{H}=\mathbb {L} under the correspondence,
\Bbbk / \mathbb {L} is Galois and \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {L})=H, and
\mathbb {L} / \mathbb {F} is Galois if and only if H is normal, in which case \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\mathbb {L} / \mathbb {F})\cong G/H

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This follows from the propositions proved earlier.

We claimed that all finite fields of characteristic p>0 are of the form \mathbb {F}_{p^{n}} for some n\in \mathbb {N}. This also implies that the only subfields of \mathbb {F}_{p^{n}} are of the form \mathbb {F}_{p^{d}} where d\mathrel {\bigm |} n.

In fact, we proved \mathbb {F}_{p^{n}} is the splitting field of x^{p^{n}}-x, therefore it is Galois over \mathbb {F}_{p}. Since [\mathbb {F}_{p^{n}} : \mathbb {F}_{p}]=n, the Galois group has order n. It follows that \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\mathbb {F}_{p^{n}} / \mathbb {F}_{p}) is generated by the Frobenius map since it has order n. In other words, \begin {split}\mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\mathbb {F}_{p^{n}} / \mathbb {F}_{p}) & \xrightarrow {\sim }\mathbb {Z} / n\mathbb {Z}\\ \phi ^{r} &\mapsto r\end {split} If d\mathrel {\bigm |} n, then the unique cyclic subgroup of \mathbb {Z} / n\mathbb {Z} is of order d generated by k (where n=dk). This corresponds to the map \phi ^{k}(x)=x^{p^{k}}. An element \alpha \in \mathbb {F}_{p^{n}} is in the fixed field of \langle \phi ^{k}\rangle if and only if \alpha ^{p^{k}}=\alpha , which is to say that \alpha is a root of x^{p^{k}}-x.

Note that k\mathrel {\bigm |} n implies (p^{k}-1)\mathrel {\bigm |}(p^{n}-1), which implies (x^{p^{k}-1}-1)\mathrel {\bigm |}(x^{p^{n}-1}-1) which implies (x^{p^{k}}-x)\mathrel {\bigm |}(x^{p^{n}}-x). So the splitting field of x^{p^{n}}-x contains the splitting field of x^{p^{k}}-x. It follows that \mathbb {F}_{p^{n}}^{\langle \phi ^{k}\rangle }=\mathbb {F}_{p^{k}} Then \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\mathbb {F}_{p^{n}} / \mathbb {F}_{p^{k}}) is the subgroup of \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\mathbb {F}_{p^{n}} / \mathbb {F}_{p}) generated by \phi ^{p^{k}} and isomorphic to \mathbb {Z} / d\mathbb {Z}.

Since \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\mathbb {F}_{p^{n}} / \mathbb {F}_{p}) is Abelian, every subgroup is normal. Therefore \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\mathbb {F}_{p^{k}} / \mathbb {F}_{p}) which is isomorphic to \langle \phi \rangle / \langle \phi ^{k}\rangle \cong (\mathbb {Z} / n\mathbb {Z}) / (\mathbb {Z} / k\mathbb {Z})\cong \mathbb {Z} / k\mathbb {Z}, which is generated by the image of \phi in the quotient group.

But if we want to actually compute with a finite field \mathbb {F}_{q}, where q=p^{n}, we need to find a presentation with generators and relations. If f(x) is an irreducible polynomial of degree n over \mathbb {F}_{p}, then \mathbb {F}_{p}[x]/(f(x)) must be isomorphic to \mathbb {F}_{p^{n}}. Such irreducible polynomials do exist, but that assertions remains to be proven.

fr:title.text: Finite extensions of finite fields of characteristic p>0 are simple

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Finite extensions of finite fields of characteristic p>0 are simple

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let p\in \mathbb {N} be prime, let n\in \mathbb {N}. Then the finite extension \mathbb {F}_{p^{n}} / \mathbb {F}_{p} is simple, which means there exists some irreducible polynomial f(x)\in \mathbb {F}_{p}[x] of degree n such that \mathbb {F}_{p^{n}}\cong \mathbb {F}_{p}[x]/(f(x)).

Since \mathbb {F}_{p^{n}}^{\times } is cyclic, the result follows. More explicitly, let \alpha be a generator, then every other element of \mathbb {F}_{p^{n}} is a power of \alpha , so \mathbb {F}_{p^{n}}\cong \mathbb {F}_{p}[\alpha ]\cong \mathbb {F}_{p}[x]/(f(x)), where f(x)=m_{\alpha }(x) is the minimal polynomial of \alpha over \mathbb {F}_{p}. Since \mathbb {F}_{p^{n}} has degree n over \mathbb {F}_{p}, so does f(x).
Let p\in \mathbb {N} be prime, let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. Then x^{p^{n}}-x is the product of every distinct irreducible polynomials over \mathbb {F}_{p} whose degree divides n.

Let f(x) be an irreducible polynomial of degree d such that d\mathrel {\bigm |} n. Then \mathbb {F}_{p}[x]/(f(x))\cong \mathbb {F}_{p^{d}}, which is isomorphic to a subfield of \mathbb {F}_{p^{n}}. Then f(x) has a root in \mathbb {F}_{p^{n}}, hence splits completely over it since \mathbb {F}_{p^{n}} / \mathbb {F}_{p} is Galois. But then every root of f(x) (being an element of \mathbb {F}_{p^{n}}) is a root of x^{p^{n}}-x. Since f(x) is separable, f(x)\mathrel {\bigm |}(x^{p^{n}}-x).

Suppose f(x) is irreducible over \mathbb {F}_{p} and suppose it divides x^{p^{n}}-x. Then its splitting field is contained in \mathbb {F}_{p^{n}} and must be isomorphic to \mathbb {F}_{p^{d}} for some d which divides d\mathrel {\bigm |} n. But since \mathbb {F}_{p^{d}} is Galois, it must be isomorphic to \mathbb {F}_{p}[x]/(f(x)), hence f(x) has degree d.
Since x^{p^{n}}-x is separable, it's the product of all distinct irreducible factors.

We define the Möbius function \mu \colon \mathbb {N}\to \mathbb {Z} by \mu (n) = \begin {cases}1 & \hbox {if }n=1\\ 0 & \hbox {if }n\hbox { has a square factor}\\ (-1)^{r} & \hbox {if }n\hbox { has }r\hbox { distinct factors}\end {cases}

If f\colon \mathbb {N}\to \mathbb {C} is a function, then we define its Möbius transform g(n)=\sum _{d\mathrel {\bigm |} n}f(d) which satisfies a Möbius inversion formula f(n)=\sum _{d\mathrel {\bigm |} n}\mu (d)g(n / d).

fr:title.text: Number of irreducible polynomials over finite fields of characteristic p>0

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Number of irreducible polynomials over finite fields of characteristic p>0

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The number of distinct irreducible polynomials of degree n over \mathbb {F}_{p} is given by \frac {1}{n}\sum _{d\mathrel {\bigm |} n}\mu (d)p^{n / d}, where \mu (n) is the Möbius function.

Let f(n) be the number of distinct irreducible polynomials of degree n over \mathbb {F}_{p}. Since the distinct irreducibles of degree d (where d\mathrel {\bigm |} n) are all the factors of x^{p^{n}}-x, counting degrees we get p^{n}=\sum _{d\mathrel {\bigm |} n}d\cdot f(d). Then applying the Möbius inversion formula to g(n)=p^{n} gives us nf(n)=\sum _{d\mathrel {\bigm |} n}\mu (d)p^{n / d}, as desired

We see by direct calculation, \begin {align*} \frac {[\Bbbk _{1} : \mathbb {F}][\Bbbk _{2} : \mathbb {F}]}{[\Bbbk _{1}\cap \Bbbk _{2} : \mathbb {F}]} &= [\Bbbk _{1} : \Bbbk _{1}\cap \Bbbk _{2}][\Bbbk _{2} : \mathbb {F}]\\ &= [\Bbbk _{1}\Bbbk _{2} : \Bbbk _{2}][\Bbbk _{2} : \mathbb {F}]\\ &= [\Bbbk _{1}\Bbbk _{2} : \mathbb {F}]. \end {align*}
The Galois Closure \mathbb {L} of \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} in \overline {\Bbbk } is the intersection of all Galois extensions of \mathbb {F} containing \Bbbk .
A Simple Field Extension is a Field extension generated by a single element \mathbb {F}(\alpha ). We call \alpha a Primitive Element.
Fact: If \mathop {\textrm {char}}\nolimits (\mathbb {F})=0, then all finite extensions of \mathbb {F} are simple.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: If \mathbb {F} is a finite field, then every extension is simple (Really? Prove it! What about infinite extensions?). But what is some good criteria for \mathbb {F} infinite?

fr:title.text: A finite extension of an infinite field is simple iff it has finitely many subfields

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A finite extension of an infinite field is simple iff it has finitely many subfields

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be an infinite field, let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be a finite extension. Then \Bbbk is simple if and only if \Bbbk has finitely many subfields.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This holds trivially for finite fields \mathbb {F}.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Any finite separable extension \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is simple. In particular, any finite extensions of a Perfect field is simple.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Steinitz presented this in its modern form first in his paper Algebraische Theorie der Körper (1910).

fr:title.text: Galois group of Cyclotomic field is multiplicative groups of integers modulo n

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Galois group of Cyclotomic field is multiplicative groups of integers modulo n

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The sums \sum _{\sigma \in H}\sigma \zeta _{n} are called Gaussian Periods. The study of their combinatorial properties is referred to as Cyclotomy.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a finite Abelian group. There exists a field \Bbbk contained in some Cyclotomic field \mathbb {Q}(\zeta _{n}) such that \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {Q})\cong G.
An Abelian Extension \Bbbk of \mathbb {F} is a Galois extension whose Galois group \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}) is Abelian.
Any finite Abelian extension of \mathbb {Q} is contained in some cyclotomic field.
(1) This is a difficult theorem in algebraic number theory requiring class field theory. We won't prove this theorem.
(2) If \Bbbk / \mathbb {Q} is Abelian, then \Bbbk =\mathbb {Q}(\alpha ) where \alpha is some rational function of n^{\text {th}} roots of unity \zeta _{n}.
(3) How to generalize this to arbitrary quadratic extensions over \mathbb {Q} and how to find them? This remains an open problem.

fr:title.text: Constructibility of regular polygon by straightedge and compass

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Constructibility of regular polygon by straightedge and compass
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 14.5.29

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Which finite groups occur as Galois groups of rational polynomials?

Let \mathbb {F} be a field (or more generally, any commutative ring), let x_{1}, …, x_{n} be formal variables. The Elementary Symmetric Functions in x_{1}, …, x_{n} are \begin {align*}s_{1}&=x_{1}+…+x_{n}\\ s_{2}&=x_{1}x_{2}+x_{1}x_{3}+…+x_{n-1}x_{n}=\prod _{1\leq i<j\leq n}x_{i}x_{j}\\ s_{3}&=x_{1}x_{2}x_{3}+…+x_{n-2}x_{n-1}x_{n}=\prod _{1\leq i<j<k\leq n}x_{i}x_{j}x_{k}\\ \vdots & \\ s_{n} &= x_{1}x_{2}(…)x_{n}\end {align*}
The field \mathbb {F}(s_{1},…,s_{n}) generated by the elementary symmetric polynomials s_{i} is a subfield of \mathbb {F}(x_{1},…,x_{n}) of rational functions.

fr:title.text: Galois group of rational functions over the field of elementary symmetric functions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Galois group of rational functions over the field of elementary symmetric functions

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Consider the field of rational functions as a field extension \mathbb {F}(x_{1},…,x_{n}) / \mathbb {F}(s_{1},…,s_{n}) of the field generated by the Elementary Symmetric Functions. Then its Galois group is \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\mathbb {F}(x_{1},…,x_{n}) / \mathbb {F}(s_{1},…,s_{n}))=S_{n}.

fr:title.text: Rational functions invariant under permutations may be written in terms of elementary symmetric functions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Rational functions invariant under permutations may be written in terms of elementary symmetric functions

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Any rational functions in x_{1}, …, x_{n} which is invariant under permutations of the x_{i} may be written as a function of Elementary Symmetric Functions s_{1}, …, s_{n}.

fr:title.text: The roots of a polynomial are algebraically independent

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The roots of a polynomial are algebraically independent

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In other words, if f\in \mathbb {F}[y_{1},…,y_{n}] is any nonzero polynomial, then f(x_{1},…,x_{n})\neq 0.

fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 14.6.32

fr:title.text: Asymptotic density of polynomials whose Galois group is not the symmetric group

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Asymptotic density of polynomials whose Galois group is not the symmetric group

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R_{n}(M) be the number of polynomials of degree n with coefficients |a_{i}|\leq M and whose Galois group is not S_{n}. Then R_{n}(M)\ll M^{n-1/2}\log (M).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This was proved by Patrick X. Gallagher, "The large sieve and probabilistic Galois theory", Proceedings of Symposia in Pure Mathematics XXIII (AMS, 1973), pages 91–101. Gallagher improved an earlier result of van der Waerden. See also Dietmann's "Probabilistic Galois Theory" (arXiv:1111.2853) for recent developments.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let x_{1}, …, x_{n} be a set of numbers. Their Discriminant is D=\prod _{i<j}(x_{i}-x_{j})^{2}. The discriminant of a polynomial is the discriminant of its roots.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: It's easy to see D is invariant under transpositions, hence under all the elements of S_{n}. Therefore D is a function of s_{1}, …, s_{n}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 14.6.33

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field of characteristic \mathop {\textrm {char}}\nolimits (\mathbb {F})\neq 2, let \sigma \in S_{n} be a permutation. Then \sigma \in A_{n} if and only if it fixes the squareroot of the Discriminant D.
In other words, \mathbb {F}(s_{1},…,s_{n},\sqrt {D}) is a quadratic extension over \mathbb {F}(s_{1},…,s_{n}), and its Galois group is A_{n}.
Exercise 1: Consider a quadratic polynomial f(x)=x^{2}+ax+b. Suppose it has roots \alpha , \beta . What is its discriminant in terms of a and b?

Exercise 2: Consider a cubic polynomial f(x)=x^{3}+ax^{2}+bx+c. A change of variables x=y-(a/3) transforms the polynomial into g(y)=y^{3}+py+q.
What is p and q in terms of a, b, and c?
Check the discriminant is (\alpha -\beta )^{2}(\beta -\gamma )^{2}. What is this in terms of the coefficients a, b, c? What is it in terms of p and q?

fr:title.text: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra via Galois Theory

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra via Galois Theory

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We will use the following facts:

fr:ol.fr:li: Any odd-degree polynomial with real coefficients has a real root (which is a consequence of the intermediate value theorem from calculus);
Any quadratic polynomial over the complex numbers has a complex root (which can be verified using the quadratic formula).

fr:p.fr:em: Any non-constant polynomial p(x)\in \mathbb {C}[x] has a root in \mathbb {C}. In other words, \mathbb {C} is algebraically closed.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Proof: It's enough to prove this for p(x)\in \mathbb {R}[x]. Indeed, p(x) has a complex root if and only if \overline {p}(x) does, which is the polynomial obtained from p(x) by complex conjugation. Then p(x) has a complex root if and only if q(x)=p(x)\overline {p}(x) does. Now q(x) is invariant under complex conjugation, so it belongs to \mathbb {R}[x].

Let p(x)\in \mathbb {R}[x] be a nonconstant polynomial, let \Bbbk / \mathbb {R} be its splitting field. Let H be the Sylow 2-subgroup of \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk (i)/\mathbb {R}). Then \Bbbk (i)^{H} has odd degree over \mathbb {R}.

By fact (1), \Bbbk (i)^{H} must be the trivial extension, i.e., \Bbbk (i)^{H}=\mathbb {R}. Therefore \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk (i)/\mathbb {R}) is a finite 2-group, therefore so is \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk (i)/\mathbb {C}) (say, of order 2^{n}). If n\geq 1, the latter must therefore contain a subgroup H' of order 2^{n-1} of index 2 and necessarily normal. Then \Bbbk (i)^{H'} is a quadratic extension of \mathbb {C}.
By fact (2), this is impossible, so n=0, and \Bbbk (i)=\mathbb {C}.
In other words, \mathbb {C} contains all the roots of p(x).
Let \mathbb {F} be a field. We say the extension \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is Cyclic if it is a Galois extension and \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}) is a cyclic group.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criteria for simple radical extensions
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 14.7.36

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N}. Let \mathbb {F} be a field containing the n^{\text {th}} roots of unity. If \mathop {\textrm {char}}\nolimits (\mathbb {F})\nmid n, then for any a\in \mathbb {F} the extension \mathbb {F}(\sqrt [n]{a}) ic cyclic over \mathbb {F} of degree dividing n.
Here \sqrt [n]{a} is any solution to x^{n}-a\in \mathbb {F}[x].

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We say \mathbb {F}(\sqrt [n]{a}) is a Simple Radical Extension of \mathbb {F}.
This was invented by Lagrange in his memoirs [book] Réflexions sur la résolution algébrique des équations (1770).

fr:title.text: Lagrange resolvent is not fixed by any subgroup of the Galois group

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Lagrange resolvent is not fixed by any subgroup of the Galois group

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field containing the roots of unity \mu _{n}, of characteristic not dividing n, i.e. \mathop {\textrm {char}}\nolimits (\mathbb {F})\nmid n. If \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is a cyclic Galois extension, then \Bbbk = \mathbb {F}(\sqrt [n]{a}) for some a\in \mathbb {F}.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This is a converse to the criteria for simple radical extensions.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If b=\lambda (a,\zeta )^{n}, then \sqrt [n]{b}\in \Bbbk and b\in \mathbb {F}. Then \mathbb {F}(\sqrt [n]{b})=\Bbbk .

By the linear independence of characters, there exists an a\in \mathbb {F} such that \lambda (a,\zeta )
eq 0 and \sigma \lambda (a,\zeta )=\zeta ^{-1}\lambda (a,\zeta )
eq \lambda (a,\zeta ), so for any k we have \sigma ^{k}\lambda (a,\zeta )=\zeta ^{-k}\lambda (a,\zeta )
eq \lambda (a,\zeta ). Hence \lambda (a,\zeta ) is not fixed by any subgroup of \mathop {	extrm {Gal}}
olimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}). Hence \Bbbk =\mathbb {F}(\sqrt [n]{b}).

Suppose \mathbb {F} is a field of characteristic zero. Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be a finite extension. We say \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is a Root Extension if there exists subfields \mathbb {F}=K_{0}\subset K_{1}\subset …\subset K_{i}\subset K_{i+1}\subset …\subset K_{s}=\Bbbk where K_{i+1}=K_{i}(a_{j}^{1/n_{j}}) for some a_{i}\in K_{i} for i=0,1,…,s-1.
If \alpha is algebraic over \mathbb {F}, we say it can be Expressed by Radicals if \alpha lies in a root extension of \mathbb {F}.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This notion is well-defined when \mathbb {F} is characteristic p>0 and p does not divide any of the n_{j} (orders of the roots that are taken).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let p(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] be a polynomial. We say p(x) is Solvable by Radicals if the roots of p(x) can be expressed using addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and radicals of constants and coefficients of p(x).
In other words, all roots of p(x) can be expressed by radicals (i.e., all the roots lie in some Root Extension of \mathbb {F}).

fr:title.text: Simple root extension of a root extension is another root extension

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Simple root extension of a root extension is another root extension

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be a Root Extension with \mathbb {F} = K_{0}\subset K_{1}\subset …\subset K_{n}=\Bbbk such that K_{i+1}=K_{i}(a_{i}^{1 / n_{i}}) for some a_{i}\in K_{i}.
For any a\in \mathbb {F} and m\in \mathbb {N}, writing \mathbb {F}'=\mathbb {F}(a^{1 / m}) and \Bbbk ' = \mathbb {F}'\Bbbk , then we have \Bbbk ' / \mathbb {F} is a root extension.

fr:title.text: Composite of root extensions is a root extension

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Composite of root extensions is a root extension

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} and \Bbbk '/\mathbb {F} are Root Extensions, then so is (\Bbbk \Bbbk ')/ \mathbb {F}.

Suppose \mathbb {F}=K_{0}\subset K_{1}\subset …\subset K_{n}=\Bbbk and \mathbb {F}=K'_{0}\subset K'_{1}\subset …\subset K'_{n'}=\Bbbk Simple root extension of a root extension is another root extension inductively implies the extensions K'_{i+1}/K_{i} gives us the extensions K'_{1}\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}, K'_{2}\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}, …, K'_{n'}\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}.

fr:title.text: Galois closure of a root extension is a root extension

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Galois closure of a root extension is a root extension

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be a Root Extension, let \mathbb {L} be a Galois closure of \Bbbk . Then \mathbb {L} / \mathbb {F} is a Root Extension.

Write \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F})=\{\sigma _{1},…,\sigma _{r}\}, then \sigma _{i}\Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is a root extension, so each extension \mathbb {F}=K_{0}\subset K_{1}\subset …\subset K_{n}=\Bbbk we have for each \sigma _{j}\in \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}), \mathbb {F}=\sigma _{j}K_{0}\subset \sigma _{j}K_{1}\subset …\subset \sigma _{j}K_{n}=\sigma _{j}\Bbbk . If K_{i+1}=K_{i}(a_{i}^{1 / n_{i}}), then \sigma _{j}K_{i+1}\sigma _{j}K_{i}(\sigma _{j}a^{1 / n_{i}}). But since a_{i}^{1 / n_{i}} is a root of x^{n_{i}}-a_{i}, we see that \sigma _{j}a_{i}^{1 / n_{i}} is a root of x^{n_{i}}-\sigma _{j}a_{i}. So if \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is a root extension, then so is \sigma _{j}\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}. Then applying Composite of root extensions is a root extension inductively, the composite of all \sigma _{j}\Bbbk (which is \mathbb {L}) is a root extension of \mathbb {F}.

Let G be a group. We say G is Solvable if there is a tower of subgroups 1=G_{0}\mathrel {<} G_{1}\mathrel {<}…\mathrel {<} G_{k}=G such that for each i we have G_{i}\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G_{i+1} and G_{i+1}/G_{i} is Abelian.
Exercise: Prove S_{n} is solvable for n<5, but not solvable for n\geq 5.
The polynomial p(x) is solvable by radicals if and only if the Galois group of p(x) is solvable.

(\Longleftarrow ) Assume the Galois group of p(x) is solvable. If \mathbb {L} is the splitting field and G=\mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\mathbb {L} / \mathbb {F}), then there exists groups 1=G_{0}\mathrel {<} G_{1}\mathrel {<}…\mathrel {<} G_{n}=G such that G_{j}\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G_{j+1} and G_{j+1}/G_{j} is cyclic.

(\Longleftarrow ) Assume p(x) is solvable by radicals. Let \alpha be a root of p(x) lying in a root extension of \Bbbk / \mathbb {F}. Then we see \alpha lies in a solvable Galois extension \mathbb {L} / \mathbb {F}. Since \mathbb {L} is Galois, it must contain the splitting extension \Bbbk of p(x). Then \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}) is a quotient of \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\mathbb {L} / \mathbb {F}) and therefore it is solvable.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This implies there is no general formula for the roots of a polynomial p(x) of degree p(x)\geq 5 in terms of radicals, addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division by constants and the coefficients of the polynomial.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In general, a polynomial p(x) of degree \deg (p)\geq 5 is not solvable by radicals.
The Galois group of such a p(x) is S_{n} which is not solvable for n\geq 5. Galois's theorem implies the result.

fr:title.text: Tools from algebraic number theory for calculating Galois groups

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Tools from algebraic number theory for calculating Galois groups

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suppose f(x)\in \mathbb {Q}[x] is an irreducible polynomial. Often it's enough to determine the Galois group of f(x) up to isomorphism, as a subgroup of S_{n}.
Let us review some relevant parts of algebraic number theory which will help us calculate the cycle type in Galois groups of polynomials over the integers.
A Number Field is a finite field extension of \mathbb {Q}.

Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {Q} be a Number Field. An element a\in \Bbbk is called an Algebraic Integer if its minimal polynomial m_{\alpha }(x) is a polynomial with integer coefficients, i.e., m_{\alpha }(x)\in \mathbb {Z}[x].
The set of all algebraic integers in \Bbbk is denoted \mathcal {O}_{\Bbbk }.

fr:ol.fr:li: Let \Bbbk =\mathbb {Q}(\mathrm {i}) where \mathrm {i}=\sqrt {-1}. Then \mathcal {O}_{\Bbbk }=\mathbb {Z}[\mathrm {i}].
Let \Bbbk =\mathbb {Q}(\sqrt {2}). Then \mathcal {O}_{\Bbbk }=\mathbb {Z}[\sqrt {2}].

Let \Bbbk =\mathbb {Q}(\sqrt {5}). Then the minimal polynomial of \sqrt {5} is m_{\sqrt {5}}(x)=x^{2}-x-1. This means that \mathcal {O}_{\Bbbk }=\mathbb {Z}[\varphi ] where \varphi =(1+\sqrt {5})/2 is the golden ratio.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: (1) If \sigma \in \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {Q}), then \sigma (\mathcal {O}_{\Bbbk })=\mathcal {O}_{\Bbbk }.

(2) If I\mathrel {\triangleleft }\mathcal {O}_{\Bbbk } is a proper ideal, then \sigma (I)\mathrel {\trianglelefteq }\mathcal {O}_{\Bbbk } for any \sigma \in \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {Q}).

fr:title.text: Algebraic integers form an integral domain

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Algebraic integers form an integral domain

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Bbbk be a Number Field. The ring of Algebraic Integers \mathcal {O}_{\Bbbk } is an Integral domain and its field of fractions is \Bbbk .
Proof idea: Suffices to show \mathcal {O}_{\Bbbk } is closed under addition and multiplication. Then it's an integral domain since it's a subring of a field.

fr:title.text: Prime factorization of ideals of algebraic integers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Prime factorization of ideals of algebraic integers

fr:title.text: Galois group of number field acts transitively on any prime factor of an ideal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Galois group of number field acts transitively on any prime factor of an ideal

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {Q}) acts transitively on the prime ideals P_{i}. Moreover, for each P_{i}, we have P_{i}\cap \mathbb {Z}=p\mathbb {Z}.

(1) Prime factorization of ideals of algebraic integers plus this proposition implies all the powers e_{i} of the factorization of an ideal are equal to each other e_{i}=e_{j} for all i, j. This exponent is called the Ramification Index.
(2) In this situation, we say that a prime ideal P\mathrel {\trianglelefteq }\mathcal {O}_{\Bbbk } Lies Above p if P occurs in the factorization of the principal ideal (p).

When P\mathrel {\trianglelefteq }\mathcal {O}_{\Bbbk } is lying over p\in \mathbb {Z}, then \mathcal {O}_{\Bbbk }/P is a finite field containing \mathbb {F}_{p}\cong \mathbb {Z} / p\mathbb {Z}, so \mathcal {O}_{\Bbbk }/P\cong \mathbb {F}_{q} for some q=p^{m}.
Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {Q} be the splitting field of an irreducible monic polynomial f(x)\in \mathbb {Z}[x]. Suppose p\in \mathbb {Z} is a prime not dividing the discriminant of f(x).
Then p\mathbb {Z}=P_{1}(…)P_{r} is a prime ideal factorization of p\mathbb {Z} in \mathcal {O}_{\Bbbk } with P_{i}\mathrel {\trianglelefteq }\mathcal {O}_{\Bbbk } distinct.

For each P=P_{i}, the group morphism D_{P}\to \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\mathbb {F}_{q} / \mathbb {F}_{p}) is an isomorphism. In particular, D_{P} is cyclic of order [\mathbb {F}_{q} : \mathbb {F}_{p}] generated by the Frobenius element in \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\mathbb {F}_{q}/\mathbb {F}_{p}).

Let C\subseteq \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {Q}) be a conjugacy class of size r, let n=|\mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {Q})|. Then the density (proportion) of primes p\in \mathbb {Z} such that C=\mathbb {F}_{p} is r/n.

Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be a field extension. A subset S\subseteq \Bbbk is called Algebraically Independent over \mathbb {F} if for any s_{1}, …, s_{n}\in S, and any nonzero polynomial f(x_{1},…,x_{n})\in \mathbb {F}[x_{1},…,x_{n}], we have f(s_{1},…,s_{n})\neq 0.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This should remind the reader of Linearly Independent Vectors from linear algebra.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Example: \{\pi \}\subseteq \mathbb {C} is algebraically independent over \mathbb {Q}.

fr:title.text: Field extensions with nonempty algebraically independent sets are not finite extensions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field extensions with nonempty algebraically independent sets are not finite extensions

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be a field extension. If S\subseteq \Bbbk is a nonempty Algebraic Independence set, then \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is not finite.
Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be a field extension. A Transcendental Basis of \Bbbk over \mathbb {F} is an algebraically independent set S that is maximal with respect to inclusion.
This follows from Zorn's lemma.
Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be a field extension, let S be a transcendental basis of \Bbbk over \mathbb {F}. Then the Transcendence Degree of \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is the cardinality of S.
We claim (without proof) that any two transcendence bases for \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} have the same cardinality. Hence the transcendence degree is well-defined.

Let S\subseteq \Bbbk be a transcendental basis for \Bbbk over \mathbb {F}. The \mathbb {F}(S) is a Purely Transcendental extransion of \mathbb {F}, i.e., it is generated by an algebraically independent set.

fr:title.text: Field extensions over purely transcendental extensions are algebraic

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field extensions over purely transcendental extensions are algebraic

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let S\subseteq \Bbbk be a transcendental basis over \mathbb {F}. Then \Bbbk / (\mathbb {F}(S)) is an algebraic extension.
Let x\in \Bbbk . If x is not algebraic over \mathbb {F}(S), then S'=S\cup \{x\} is algebraically independent over \mathbb {F} and strictly contains S, which contradicts the maximality of S.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Therefore a completely arbitrary extension \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} can be decomposed into extensions \Bbbk / (\mathbb {F}(S)) which is purely algebraic, and \mathbb {F}(S) / \mathbb {F} which is purely transcendental.

fr:ol.fr:li: We see the field of rational functions in two unknowns with rational coefficients \mathbb {Q}(t_{1},t_{2}) is purely transcendental over \mathbb {Q} and has transcendental degree equal to 2.

Although both \mathbb {Q}(\pi ) / \mathbb {Q} and \mathbb {Q}(\mathrm {e}) / \mathbb {Q} are both purely transcendental. However, it is not known if \mathbb {Q}(\pi ,\mathrm {e}) / \mathbb {Q} is purely transcendental (i.e., there may be some nonconstant polynomial f(x,y)\in \mathbb {Q}[x,y] such that f(\mathrm {e},\pi )=0): this is still an open problem.

Let C\subseteq \mathbb {C}^{2} be the algebraic curve given by \{(a,b)\in \mathbb {C}^{2}\mid f(a,b)=0\} for some irreducible f\in \mathbb {C}[x,y]. Then A=\mathbb {C}[x,y]/(f(x,y)) is the set of all polynomial functions on C, and its fraction field K corresponds to the rational functions on C. Then K is a field of transcendental degree 1 over \mathbb {C}, but it is not purely transcendental.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This last example leads naturally to algebraic geometry. The classic text to classical algebraic geometry is Griffiths' Introduction to Algebraic Curves.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Set of complex numbers
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics §2.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We define the Set of Complex Numbers \mathbb {C}=\{(x,y)\mid x,y\in \mathbb {R}\}. Given a complex number z=(x,y), we call \Re (z)=x the Real Part of z, and \Im (z)=y the Imaginary Part of z.
We write \mathrm {i}=(0,1) for the Imaginary Unit and write z=(x,y) as z=x+\mathrm {i} y. (Electrical Engineers use j instead for the imaginary unit.)

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Addition of complex numbers
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics §2.2.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We define the Addition of complex numbers as the binary operator + by (a+\mathrm {i} b)+(c+\mathrm {i} d)=(a+c)+\mathrm {i}(b+d)

fr:title.text: Properties of addition of complex numbers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of addition of complex numbers
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.2.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z_{1},z_{2},z_{3}\in \mathbb {C} be complex numbers. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: Commutativity: z_{1}+z_{2}=z_{2}+z_{1}
Additive identity: There is a unique complex number denoted 0 such that for any z\in \mathbb {C} we have 0+z=z. Moreover, 0=(0,0).
Additive inverse: For each z\in \mathbb {C} there exists a unique complex number denoted -z such that z+(-z)=0. Moreover, if z=(x,y), then -z=(-x,-y).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Multiplicative inverse of complex numbers
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.2.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For any nonzero z\in \mathbb {C}, z\neq 0, there exists a unique complex number denoted z^{-1} such that zz^{-1}=1. Moreover, if z=x+\mathrm {i} y with x,y\in \mathbb {R}, then z^{-1}=\frac {x}{x^{2}+y^{2}}+\mathrm {i}\frac {-y}{x^{2}+y^{2}}
Uniqueness: Suppose there are two complex numbers w\in \mathbb {C} and v\in \mathbb {C} such that zv=1 and zw=1. Then v=1v=(zw)v=(wz)v=w(zv)=w1=w.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of multiplying complex numbers
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.2.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z_{1},z_{2},z_{3}\in \mathbb {C} be complex numbers. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: Commutativity: z_{1}z_{2}=z_{2}z_{1}
Multiplicative identity: There is a unique complex number denoted 1 such that for any z\in \mathbb {C} we have 1z=z. Moreover, 1=(1,0).
Distributivity of multiplication over addition: z_{1}(z_{2}+z_{3})=z_{1}z_{2}+z_{1}z_{3}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Complex conjugation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 2.2.8

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z=x+\mathrm {i} y\in \mathbb {C} be a complex number with x,y\in \mathbb {R}. Then we define the Complex Conjugate of z to be the complex number \overline {z}=x-\mathrm {i} y.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of complex conjugation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.2.9

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z_{1} and z_{2}\in \mathbb {C} be complex numbers. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: \overline {z_{1}+z_{2}}=\overline {z_{1}}+\overline {z_{2}} (the conjugate of the sum is the sum of conjugates)
\overline {z_{1}z_{2}}=\overline {z_{1}}\overline {z_{2}} (the conjugate of products is the product of conjugates)
\overline {1/z_{1}}=1/\overline {z_{1}} when z_{1}\neq 0
\overline {z_{1}}=z_{1} if and only if \Im (z_{1})=0
\Re (z_{1})=\frac {1}{2}(z_{1}+\overline {z_{1}}) and \Im (z_{1})=\frac {1}{2\mathrm {i}}(z_{1}-\overline {z_{1}}).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Modulus of complex number
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 2.2.10

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z=x+\mathrm {i} y be a complex number with x,y\in \mathbb {R}. We define the Modulus of z to be the value |z|=\sqrt {x^{2}+y^{2}}>0. In particular, if x\in \mathbb {R}, then |x+\mathrm {i} 0|=\sqrt {x^{2}+0}=|x| is just the absolute value.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of modulus
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.2.11

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z_{1},z_{2}\in \mathbb {C} be complex numbers. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: Triangle inequality: |z_{1}+z_{2}|\leq |z_{1}|+|z_{2}|
z_{1}\overline {z_{1}}=|z_{1}|^{2} which implies when z_{1}\neq 0, z_{1}^{-1}=\frac {\overline {z_{1}}}{|z_{1}|^{2}}

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Polar form for complex numbers
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics 2.3.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z=x+\mathrm {i} y be a complex number where x,y\in \mathbb {R}. Then we define the Argument of z to be the number \theta =\mathop {\textrm {Arg}}\nolimits (z) where 0\leq \theta <2\pi such that x=|z|\cos (\theta ) and y=|z|\sin (\theta ).
We can also write this in exponential form as z=|z|\mathop {\textrm {exp}}\nolimits (\mathrm {i}\theta ).

fr:title.text: Multiplication of complex numbers in exponential form

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Multiplication of complex numbers in exponential form
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 2.3.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z_{1}=r_{1}\mathrm {e}^{\mathrm {i}\theta _{1}}, z_{2}=r_{2}\mathrm {e}^{\mathrm {i}\theta _{2}}\in \mathbb {C} be complex numbers in exponential form. Then z_{1}z_{2}=r_{1}r_{2}\mathrm {e}^{\mathrm {i}(\theta _{1}+\theta _{2})}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: De Moivre's formula
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.3.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z=r(\cos (\theta )+\mathrm {i}\sin (\theta )) be a complex number in polar form. Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. Then:

fr:ol.fr:li: The exponentiation z^{n}=r^{n}(\cos (n\theta )+\mathrm {i}\sin (n\theta ));
The n^{\text {th}} roots of z are given by the n complex numbers z_{k}=r^{1/n}[\cos ((\theta +2\pi k)/n)+\mathrm {i}\sin ((\theta +2\pi k)/n)].

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Root of unity
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 2.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N}. We define the n^{\text {th}} Root of Unity to be 1^{1/n}=\cos (2\pi k/n)+\mathrm {i}\sin (2\pi k/n) where k=1,…,n.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Complex exponential
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 2.3.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z=x+\mathrm {i} y be a complex number with x,y\in \mathbb {R}. Then we define the Complex Exponential to be a function \mathop {\textrm {exp}}\nolimits \colon \mathbb {C}\to \mathbb {C} defined by \mathop {\textrm {exp}}\nolimits (z)=\mathrm {e}^{x}\mathrm {e}^{\mathrm {i} y}=\mathrm {e}^{x}(\cos (y)+\mathrm {i}\sin (y))

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Complex sine and cosine
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 2.3.4

fr:title.text: Properties of complex exponential and trigonometric functions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of complex exponential and trigonometric functions
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.3.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z_{1},z_{2}\in \mathbb {C}. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: \mathrm {e}^{z_{1}+z_{2}}=\mathrm {e}^{z_{1}}\mathrm {e}^{z_{2}} and \mathrm {e}^{z}\neq 0 for any z\in \mathbb {C}

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Extreme value theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 3.1.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f\colon D\to \mathbb {R} be a continuous function on the closed disc D_{R}=\{(x_{1},x_{2})\in \mathbb {R}^{2}\mid x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}\leq R^{2}\} of radius R. Then f is bounded and attains its minimum and maximum values on D. In other words, there exists points x_{\text {min}},x_{\text {max}}\in D such that for all x\in D we have f(x_{\text {min}})\leq f(x)\leq f(x_{\text {max}})

fr:title.text: Modulus of complex polynomial attains a minimum value

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Modulus of complex polynomial attains a minimum value
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 3.1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f\colon \mathbb {C}\to \mathbb {C} be a polynomial function. Then there exists a z_{0}\in \mathbb {C} where |f| attains its minimum value in \mathbb {R}.
Case 1: f is a constant polynomial. Then |f| attains its minimum value at every point in \mathbb {C}, so pick z_{0}=0 and we're done.

Case 2: f is not a constant polynomial. Then we can write it out as f(z)=a_{n}z^{n}+…+a_{1}z+a_{0} where n=\deg (f) is the degree of f, with a_{n}\neq 0. Set A=\max \{|a_{0}|,…,|a_{n}|\} Then we have A/|a_{n}|\geq 1, so |f(z)|\geq |a_{n}||z|^{n}\left (1-\frac {A}{|a_{n}|}\sum ^{\infty }_{k=1}\frac {1}{|z|^{k}}\right )=|a_{n}||z|^{n}\left (1-\frac {A}{|a_{n}|}\frac {1}{|z|-1}\right ) For all z\in \mathbb {C} such that |z|\geq 2, we can simplify this lower bound as |f(z)|\geq |a_{n}||z|^{n}\left (1-\frac {2A}{|a_{n}||z|}\right ) This implies there exists an R>0 such that |f(z)|>|f(0)| for all z\in \mathbb {C} such that |z|>R. Let D\subseteq \mathbb {R}^{2} be the close disk of radius R centered at the origin, then define g\colon D\to \mathbb {R} by g(x,y)=|f(x+\mathrm {i} y)|. Since g is continuous, we apply Extreme value theorem to obtain a point (x_{0},y_{0})\in D such that g attains a minimum at (x_{0},y_{0}). By the choice of R we have that for z\in \mathbb {C}\setminus D, |f(z)|>|g(0,0)|\geq |g(x_{0},y_{0})|. Therefore |f| attains its minimum at z=x_{0}+\mathrm {i} y_{0}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 3.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer, let a_{0},…,a_{n}\in \mathbb {C} be complex numbers with a_{n}\neq 0. Then the polynomial equation a_{n}z^{n}+…+a_{1}z+a_{0}=0 has at least one solution in z\in \mathbb {C}.
(It seems like every field has its own proof of the fundamental theorem of algebra, so I will link them here:)

fr:ul.fr:li: Proof: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra via Extreme Value Theorem
Proof: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra via Galois Theory

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Terminology surrounding polynomials
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 3.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If n=a_{0}=0, then we call p(z)=0 the Zero Polynomial. Convention dictates \deg (0)=-\infty .
We also call:

fr:ul.fr:li: degree zero polnomials are called constant polynomials
degree one polnomials are called linear polynomials
degree two polnomials are called quadratic polynomials
degree three polnomials are called cubic polynomials
degree four polnomials are called quartic polynomials
degree five polnomials are called quintic polynomials
… and so on.

fr:title.text: Properties of degrees of polynomials under arithmetic

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of degrees of polynomials under arithmetic
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 3.2.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let p(z) and q(z) be nonzero polynomials. Then:

fr:ol.fr:li: \deg (p(z)\pm q(z))\leq \max (\deg (p(z)),\deg (q(z))), and

fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 3.2.2

fr:ol.fr:li: For any w\in \mathbb {C}, we have f(w)=0 if there exists a polynomial g\colon \mathbb {C}\to \mathbb {C} of degree \deg (g)=n-1 such that f(z)=(z-w)g(z);
There are at most n distinct complex numbers w\in \mathbb {C} for which f(w)=0; i.e., f has at most n distinct roots;

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A Field is traditionally defined as a set F with two binary operators, addition (denoted +) and multiplication (denoted \cdot ), satisfying the field axioms:

fr:ol.fr:li: Associativity of addition: for all x,y,z\in F, (x+y)+z=x+(y+z)
Commutativity of addition: for all x,y\in F, x+y=y+x
Additive identity: there exists a 0\in F such that for all x\in F we have 0+x=x and x+0=x
Additive inverses: for each x\in F there is a unique y\in F such that x+y=0 and y+x=0; in this case, we usually denote y as (-x)
Associativity of multiplication: for all x,y,z\in F, (x\cdot y)\cdot z=x\cdot (y\cdot z)
Commutativity of multiplication: for all x,y\in F, x\cdot y=y\cdot x
Multiplicative identity: there exists a 1\in F such that for all x\in F we have 1\cdot x=x and x\cdot 1=x
Multiplicative inverses: for each x\in F which is nonzero x\neq 0 there is a unique y\in F such that x\cdot y=1 and y\cdot x=1; usually we denote y as x^{-1}
Distributivity of multiplication over addition: for all x,y,z\in F, we have x\cdot (y+z)=(x\cdot y)+(x\cdot z) and (x+y)\cdot z=(x\cdot z)+(x\cdot y)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Note that some of these are redundant.
Also note: fields are usually written in blackboard bold, and the generic field is either \mathbb {F} or \Bbbk (since the German word for field is "Körper").

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Vector Space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 4.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field. A Vector Space over \mathbb {F} consists of a set V equipped with vector addition +\colon V\times V\to V and scalar multiplication \cdot \colon \mathbb {F}\times V\to V such that:

fr:ol.fr:li: Commutativity: for all u,v\in V, we have u+v=v+u
Associativity: for all u,v,w\in V, we have (u+v)+w=u+(v+w)
Additive identity: there exists a \vec {0}\in V such that for all v\in V we have v+\vec {0}=v
Additive inverse: for each v\in V there exists a w\in V such that v+w=\vec {0}
Associativity of scalar multiplication: for all v\in V and a,b\in \mathbb {F}, we have (ab)v=a(bv)
Multiplicative identity: The multiplicative unital element 1\in \mathbb {F} is such that for all v\in V we have 1v=v
Distributivity: for all a,b\in \mathbb {F} and u,v\in V we have a(u+v)=au+av and (a+b)v=av+bv

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Compare this to the definition of a Real vector space from elementary linear algebra. When \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {R}, we call V a real vector space. When \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {C}, we call V a Complex Vector Space.

fr:title.text: Finite tuples over a field form a vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Finite tuples over a field form a vector space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 4.1.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Consider \mathbb {F}^{n} the set of all n-tuples with values in \mathbb {F}. This is a vector space with addition and multiplication defined by (u_{1},…,u_{n})+(v_{1},…,v_{n})=(u_{1}+v_{1},…,u_{n}+v_{n}) a(u_{1},…,u_{n})=(au_{1},…,au_{n}) Then this really is a vector space.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Vector space of sequences
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 4.1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field. Then \mathbb {F}^{\infty } is the set of all sequences over \mathbb {F}. Then vector addition defined componentwise (u_{k})+(v_{k})=(u_{k}+v_{k}) and scalar multiplication defined componentwise a(u_{n})=(au_{n}) give us a vector space.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Polynomials form a vector space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 4.1.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F}[z] be the set of all polynomial with coefficients in \mathbb {F} and in unknown z. Then defining (p+q)(z)=p(z)+q(z) and (ap)(z)=ap(z) for any a\in \mathbb {F} and p,q\in \mathbb {F}[z] forms vector addition and scalar multiplication.

fr:title.text: Field-valued functions form a vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field-valued functions form a vector space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 4.1.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let D\neq \emptyset be any set. Let \mathbb {F} be a field. Then the Set of all functions \mathbb {F}^{D} forms a vector space. Vector addition of f,g\in \mathbb {F}^{D} is given by (f+g)(x)=f(x)+g(x) for any x\in D, and scalar multiplication is given by (af)(x)=af(x) for any a\in \mathbb {F}.

There are various related vector spaces of interest to Mathematicians. For example, when \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {R} and D\subseteq \mathbb {R}, the set of all continuous real-valued functions on D forms a subspace of \mathbb {R}^{D}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Zero vector is unique
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Then the additive identity \vec {0}\in V is unique.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Additive inverse is unique
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. For each v\in V, there is a unique additive inverse of v in V.
Suppose w and w' are additive inverses of v. Then w=w+0=w+(v+w')=(w+v)+w'=0+w'=w' which gives us w=w' as desired.
Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. We denote by -v the additive inverse of v\in V.
Similarly, for any v,w\in V, we denote by v-w the expression v+(-w).

fr:title.text: Scalar multiplication by zero gives zero vector

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Scalar multiplication by zero gives zero vector
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let v\in V and 0_{F}\in \mathbb {F}. Then 0_{F}v=\vec {0}.
We see by distributivity, 0_{F}v=(0_{F}+0_{F})v=0_{F}v+0_{F}v, and then subtracting 0_{F}v from both sides yields \vec {0}=0_{F}v-0_{F}v=(0_{F}v+0_{F}v)-0_{F}v=0_{F}v as desired.

fr:title.text: Scalar multiples of zero vector are the zero vector

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Scalar multiples of zero vector are the zero vector
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let \vec {0}\in V and a\in \mathbb {F}. Then a\vec {0}=\vec {0}.
We see a\vec {0}=a(\vec {0}+\vec {0})=a\vec {0}+a\vec {0}, then adding the additive inverse of a\vec {0} to both sides yields the result.

fr:title.text: Negating a vector by multiplying by minus one

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Negating a vector by multiplying by minus one
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let v\in V. Then (-1)v=-v.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subspace
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 4.3.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let U\subseteq V be a subset. Then we call U a Subspace of V if U is a vector space over \mathbb {F} under the same operations that make V a vector space over \mathbb {F}.
